INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the procedures laid down by the Senate under its resolutions of 25 February 1988, Senator McGauran has raised with me a matter of privilege. The matter which he has raised is an allegation that Senator Schacht, in speaking during the adjournment debate last night, made use of an unauthorised record of proceedings of a meeting involving senators and disclosed those proceedings without the permission of the meeting. Under the procedures prescribed by the Senate, I am required to determine whether a motion relating to the matter should have precedence over other business, and in doing so I am required to have regard to certain criteria.

INTERJECT.PARA: In assessing this matter, I have assumed that the facts are as alleged, namely, that the proceedings of the meeting were recorded and disclosed without the authorisation of the meeting, and I have considered whether such actions should be investigated as a matter possibly involving contempt of the Senate. The Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 provides, in section 4, that the essential element of a contempt is that it involves `an improper interference with the free exercise by a House or committee of its authority or functions, or with the free performance by a member of the member's duty as a member'. I believe that it would be stretching the contempt jurisdiction of the Senate beyond its proper bounds to hold that an unauthorised disclosure of the proceedings of an informal meeting of senators could constitute an improper interference of the kind referred to in that section.

Moreover, one of the criteria to which I am required to have regard is `the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for Senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions'. I do not consider that the matter raised meets this criterion, in that, even if the facts are as alleged, it would not in my view be open to the Senate to find that there had been an improper act tending substantially to obstruct the Senate, its committees or senators. For these reasons I have determined that a motion relating to the matter should not have precedence over other business.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates has raised with me another matter as a result of the remarks made by Senator Schacht last night, namely, the security of the sound reinforcement system in committee rooms. I am advised that the meeting in question was publicly announced and listed on the television monitors throughout the building. There is some evidence to suggest that the broadcast system may have been active during the meeting in question. I have asked the Usher of the Black Rod and the Parliamentary Information Systems Office to make an urgent and full investigation of the matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am very concerned about these matters, as is Madam Speaker. Following receipt of a full report on it, the Speaker and I will direct that the system be modified in such a manner as to ensure that participants in meetings in the committee rooms will be aware at all times of the status of the broadcasting and sound reinforcement systems in the rooms. In particular, it will be important to ensure that during private meetings the systems are completely inactive and that occupants of the rooms have a clear indication that the systems are inactive. I will keep honourable senators fully informed on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has never happened before! Party meetings are not leaked in this building!

It is of a totally different nature, in a building which is extensively wired for recording, if rooms in this building cannot be used with confidence that meetings are not being taped. This is a very serious matter in terms of the operation of this institution. It is a matter which the Opposition takes extremely seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: I make no challenge at this time to the view you have expressed, Mr President, that this is not a matter of privilege. It would be too early for me to do that, given that your own opinion has had to be based on an assumption as to the facts which is not proven. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Senator Schacht.
—I cannot remember exactly when it was held, but the meeting to which reference was made was publicly known to everybody because it was listed on the VTX.
—It is open to anyone to see that.

—It was open to anyone to see that a meeting was to be held. I am not drawing any inferences as to what persons may have done when they saw the notice of that meeting. Having been a senator for a long time, it disturbs me that last night the document was not tabled because I was not present. The vote was 28 votes to 28. I do not usually depart this place so early, but at about 5 past 10 Senator Walters was asking Senator Walsh questions and I thought, `That ought to see it out for the rest of the night'. I was not advised by Senator Schacht-and I am very disappointed about this-that this matter was to be discussed, notwithstanding the fact that I attended a meeting of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters with Senator Schacht only a few hours beforehand. Over a period I have implicitly trusted all of my colleagues in this chamber and in the other chamber, whether or not they disagree with me on issues. I hope that that mutual trust has always been there, whether or not they disagree with me on issues. I am a little disconcerted because this element of trust is now at stake.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that a recording was made because statements were quoted verbatim. The worst part of it was that those verbatim statements were taken completely out of context last night, and it was quite unfair for that to be done. That is another reason why I would like to see that full document tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that it costs more than $600 to pack a container at depots manned by Waterside Workers Federation of Australia (WWF) labour compared with less than $400 at those manned by the Transport Workers Union of Australia (TWU) and the National Union of Workers? Does he know that automotive companies have on occasions shipped products from Japan to Singapore by sea, and then air freighted them into Australia simply to avoid the waterfront depots manned by the WWF? Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister, who said on 10 April that the issue of union coverage is `not central to the thrust of reform' on the waterfront and that the WWF's concerns in this area are `understandable' and can be accommodated? If he does agree with the Prime Minister's statement, does this mean that the Government will be rejecting the recommendation of the Inter-State Commission (ISC) on depot coverage, which is for the Waterside Workers Federation to man waterfront depots and the TWU or National Union of Workers to man inland depots, with free competition among those depots subject only to customs regulations? Would he agree that failure to implement this essential recommendation of the Inter-State Commission would seriously undermine the ISC's strategy of creating a more competitive environment on the waterfront?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question, I am not aware of the figures mentioned by Senator Chaney. I would be very surprised if they were true. The WWF has been playing a very constructive role in identifying joint venture and other forms of activity, which have been designed to effectively reduce streamline costs on the waterfront. I think that it is as conscious as anyone else of the need for efficiencies to continue to occur in that area.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question asked whether I agree with the Prime Minister that the coverage issue is not central to resolution of the waterfront package. Of course I agree with the Prime Minister. I would not dare to do otherwise. And I agree as to the substance of what he said. It is the case that the coverage issue was not one that was in any way central to or even in any significant way part of the ISC recommendations. Of course, the big problems on the waterfront, which we unequivocally acknowledge do exist, can be addressed without opening up in any major way that particular problem, if indeed it is a problem.
As to what the statement would, will or should contain on this issue and related issues, Senator Chaney will simply have to wait until that statement is delivered later this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I regret that a Minister who has presumably been discussing these matters in Cabinet is unaware of some of the basic figures. Will he check those figures about comparative costs between Waterside Workers Federation manned depots and depots manned by other unions? Will he also check the figures on the proportion of containers which are actually loaded-that is, the volume of loading which is achieved at WWF depots as against depots manned by other unions? —I will take that part of the question on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Government aware that the report into the April 1988 Aloha Airlines aircraft accident in Hawaii, in which a major roof section tore away from an aircraft, is shortly to be released by the United States National Transportation Safety Board? In view of mounting concern in Australia about ageing civil aircraft of all types, can the Minister reassure the Australian public that the findings in the United States report will be examined closely by the Civil Aviation Authority here and that any necessary actions will be taken as a matter of urgency? Finally, has the Australian Government been advised of United States reports that the banning of smoking on domestic airliners, which I fully support, can make it more difficult to detect metal fatigue cracks on aircraft bodies compared with the situation in the past when small nicotine stains on the exterior of aircraft reportedly helped in the discovery of cracks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly apparent that any cracks on VIP aircraft will well and truly show up with the Prime Minister's cigars. I do not know about that part of the question relating to nicotine stains. Of all the bizarre justifications I have heard for continuing to allow smoking on aircraft, that is probably close to the limit but I will follow up that part of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the early parts of the question, the Civil Aviation Authority's representative in Washington has advised the Civil Aviation Authority of the Board's finding on the probable causes of the Aloha Airlines accident. The full report has not yet been received, but the Civil Aviation Authority has given an undertaking that the report will be carefully examined and any necessary action taken. The honourable senator should be aware, however, that the four contributory causes do not directly affect any Australian aircraft, any Australian operator or the Australian airworthiness authority. All findings relate to lap joint desponding and metal fatigue in early model Boeing 737 aircraft and no aircraft of this configuration are flying in Australia. However, the Civil Aviation Authority is very aware of the implications for similar fatigue and corrosion problems in other aircraft types which are currently operating in Australia and which may enter this country following economic deregulation of the industry in 1990. The airworthiness area of the Civil Aviation Authority is actively working on this problem in association with Australian operators, overseas manufacturers and overseas airworthiness authorities. A research program involving a composite preventative repair of lap joints is currently being negotiated between the Civil Aviation Authority and the Aeronautical Research Laboratories in Melbourne.

The matter of ageing aircraft in general has been closely considered by the industry and the United States Federal Aviation Administration recently. A large number of changes to maintenance practices and procedures for these aircraft will start to be introduced shortly in the United States. It is anticipated that their introduction to Australia will follow in respect of those models which operate in Australia.

I have a note here about the nicotine question. I am advised that much more reliable methods than nicotine stain examination are readily available for this purpose. I am delighted to inform the Senate that, although in the past cracks have sometimes been found in this way, the ban on smoking, therefore, has not made it more difficult to detect fatigue cracking. If the honourable senator wants further chapter and verse on that matter I would be delighted to do some research and dig the information out for him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer's words in his April economic statement when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: If a government cannot run wages in Australia, it cannot run the Australian economy.
I ask the Minister whether he has noted that in the Australian national accounts document released last Thursday the Australian Statistician pointed out:
In current price, seasonally adjusted terms, wages, salaries and supplements rose by 3.4 per cent in the March quarter 1989, following a rise of 4.5 per cent in the previous quarter . . .

That is, an 8 per cent rise during those six months. Has the total rise in wages, salaries and supplements during the 12 months to March 1989 amounted to no less than 11.7 per cent? How do these figures compare with the Treasurer's Budget forecast of a growth in average earnings on the same national accounts basis of 6 1/2 per cent this year? Given a national productivity increase of-and I will be generous-2 per cent per annum, is the Minister in any way concerned about the implications of this sharp rise in wage costs, for both inflation and hence the value of the Australian dollar? Finally, does the Minister agree that, on the basis of these figures, the Government has failed the Treasurer's own test of economic competence?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have little doubt that what the Treasurer had in mind when he said that if a government could not run a wages policy it could not run the Australian economy was the spectacular failure of the previous coalition Government, especially in 1981 and 1982, when we had wage increases of 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively. It is true that there have been other periods of extraordinary, unacceptably high wages growth. One of those periods was during the term of the Labor Government in 1973-74. The situation is not unique, but the last wages explosion in this country was presided over, if not engineered by, the last coalition Government. I will check for the record, but the figures that Senator Stone had quoted for wages, salaries and supplements for the March quarter of the year as a whole are, I believe, the aggregate figures. In other words, they measure the total payments and not the unit costs. Therefore, they are a highly inaccurate measure of unit costs because they can be heavily influenced. In that particular 12 months they would have been heavily influenced by increases in the number of people employed and, to a lesser degree, by increases in overtime worked. I do not think the increase in real unit labour costs over the period is known yet. It is certainly not known by me. It will become available at some later stage. But that is the relevant figure, if one is looking at wages, and not the total payments. If everything else remained the same and the number of people employed doubled, obviously wages costs would double but without unit labour costs being changed at all.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the test firing by India of an intermediate range ballistic missile, as reported on 22 May. Does the Australian Government regard this as a significant change in the Indian Ocean strategic environment and, if so, what is the Government's response to such a change?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should say in general terms at the outset that the introduction to any region in the world of ballistic missiles of greater than tactical range is likely to make that regional security environment more tense and less stable, especially if such weapons were to be associated or suspected of being associated with chemical or nuclear warheads. United States intelligence, at least as reported in the press, suggests that more than 15 countries, including India, Pakistan, Argentina, Brazil, Israel and Egypt, are now engaged in developing long range ballistic missiles. If any country introduces this type of weapon, others in the region are likely to follow, diminishing as a result the security of all states in the region.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has very carefully noted Prime Minister Gandhi's public statements about the launch, statements to the effect that AGNI is a research and developmental vehicle, not a weapons system, and that India has set an example to the world of a refusal to convert nuclear capability into nuclear weapons and wishes to keep it this way. The Government will continue to urge that governments think long and hard about the implications of developing operational long range missile forces. May I say finally that I will have the opportunity to discuss these matters in New Delhi with relevant Ministers at the end of next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to my letter to him of 7 April requesting information about the request by James Walker Australia Pty Ltd for the removal of the 10 per cent import duty on aluminium-coated mild steel sheet in coils used in the manufacture of automotive exhaust systems. First, was the Government's decision in December 1987 to discontinue concessional arrangements regarding the import of aluminised steel designed to protect the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), which produces zircalum, a similar material also used in the manufacture of exhaust systems? Is the Minister aware that BHP apparently supports the removal of this duty providing the material is imported for use in the manufacture of exhaust systems only? Secondly, is the Minister aware that since the import duty on this product was increased from 2 per cent to 10 per cent in 1987, Walker Australia has been significantly disadvantaged in favour of its New Zealand competitors, who are able to import aluminium coated mild steel sheet from Japan on a duty free basis? Can the Minister explain why the Government is allowing a situation to continue whereby a New Zealand manufacturer of exhaust systems is able to gain more of the Australian market for that product due to the imposition of a duty which currently protects no-one? Further, can the Minister explain why the Government, which was so keen to advance the interests of BHP in this matter, is apparently not interested in assisting Walker Australia, the largest manufacturer of exhaust systems in the country, if, as it claims, it is not seeking the imposition of bounties, duties or other barriers to prevent competition from the import of similar products from New Zealand but, rather, is seeking the removal of the duty on this product in order to give it the same competitive base for raw materials as its New Zealand counterparts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The burden of this question is whether the Government is about helping BHP as distinct from a company called Walker Australia. The concessional arrangements for aluminised steel to which Senator Haines refers were discontinued from 30 September 1987 following a report of the Industries Assistance Commission which recommended that course of action, namely, that the concessional entry arrangements be abolished.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true, as Senator Haines says, that BHP now supports the removal of the duty, but for a specific end use only: the manufacture of a particular product-in this case, exhaust systems. However, the commercial tariff concession system does not allow concessional entry conditioned by end use. In other words, one cannot obtain concessional entry for a particular end use. That is because end use by-laws-so-called-present economic and administrative drawbacks, and should be resorted to only in very exceptional circumstances.

As part of the burden of her question, Senator Haines raised the issue of the detriment to the competitiveness of Walkers as against New Zealand manufacturers. It is true that the imposition of a 10 per cent duty would, in theory at least, disadvantage Walkers against some overseas suppliers. In that connection, there are two points to be made. First, the cost impact is approximately $2 per exhaust system. That, in itself, is unlikely to be a significant disadvantage. Secondly, so far as competing in the New Zealand or any overseas market is concerned, companies such as Walkers, which import aluminised steel and pay a 10 per cent duty on it, are eligible to use the by-law for export scheme. They get a rebate, as it were, of any duty they pay on aluminised steel. Therefore, if they are operating in export markets, that duty does not affect them.

Those are the facts of the matter. The Government does not favour BHP over Walkers. The position is determined by an Industries Assistance Commission report and a policy long standing, and that is consistent with overall policy in relation to all industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Despite the early part of Senator Button's answer, the burden of my question was not about continuing a bounty that protects BHP, but was about continuing a bounty that apparently acts to protect no-one in Australia while benefiting a New Zealand company. Whilst the Minister may not think that $2 on an item is much, Walkers apparently is concerned that it is being disadvantaged, not vis-a-vis BHP but vis-a-vis a New Zealand company. I ask again whether the Government is prepared to consider removing that bounty, as, apparently, it did recently in the case of Shearers.

—The honourable senator is confusing bounties with concessional entry. I ask her to read Hansard before pursuing this issue further with me. I think that if she does that, she will understand. The burden of her question was intended to gain a little publicity: `Government discriminates against small company in favour of BHP'. The Government is not doing that, for reasons that I have explained.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Why does the Minister maintain that the military in Indonesia should not act in a traditional military fashion by assessing Australia's military posture as a potential threat, given the acquisition of new offensive weapon systems such as the FA18s, with a refuelling capability, six new submarines, backed up by the Geraldton spy base, and a chain of new military bases across the north of Australia, and the holding of the largest peacetime exercise ever held in Australia, starting this July? I draw the Minister's attention to the striking similarity between Kamaria and islands in the Indonesian archipelago. I ask, further, why the Minister insists that the Indonesian military should feel happy with these developments when statements, not only by retired Lieutenant-General Hasnan Habib but also by Dr Des Ball of the Australian National University's Strategic and Defence Studies Centre and Russell Rollason of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, indicate that the Indonesians are concerned. I ask also what the Government's reaction would be if Indonesia were to build a chain of military bases along the archipelago facing south, acquire new aircraft and submarines facing in the same direction, and top it all by holding a massive $96m military exercise aimed at a mythical nation that lies roughly where Australia is on the map. Finally, has the Minister seen articles in the West Australian of 29 April and the Sunday Territorian of 7 May, which draw lurid scenarios of an invasion of Australia by Indonesian commandos on trail bikes? Does he believe that such scenarios are credible, and that they are helpful in improving relations between Australia and Indonesia?

—Mr President, on a point of order: this question and the one before it were really quite out of order in terms of their length. I ask you, Mr President, to make a statement about the length of questions during Question Time.
—I am aware of the length of the previous question. I think it is something that the appropriate committee should look at.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine's question relates to remarks made by General Hasnan Habib over the weekend. General Habib was speaking purely in a personal capacity. The official spokesman for the Indonesian armed forces, General Nwihadi, has been quoted as saying as recently as yesterday that Indonesia does not see any threat coming from Australia. Australia's defence posture is, in the broadest sense, defensive and the force structure that we are developing reflects this. We have discussed our defence posture and force structure with the Indonesian Government at the highest levels. It has expressed its understanding of the policies that we have adopted. In relation to Kangaroo 89, there is no similarity between Indonesia and Kamaria.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vallentine asked how we would respond to developments in Indonesia's defence posture. Of course, we recognise Indonesia's right to develop a force structure which meets its security needs just as it recognises our right to do the same. The articles referred to by Senator Vallentine in the Territorian were lurid and sensational. The Australian Government values good relations with Indonesia. We have no reason to believe that Indonesia would undertake hostile acts against Australia; nor do we have any reason to undertake such acts against Indonesia. Therefore, the Minister for Defence does not believe that the scenarios in these articles were credible; nor were they helpful in improving relations between the two countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In the light of the statement that Senator Walsh gave the Senate on Monday, 11 May, regarding the estimated figure that would have been borne by the taxpayer had the 1986-87 season guaranteed minimum price (GMP) of wheat been set at 95 per cent of the subject year only, that is, $300m-the statement can be seen on page 2361 of Hansard-I ask the Minister whether he has reconsidered his estimates. Was he aware at the time that the 1986-87 subject year forecast was set at $125.72 when the GMP was calculated and that the 1986-87 pool finally returned $125.50, which is 98.8 per cent of the forecast figure? If so, does he agree that the taxpayer would not have been liable for any pay-out at all at 95 per cent of GMP? Finally, when can it be expected that the Minister will correct his misleading statement?

—I thought Senator Panizza might take this up because he mentioned it to me privately some weeks ago, but I thought he would do it last week and I have been trying to find my note which was supplied to me from elsewhere. For the record, the basis of the round figure of $300m which I used in that debate-I had used the figure of $200m before which was based on a misreading by me of the handwritten figures I had in front of me at the time-going back to the collapse in wheat prices in 1986-87, was a forecast average return price of $157 for Australian standard white, which was taken from the May 1986 Quarterly Review of the rural economy, and actual average export price for ASW taken from the December 1988 Quarterly Review and an export quantity of almost 16 million tonnes in that year. It is fairly obvious that there was a difference in the May Quarterly Review forecast between the actual realisation of $20 a tonne and an export quantity of nearly 16 million tonnes. The figure, on that basis, has come down to slightly over $300m.
—I have a mini-question for the Minister for Resources.
—I hope he gives a mini-answer.

—We are going to try to save the trees by keeping the answer short as well. I refer the Minister to reports of the recent meeting of the International Tropical Timber Organisation (ITTO). Did Australia participate in this meeting? If so, what was the nature of our participation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did participate in the meeting. It was held on the Ivory Coast last week. The ITTO has been going for about three years. Forty-three countries-some of them producers, some of them consumers-are members of the ITTO. Australia has been a member since February 1988. The ITTO Council met last week. A representative of my Department represented Australia at the meeting. With the concurrence of the Malaysian Government the ITTO Council undertook to make a study in Sarawak of rainforest cutting practices and what conservation and human rights issues needed to be considered in the context of what is going on in Sarawak at present. The study team consists of Bolivia, the Ivory Coast and Indonesia representing the producers and Japan, the United States and a Nordic country-probably Norway or Sweden-representing the consumers. On the non-government organisation side environmental organisations will choose someone from the United Kingdom and someone in the timber trade from Denmark.

ANSWER.PARA: The study will assess the sustainable utilisation of tropical timbers in rainforest areas and conservation and environmental measures that are necessary. It will focus on human rights concerns of the local indigenous people, including the Penan people about whom there has been some publicity in Australia recently. An Australian doctor, Alf Leslie, who is the former head of forestry at the Food and Agriculture Organisation headquarters in Rome, will lead the forestry component of the study. Australia will make a $US50,000 contribution to the cost of completing the study.

I note that the World Wildlife Fund, in acknowledging what the ITTO had done, in a press release last Thursday said that this was `a key victory' in the battle to save the world's remaining tropical rainforests. It went on to describe the initiative I have outlined to the Senate. It concluded its press release with these words:
It is pleasing to see that the Australian Government delegation has played its part in the support of these developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen the call from the National Conference of Young Workers and Unions-a call now being studied by the Australian Council of Trade Unions-to eliminate junior pay rates from all wages? Have the movements in the past towards abolition or reduction of junior pay differentials been principally motivated by the desire of adult trade unionists to reduce employment competition from juniors by pricing them out of the market? Is this new campaign primarily directed at increasing union membership? In view of the deplorably high rates of unemployment among young people does this new campaign not represent a cruel hoax on young people by reducing their opportunities for jobs in which they can gain employment, experience and self-respect? Will the Government take action against any such moves to perpetuate this cruel hoax on young people whose consequences can be seen, among other areas, in the widely advertised problems of homeless and unemployed youth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report of the Conference, nor did I know that the Conference had been held. I do not think I am in any position to make judgments or even to speculate about the motives of the people who put up that proposition. The belief which most of us probably subscribe to is that if there is a choice between a conspiracy and-I am trying to think of a more polite term than the vernacular term-a muck-up, then we should go for the muck-up instead of the conspiracy and we will be right nearly all the time. I suspect that that could be applied in this case.

ANSWER.PARA: The relationship between wage levels and relative unemployment rates for young people has long been a matter of debate and the subject of academic articles. It has not, nor will it ever be, decisively settled. Many young economists will become doctors of philosophy writing theses about it for the next few decades. I certainly do not want to become involved in that debate other than to draw the obvious conclusion that at some point there must be an inverse relationship between wage levels and employability or employment opportunities. More certain is the conclusion that, if there is absolutely no relationship between wage levels for juniors and employment or unemployment rates for juniors, nothing can be gained from providing wage subsidies to employers to employ such people. That conclusion is inescapable, but some of the people who argue most vehemently that there is no relationship between junior wages relative to adult wages and junior unemployment rates relative to adult unemployment rates are some of the keenest proponents of wage subsidy schemes to stimulate employment for juniors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources to explain how he can claim to have considered all prudent and feasible alternatives to logging in National Estate forests in south-eastern New South Wales when, on his own admission, no environmental impact statement (EIS) has been completed which examines possible alternative cutting plans outside the National Estate areas for 1989. Could the Minister explain why he has based some of his calculations of timber resources available outside National Estate areas on the unlikely scenario that current rainfall in the district, which is a one in 20-year event, will continue for the remainder of the year? What exactly has the Minister done to assure himself, under section 5c of the Harris-Daishowa woodchip export licence, that supplies of sawmill and logging residue available to the company in the Eden woodchip management area are being utilised to the fullest extent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the first question, I tabled in the Senate last week a consideration of how I had met my obligations in studying the prudent and feasible alternatives under section 30, I think it is, of the Heritage Act. The consideration that I entered into is set out in that document. However, the question related to whether there are limits on what areas have been studied by environmental impact statements and why I did not find prudent and feasible alternatives in those areas. The answer to that question is simply this: as a consequence of a case taken by the environmental movement in the New South Wales Land and Environment Court, the Jarasius case, areas of forest that have not been subjected to an environmental impact statement in my view quite rightly cannot be cut until an environmental impact statement has been conducted. The New South Wales Forestry Commission is conducting an environmental impact statement at present for its cutting for the next calendar year operations. That EIS will be completed in October or maybe early November this year and that will in part show me what prudent and feasible alternatives there might be in other areas outside the National Estate.

ANSWER.PARA: In any case, the proposal that I put to the New South Wales Government as terms for the Harris-Daishowa woodchip export licence are proposals which would enable me to complete a comprehensive study of the whole of the south-east forest, not just the National Estate areas of that forest, and to make a detailed consideration of prudent and feasible alternatives for the whole of the forest area at the end of the study period I proposed-one year. If the New South Wales Government adopted my proposal, we would be in a position, at the end of the 12-month study period, to plan the long term development of the industry and the long term protection of the environment in the south-east. The prudent and feasible alternatives that I now study are limited by the time span within which I have had to work and that time span after the year I have referred to will be much broader.

The second question related to the current rainfall in the area. I have to work on the basis that there are unseasonal and early rains, that they are heavy rains and that they may occur once in 20 years, but they are the rains we are having at present. I cannot plan on the basis of assuming that these rains will suddenly stop and that the one year in 20 scenario will not be realised. I have to plan on the basis of what is practically the case, what is the real operation, and I have done so. If, for some reason, there is a drought between now and the end of the 12-month period and there are no further rains, and if access to parts of the forest which is now not available can be obtained, enabling prudent and feasible alternatives outside the National Estate to be accessed, we would alter our cutting plan to provide for that. That would be a sensible thing to do.

Senator Dunn asked what I have done about section 5c. That is an ongoing issue. It is a matter that is regularly monitored. My Department is kept informed of it. There are two commercial constraints. Sawmills would not send material to Harris-Daishowa for processing as woodchips if they had a commercial use for that material, because the best return for them is to cut logs on the basis of their sawmilling use. The income they receive for the material they send to Harris-Daishowa is less than the income they would receive for their sawmilling operation, so there is that commercial constraint on millable material not going for woodchip use.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Pending the outcome of the biological resources study will the Minister undertake not to grant Harris-Daishowa permission to export until he is in possession of adequate information regarding the timber resource outside the National Estate areas?

—The answer to that question is no. We have an operation that we want to see continue as a woodchip operation so that this country can confront the problem of being $1.6 billion in trade deficit in forest products. In order to move upstream in dealing with our forest output, we need a woodchip operation so that we can move into pulp manufacture, so that we can move into paper manufacture, and so that we can stop being a country that exports raw materials in the form of woodchips and buys back expensive materials in the form of finished paper products. Therefore, I do not see a reason to put this woodchip company out of operation for a period and then require it to start up again, just on the basis of awaiting the outcome of the particular study that Senator Dunn has referred to. The plan which I have put to the New South Wales Government is prudent and feasible, and meets the requirements.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Is the estimated future liability to public servants for Commonwealth superannuation benefits in the vicinity of $25 billion to $30 billion? Has the Government examined options for limiting the explosive growth of this liability, including paying out beneficiaries' entitlements in the form of lump sums either compulsorily or at the option of members? What future savings would accrue to the Commonwealth if such an approach were to be adopted? What improvements in Public Service morale and performance does the Minister envisage from the introduction of this more flexible approach? When will the Government announce the findings of its review of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme (CSS) to allow, amongst other things, the Government's business enterprises such as Telecom Australia and Australia Post to establish and fully control their own superannuation arrangements on a more commercial basis?

—I will answer this question on the Commonwealth superannuation scheme in my own capacity, as Finance Minister. I cannot remember what the present value liability of the existing CSS is, but I know it is a lot of money. The $25 billion or $30 billion figure that Senator Messner mentioned might well be correct, but I really do not know. As for the rest of the question, I think a submission has been lodged-certainly it has been cleared by me-to go to Cabinet. I am not sure when it will be considered by Cabinet; I am not in control of the Cabinet agenda, but I expect that some time in the next week or two it will go to Cabinet, along with recommendations by me, on a new Commonwealth superannuation scheme. At this stage I do not think I should provide any precise details of those recommendations other than to say that the review and the submission which finally came out of it have taken into account the sorts of issues that Senator Messner raised.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware of the Opposition's proposals to cut defence spending? Has the Government examined those proposals and will it implement a real reduction in defence outlays in the August Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some proposals by some Opposition members to cut defence spending. For example, when Mr Peacock became Opposition Leader three weeks ago, or whenever it was, he made Mr Carlton the shadow Minister for defence and said:

ANSWER.PARA: I've spelt out the requirements to Mr Carlton as to what I want him to do. I have served myself in a defence related portfolio. I know what has to be done in cutting the fat there and I regard Mr Carlton as the expert to do that in government.

That was fighting stuff from the new Leader. He was establishing his new tough image, and trying to rationalise his decision to keep John Howard off the front bench by denying him the defence portfolio. That is, one might think, the kind of thing that might lift a government to have another look at defence spending, which was of course scrutinised by the Government prior to the April statement. However, on Saturday we found out that the Opposition's nerve seemed to be failing it on this matter. Mr Carlton was interviewed by Paul Malone from the Canberra Times. I would like to refer to the whole article but I will select a couple of excerpts. Mr Carlton was asked by Paul Malone:
But is there any way of doing these things-increasing morale, having more operations, ammunition and so on-without spending more money?
I don't know yet. That's the real answer to that question. You certainly can't do it by cutting the money any more. That's absolutely right.
You certainly can't do it by cutting the money any more. That's absolutely right.

That was a very different tune from the one that Mr Peacock was singing less than three weeks before. It was a very different tune from that sung by some other pipsqueaks on the Opposition front bench in this chamber who are forever demanding more money to be spent on defence. The interview continued:
So absolutely no less money will go to the manpower side of things . . .

The April statement has cut the thing way back to zero real increase. Well, we couldn't credibly go into anything that would go below that. Now, I've got to sort out with my colleagues just at what level we go in or what formula we use.

The interview continued in a similar vein. I table the record of the interview and note again not only, most importantly, the total contradiction between what the Leader of the Opposition was saying less than three weeks ago and what his defence spokesman was saying last week but also the much less important contradiction between some pipsqueaks on the Opposition front bench here and the Leader of the Opposition.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELECOM AUSTRALIA: DEVELOPMENT OF OFFICE COMPLEX

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that Telecom Australia has let a contract to build a major corporate office complex in the Melbourne central business district (CBD) at a total estimated cost in excess of $300m? Was the Government informed before such a decision was taken? Can the Minister explain why a Telecom Taj Mahal needs to be built in the central business district rather than in the outer suburban areas? Is it a fact that Telecom sought advice from developers and property agents and was informed that, in view of the current glut of commercial office space, it would have been possible to have bought a suitable existing building for half the proposed cost?
—Whereabouts?

—In the CBD. Is the flagrant example of conspicuous extravagance driven by a desire to convert a likely operating profit figure in excess of $1 billion into a capital asset rather than to reduce prices for its long-suffering customers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the question is not indicative of the quality of questioning that we are to get from the new communications spokesman, because it does not say much for the kind of confidence that the Opposition would be willing to vest in the Board's management and judgment and indeed all the arm's length distance from government decision-making which it urges upon us constantly. The point of the matter is that Telecom has a board under the highly effective and experienced chairmanship of Mr Alec Morokoff, and a Vice-Chairman, Bill Dix. Of course, they are very experienced in industry affairs. They are perfectly capable of making sensible decisions of this kind and they are not the kinds of decisions that the Government is minded to second-guess even if we had the power to do so under the self-denying new government business enterprise ground rules that have been identified.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular information I have about the corporate headquarters is as follows: Telecom, in association with private sector consultants, has developed specifications for the construction of a major corporate office building in Exhibition Street, Melbourne. It is proposed that design documentation and construction will be carried out using consultants, building contractors and suppliers from the private sector. Tenders were invited for the project on 25 January and closed on 8 March this year. At its meeting on 13 April, the Telecom board, the composition of which I have mentioned, decided to proceed with the construction of the building as the most financially viable option available. The contract was signed on 11 May 1989 with Grocon Ltd for the construction of the building.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health seen the thoughtful and considered editorial in Monday's edition of the Adelaide Advertiser supporting the Government's reforms to health legislation with the proposals for reinsurance and rebuking the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for opposing the legislation `by playing politics rather than caring for people'? In the light of considered support from the community and, in particular, various pensioner groups, can the Minister say what the consequences of sending this legislation to a Senate committee would be in terms of both costs and the effects on people?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Puplick

When Senator Panizza asked a question on the wheat legislation, which is before this place, we did not object. We do it time and time again. Senator Panizza asked a question about the history of payments under the Wheat Act.
—Something that could well be raised when the Bill comes on for debate.

—One can raise anything when a Bill is under discussion; but the point is that the question related specifically to matters of history on which facts are relevant and will be relevant to a future debate. It in no way raised the issue of the legislation itself. I therefore suggest that it is a totally irrelevant point as far as this point of order is concerned.

—On that point of order, Mr President: I take objection to the point of order brought by Senator Puplick. —Please do not ask for it to be read again!

—You wrote it.

—I did not write it. As I recall, the first part of the question related to an editorial in Monday's edition of the Adelaide Advertiser. I do not see how I can say any more about it other than to draw the attention of the Senate to that editorial.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Crowley also asked for the costs involved in referring any of this matter to a Senate committee. I think I answered a question on this matter last week. TALK.START.PARA: —My question, to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, follows the question from Senator Alston, which the Minister did not answer. Is it a fact that the Government will make a statement on government business enterprises next Thursday as part of its attempt to show that the Government is serious about micro-economic reform? Does the Government accept that the efficiency of government business enterprises is an important matter, going to the effectiveness of the Australian economy and to the solving of our current economic problems? When the Minister has answered those questions I further ask him-and I am repeating the questions which he failed to answer a moment ago-whether the Government was informed of the decision of Telecom Australia to build a major corporate office complex in the central business district (CBD) of Melbourne at an estimated cost in excess of $3000m. Can the Minister explain why the building needs to be in the central business district, rather than in some suburban area? Is it a fact that Telecom sought advice from developers and property agents and was informed that, in view of the current glut of commercial office space, it would have been possible to buy a suitable existing building for half the proposed cost? These seem to be matters which go very clearly to the efficiency of that major statutory body, that major government business enterprise, so will he please give an adequate response on this occasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

ANSWER.PARA: I may need to get some further information on aspects of the question as it affects the Telecom decision, particularly the choice as between the CBD and a suburban location, but I am able to say on the basis of further briefing material in front of me that, as part of the evaluation process of the tenders to which I referred for the Telecom building, firm offers were sought from the industry for appropriate lease packages as well as build and buy back proposals for the accommodation required to be provided in the Melbourne CBD.
