At its meeting on 13 April, to which I referred earlier, the Telecom Board decided to proceed with the construction of the proposed building development as the most financially attractive option available in the current market and also one which, I am advised, offered significant operational advantages over leasing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that more adequate attempt to answer the question. I ask a supplementary question: Did any of the alternatives that were considered-it appears not on the face of what he has told us-include the purchase of a suitable existing building? Is it a fact that the advice to Telecom from developers and property agents was that it could have bought a suitable existing building for half of the proposed cost of the new building?

—I will seek further advice on that subject, but I would remind the Opposition that it is going to have to make up its mind what it wants so far as government business enterprises are concerned and so far as the kind of confidence it is prepared to vest in the boards and managements of those institutions is concerned.
—You don't want to know, is that what you are saying? You don't want to know what they are doing.
—Senator Alston wants to privatise Telecom so as to take it completely out of the reach of any government capacity to influence decisions. He has made that perfectly clear.
—No.

—Is he denying that? What is his position on the subject of privatising Telecom? I would like to hear some more about that from him. The Opposition is full of rhetoric. It is full to the brim of empty rhetoric about the need for these enterprises to make proper commercial decisions and yet, when it is faced with any such decision on which it thinks it can score a cheap, quick political point, it is up and in like Flynn. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. We will be constantly drawing attention to that anomaly in its approach.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. In view of the Prime Minister's promise in 1985, the International Year of Youth, to bring Austudy and unemployment benefits into line, and in view of the fact that as at 30 December 1988 people over the age of 21 who chose to enter tertiary studies received $97 a week at the level of full independent status while those on unemployment benefits received $116, plus a $10 rental allowance if applicable, when will the Prime Minister's promise be fulfilled by the Government?
—I do not accept as being accurate the premise upon which the question was framed. My recollection is that the under 21 rates have been aligned. I will refer that to the Minister for confirmation.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, concerns reports that there may be health concerns arising out of the use of dioxin to bleach milk cartons. In view of general community environmental and health concerns with the chlorine bleaching process, can the Minister indicate whether these reports are well-founded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some reports alleging that some paper packaging products containing dioxin may in fact pose a risk. Generally the problem is that, even though dioxin is insoluble in water, in fat products such as milk it can leach and accordingly there is potential for a problem. However, I think it should be said that the amounts that are used in packaging are extremely small. They are slightly higher than the levels of dioxin found elsewhere in the environment and, as a consequence, the National Health and Medical Research Council has advised that, although it is currently examining the issue in general, there is no significant health hazard in the particular instances that have been reported. That report is also confirmed by studies in the United States of America (USA) and New Zealand, where the authorities also indicated that the extremely low levels of dioxin in packaging in similar circumstances also present no hazard.

ANSWER.PARA: The concern that Senator Devereux raises is one that has been reflected generally throughout the community, not only in respect of packaging but also in respect of the general question of the use of dioxin in paper products. Consumers are concerned that the use of such a chemical is purely for aesthetic value and to enhance appearance. The concern extends also to the fact that, as we all know, the impact on the environment of such items as waste by-products in the manufacturing process is also of concern. Indeed, the concern extends overseas, to the extent that there have been consumer boycotts in the United Kingdom, Sweden and the United States of America. The Governments of Sweden and the USA have moved to eliminate the process from pulp mills. This concern is felt also by industry, to the extent that, for instance, Tetra Pak (Aust.) Pty Ltd in Australia has now embarked upon a contract for the use of paperboard from Scandinavia-board that is not subject to chlorine bleaching. The company is doing that not particularly for health reasons but because of environmental concerns.

Getting back to the question of bleaching, I think it is fair to say, on the advice of the National Health and Medical Research Council, that there is no significant health hazard, but that Council will keep this issue under active consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. Yesterday the Australian Associated Press (AAP) issued a release headed:

SPEECH.PARA: Stone predicts sharp rise in Australian foreign debt levels.
I hasten to add that there is nothing incorrect in that. The article said:
Opposition Finance spokesman John Stone today warned Australia's foreign debt escalated sharply in the March quarter due to the falling exchange rate and the disastrous run of bad trade figures.
Again, that is a perfectly accurate depiction of what I said in a speech at the Gold Coast yesterday morning. But the report goes on to say-and this is what I want to correct:
He predicted official March quarter figures due out Wednesday-
that is, tomorrow-
would show gross foreign debt had risen to around $140 billion from $121.17 billion at the end of 1988, while net foreign debt would probably top the $100 billion mark . . .
The reference to net foreign debt is accurate, but I want to correct the reference to gross foreign debt. I quote now from the text of my speech yesterday morning at the Gold Coast:
As to gross debt, if you take account of the fall in the Australian dollar between December and the present time-
those are the key words, `the present time'-
the figure for gross foreign debt probably stands today-
that is, also a key word, `today'-
closer to $140 billion.

It is obvious that, as of the end of March, gross debt would not have reached $140 billion. The point I was making was that there had been a very big fall in the Australian dollar in addition to that which occurred in the March quarter, and that would have brought the figure, as at the time I was speaking, closer to $140 billion. I am not blaming the AAP reporter. In the haste of preparation of such things, it was a perfectly natural mistake, but it should be corrected.
Personal Explanation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Gareth Evans asked a question of me--
—Order! What are you proposing to do now?
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation based on a question that Senator Evans put to me, in which he misrepresented my position.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, in his usual offhand way--
—Order! A personal explanation has to be confined to the misrepresentation and the correction.
—I am in the process of moving to that, Mr Deputy President.
—There must be no reflection on the motives of the person making the allegation.
—It was suggested by Senator Evans that I personally was in favour of the privatisation of Telecom.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. In the interests of dealing with this matter in an orderly way, may I suggest that, rather than Senator Alston seeking leave to make a personal explanation, the honourable senator seek leave to make a statement in a couple of minutes setting out the answer to the question that was put to him by the Minister. I understood that that had been agreed by the Manager of Government Business. It would be more accurate than a personal explanation.
—A personal explanation is more confining than a statement. Is leave granted for Senator Alston to make a statement?

—To the extent that Senator Evans suggested that it was my personal agenda or, indeed, the coalition's agenda to privatise Telecom, I want to make it clear that that is simply not the case. I wish to read from Liberal Party policy on the matter:

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom will remain responsible for the basic telecommunications network.
What needs to be understood, and what clearly cannot be grasped by honourable senators opposite, is that we are in favour of a much greater degree--

TALK.START.PARA: —A personal explanation?
—The Minister asked that I make a statement, and I am making it.
—A personal explanation.
—No, that is not what the Minister suggested.
—Order! Senator Alston has leave to make a statement.

—What we are in favour of is a much greater degree of competition, which would ensure that Telecom's first mover advantage is not used to the detriment of other players in the game. We are in favour of competition, but not the very conservative and highly regulated telecommunications environment which will result once the latest package of telecommunications Bills has gone through this chamber. Our position is that privatisation is not necessary in the present climate. What is urgently needed is a whole range of competitive pressures to be brought to bear on Telecom. If we had those sorts of things, then we certainly would not have seen it spending $300m on a Taj Mahal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report is important for what it does not say, not for what it does say. Initially, I would like to commend the very hard working staff of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) throughout Australia, which in the past year or so has laboured under extreme conditions of hardship and scrutiny and has got on with the work of fulfilling many great projects and targets for Aboriginal people. But the political agenda is far different, and that is the issue that I would want to be critical of. For example, this report that has been tabled is the first report in six financial years that does not have a chairman's introductory comments or remarks. The fact that tomorrow sees the resignation of the Chairman of the ADC, Mrs Shirley McPherson, should be put into its proper context. Maybe there is a straight parallel to that. Obviously, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has in some way edited this report.

If one looks at the introductory comments to the report, there is a statement by the Minister, naturally. As I have said, there is no statement by the Chairman. There is a list of the routine functions of the Commission, and then a list of the commissioners. Who are the commissioners with their names and photographs listed? Other than Mrs McPherson, who has been there since 1984 and Chairman since 1986, and Commissioner Zona Martin, who was appointed in 1986, the other commissioners listed are those commissioners who were handpicked by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, on 13 May 1988, six weeks before the financial year, the subject of this report, ended. Nowhere else in this report is there any commendation of the work of the former commissioners. What an insult to the great work of these previous commissioners who have gone unnoticed and who have obviously been pulled out in this respect. It is also interesting to note that missing from the list of commissioners as at 30 June 1988 is Mr Charles Perkins, the Secretary to the Department, who was sacked by the Minister in November 1988 but who was in fact a commissioner as at June 1988. His credits do not even appear in the report. To give Charles Perkins his due, there were many issues on which he was a leader in many of these particular areas.

As I have said, this report is notable for what it does not say. There is no mention made of the fact that the former commissioners, who were there for some 11 months of the financial year, had called into question the Minister's proposals to establish a new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). There is no mention anywhere in the entire overview of the considerable work done by the former board and commission and the contribution it was seeking to make on behalf of many other Aboriginal people throughout Australia. There is no mention of the very significant impact that ATSIC is to have on the operations of the Aboriginal Development Commission if it is ever to be instituted. There is no comment at the front of the report with regard to the qualifications that exist in the book sections of the report by the Australian Audit Office of the ADC itself or of the various subsidiary companies, including Baruwei Enterprises Pty Ltd, a company which has subsequently gone into liquidation. There is no mention in the early part of the report of the serious political problems for the Government. Once again, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, has chosen to fiddle around, to muck about, and to withhold important information from this Parliament. As I said in my opening remarks, much good work has been done by the staff and the commissioners of the ADC-that is listed in the back part of the report, which relates to the projects-but the political agenda has been falsely and deceitfully misrepresented by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The consideration of the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission gives honourable senators a chance to reflect upon the work of the ADC over a number of years. I remind honourable senators that this organisation was established while Senator Chaney was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs; that the second reading speech on the Bill establishing the Commission was given by the only Aboriginal senator ever to serve in this place, Neville Bonner; that it has been an entirely Aboriginal organisation in terms of its directors; and that it has done the job which was given to it. I also point out that it is the intention of this Government, having weakened and emasculated the Aboriginal Development Commission, now to abolish it for no reason other than to centralise administration and organisation within the portfolio area. My colleague Senator Tambling spoke about the report. It is necessary that I too say something about the work of Shirley McPherson, who has been the chairperson of the Commission for some years. She was appointed in 1982 by, I believe, the then Minister, Mr Wilson. She became chairperson in 1984 and she has remained in that position ever since. She has presided over an ADC which has tightened its procedures and which has taken control of its destiny. It is an organisation which has moved more of its work from grants to loans and so generated continuing income by way of loan repayments. Those repayments themselves have provided more capital to help Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: Shirley McPherson is an accountant from Western Australia who has had a distinguished career in Aboriginal affairs, and her contribution to the ADC, especially as its chairperson, has probably been one of her most distinguished achievements in her life. It is a matter of great distress--

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Labor Party has made no recognition of it at all.

—My colleague makes the point that the Government has never recognised her work. Shirley McPherson has resigned. She leaves her post this week, on 1 June, and if it were not for Opposition senators rising now to say something about her work, nothing would be said.
—That is not true.

—If Senator Collins wishes to add his remarks I would be delighted because he has a special knowledge of Aboriginal affairs. But up till now nothing has been said by Government senators about her work, her achievements or her contribution. The only reason that she is still chairperson of the ADC is that she was secure from being sacked last year by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) when he purged eight commissioners in order to stack the numbers for his other purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only do I want to say something about Mrs McPherson, who will be leaving, to the detriment of Aboriginal affairs generally-with her there things were better and with her not there things will not be as good-but also I wish to take the chance to reflect upon the eight other commissioners who were sacked so cruelly by the Minister, Mr Hand. Their work has never been acknowledged. They were cruelly traduced by an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald soon after their dismissal. That story is patently untrue and has never been repudiated by the Minister, although it has been in his power to do so at any time. They had their reputations tarnished in their own communities. No-one has done anything to show care about these particular people. I refer honourable senators to the minority report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. We in the minority took some time and trouble to add to the majority view and said a little more about the cruel way in which those eight commissioners were treated.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been left out of the report.

—It is a tragedy if they have been left out of this report. I would also like to say something about the staff of the Aboriginal Development Commission, particularly about the former General Manager, Mr Mick O'Brien, as he too has been a victim of the events of the last year. He has given distinguished service to the Aboriginal Development Commission. He deserves to have his work recognised. I do not want to say too much because there are still matters before the Standing Committee of Privileges of the Senate and I do not wish to impinge in any way upon the deliberations of that body. I return to the point that the Parliament and the nation will be the poorer this week when Shirley McPherson relinquishes her post at the Aboriginal Development Commission. She has done a real job for Australia and I believe she deserves the gratitude of all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to debate the full scope of the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). I suppose no subject has occupied more of the Senate's time over this last year or two than the subject matter of Aboriginal affairs-the role of the Aboriginal Development Commission, the role of the various Ministers we have had, and so on. There have been many occasions when honourable senators from this side of the House in particular have expressed their deep concern about the way Aboriginal affairs have been administered by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: All I wish to do this afternoon is to pick up a matter which has been touched on by the two Opposition senators who have already spoken, Senator Tambling and Senator Peter Baume. It is a fact that the report coming down this week is significant in that it coincides, as I understand it, with the end of the period of service of Mrs Shirley McPherson. Mrs McPherson is a Western Australian Aboriginal person whom I did not know before she was appointed to her position with the Commission. She is not a person who came out of the professional Aboriginal affairs stream. She is a woman who qualified in her profession as an accountant. She spent her life as a married woman, a practising accountant and a business proprietor. She brought to the Aboriginal Development Commission, to which she was appointed, a wealth of practical experience and knowledge which I think was most impressive. She has worked long and hard in her post as an ADC commissioner and as Chairman of the ADC. It is a matter of very great regret that her long and faithful and, I believe, very effective service has been in a sense put at naught by the actions of the present Government and its maladministration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

The shameful treatment of Mrs McPherson's fellow commissioners is evidenced by the fact that they were sacked by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) on the basis of their opposition to his stupid approach to Aboriginal affairs. This is something quite without precedent. Despite all the Aboriginal people who have been, if you like, difficult for succeeding governments and succeeding Ministers, it is unprecedented in my experience for a group of people to be treated in the shabby way that those commissioners were treated in being dismissed and, in their terms, put in a situation of very great disadvantage among the Aboriginal community. Many people assumed that they were sacked for cause, when in fact they were sacked out of pique by a Minister who simply could not tolerate Aboriginal people opposing his plans.

The fact that Mrs McPherson was preserved relates to the strength of the statute which gave her statutory protection that was not available to her colleagues. I am pleased that when we put that legislation together we at least guaranteed that there was some protection for people against vindictive political acts. Mrs McPherson must have gone through a most difficult period. For her to have faced these sorts of thankless responses of the present Government, the hostility, the obstruction and the absolute small-mindedness and pettiness which have been a feature of Aboriginal affairs over recent years must have been almost beyond her tolerance.

I would like publicly to express my thanks to her, and I am sure I do so on behalf of all Opposition senators, although a number of Opposition senators have already put their personal views on record. I express my personal thanks for her strength of character, her courage and her dedication, and for the contribution she has made over a long period to all the Aboriginal people of Australia. That, in turn, in my view, translates to a contribution to all of us. I simply wish to record my respect for her. I trust that she will not find her memories of the last few years totally soured by the futility of the last couple.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not normally rise on the presentation of a paper such as this. However, as I came into the chamber-this was confirmed in a private conversation with Senator Tambling-he effectively accused the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) of editing the Aboriginal Development Commission report in so far as certain omissions of material which Senator Tambling thought ought to be in the report were found by him in a reading of it. The Minister absolutely refutes any suggestion that he has had any influence on the compiling of this report. Specifically, he has had nothing to do with omitting any material that might otherwise appear. He has not had any part to play in any supposed editing of the report. I would imagine-I have not had a chance to check this-that that would be illegal. It is a charge possibly of illegality but certainly of improper interference by the Minister in the preparation of this report. I would ask Senator Tambling to reconsider that accusation. Although I realise I am later than a contemporaneous challenge to him, I ask him to withdraw those charges.
—I call Senator Short.
—Can't you find it in your heart to thank Mrs McPherson on behalf of the Government?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I have made a particular request of Senator Tambling. I ask that that be dealt with first. I do not need to be instructed by Senator Puplick on the courtesies.
—I am just curious that you are not prepared to do so.
—Order! I call Senator Short.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I have asked for a withdrawal from Senator Tambling.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Tate at no stage has made clear to you that he is seeking to invoke a standing order of the Senate. If that is what he is seeking he should rephrase his request so that you know he is trying to take advantage of a particular standing order. He has not made that clear yet and there is no way you could have ruled otherwise than the way you have.
—I thank Senator Baume for his assistance. I was about to ask Senator Tate whether he was asking for that.

—I made the point that I did not come in contemporaneously with the assertions made by Senator Tambling. I have since privately confirmed his assertion. Even though it is a little later than the normal time for taking a point of order, I would now do so and ask Senator Tambling to withdraw his assertions concerning the Minister.
—Senator Tambling?
—No.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Are you ruling on the Minister's request that Senator Tambling has to make a withdrawal?
—At this stage I am suggesting to Senator Tambling that he may want to do something of his own volition. He says he does not want to. Does the Minister want me to make a ruling?
—Yes.
—The point of order should have been taken at the time the comment was made. There is no point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) annual report, which is very overdue. It has been tabled in the Senate today and relates to the year ending 30 June last year. That is indicative of some of the very considerable problems that have existed within the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country over recent times, problems that have been caused through the deliberate and wanton actions of the Hawke Government, in particular, of the last two Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs-Mr Hand and his predecessor, Mr Holding.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I wish to add my words to those of others from this side of the chamber in relation to Mrs Shirley McPherson, the outgoing Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission Board. I spoke of her last week in the debate on the Appropriation Bills. My remarks are recorded on page 2832 of Hansard of last Friday, 26 May. I will not go over them again, other than to say that I believe Mrs McPherson has made a fantastic contribution to Aboriginal affairs administration and policy in this country over a period. I am very sad to see her go. We are all going to be the poorer for her going, particularly her constituents, the Aboriginal people.

The other couple of things I wanted to mention relate to the point Senator Tambling made in the sense of no recognition having been given in this 1987-88 annual report to the commissioners of the Board other than Mrs McPherson and Commissioner Zona Martin, who were there prior to the start of 1987-88. All the other commissioners were appointed on 13 May 1988, six weeks prior to the end of the period to which this report relates. I find it quite extraordinary that an official body such as the ADC could report to the Parliament without mentioning the names or the contributions of the Board of Commissioners who directed the affairs of the Commission for all but six weeks of the reporting period. It is all the more extraordinary that no recognition is made of the work of those commissioners when one reads the General Manager's overview. I point out that it is an overview by Mr Mick O'Brien, who has not been General Manager for some considerable time now, but that is not acknowledged in this report either. In his very comprehensive, though brief, overview at the start of the report, amongst other things he says:
The Commission's achievements-
it was a year of considerable achievement in 1987-88, despite extraordinarily difficult circumstances occasioned by the actions of the Minister, Gerry Hand-
could not have been realised without the clear directions and guidance set by a very committed Board of Commissioners . . .
Later in his overview he said:
Communication with Aboriginal people has been very successfully maintained through the efforts of the full-time Chairman-
Mrs Shirley McPherson-
part-time Commissioners, and Regional and Branch staff . . .

There is a glowing tribute from the General Manager, who in turn was persecuted by this Minister and this Government. It is a very glowing tribute to the work of the commissioners of the Board, who were sacked by the Minister for having the temerity to question the direction of Aboriginal policy and organisational administration in this country, a concern which they quite rightly expressed and which was entirely within their field of responsibility. Indeed, they would have been irresponsible had they not done so.

As a member of Senate Estimates Committee E, I have been appalled by the overwhelming evidence of the widespread lack of professionalism and accountability in many sections of Aboriginal affairs administration. Waste and inefficiency have become a feature of the Hawke Government's period in office, particularly under Clyde Holding and Gerry Hand. The victims of this maladministration and inefficiency have been those Aborigines most in need. It is time this Government stepped back and took a long hard look at where it is going in the area of Aboriginal affairs policy and administration. It is leading us down a very disastrous path at the moment, at great cost to the most needy in our community, namely, the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks on the Aboriginal Development Commission report because it gives me an opportunity to recognise the contribution that the previous Chairman of the ADC, Shirley McPherson, made not only to the ADC but also to the Aboriginal community as a whole. Shirley McPherson came from private enterprise. She was a successful person in her own right who had obtained accounting and auditing degrees. She could have been held up as a role model for all Aboriginals to follow. Unfortunately, she was hounded-I use the word advisedly-out of the position of Chairman of the ADC. She stuck in there as long as she possibly could. She fought hard against what she saw as something that would be detrimental to the Aboriginal community. I refer to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, which is not coming up before the Senate--
—Yes, it is.

—It may be, and we will debate it when it does come up. Shirley McPherson realised that that Bill would hurt the Aboriginal people and divide them, so she fought against it, and she paid the penalty for standing up for the Aboriginal people. Despite her having the right to do so, the right to offer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) advice and the right to offer an alternative solution, she was, for her sins, for doing that and for doing what was required of her under the Act, hounded from office as the chairperson of the Aboriginal Development Commission by the Minister and his staff.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very sad loss to the Aboriginal community that she will not be involved in uplifting that community. I wish her all the best and hope that she will find some contentment, certainly more than she enjoyed in the last 12 months in the ADC. It would have been an appropriate time for the Minister to recognise the contribution made by Mrs McPherson and the other Aboriginal commissioners, who were sent back to their communities in disgrace. They went back under a cloud after the Minister had sacked them with only six weeks of their term to run. Any compassionate Minister would have waited out the six weeks and set up a new ADC Board, but the present Minister could not wait six weeks. Because these people would not agree with his proposals on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, he sent them back into the bush under a cloud and in disgrace. They did not really know why they were sacked and disgraced.

The most reprehensible thing was when the story was given to the Sydney Morning Herald that $670,000 was missing from ADC funds. No member of the Senate, be he National, Labor or Democrat, would support that action. It was disgraceful, and I would have thought that the Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither do the Liberals.

—I am sorry; I meant to include the Liberals. It was absolutely disgraceful that it happened. The Minister should have taken the opportunity of holding out his hand in friendship and apologising for the publication of the story that leaked out of his office or an office for which he was responsible. He should have taken the opportunity to apologise in the ADC report, but he has failed to do so once again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some things I want to say about the Aboriginal Development Commission report which I may not have time to say today but which are important. They concern the positive achievements taking place in Aboriginal affairs, which always seem to be ignored by the Opposition. The Opposition spends so much time dropping buckets on people and making outrageous allegations about people that it forgets the tremendous damage it does in the wider community to the susceptible Aboriginal affairs. Some of my colleagues go so far as to say that it is absolutely deliberate, that the Liberal Party sets out to achieve that objective. I hope that is not true.

SPEECH.PARA: I forgive Senator Short and Senator Boswell their outrageous remarks on the grounds of ignorance, but Senator Tambling and Senator Chaney should know better. I did not hear much of what Senator Tambling said today so I will not do him the discourtesy of commenting on things that I did not hear. I will leave that to others who did hear and wish to respond. Senator Chaney outrageously tried to rewrite the history. He was once the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, when, I might say, the percentage of Aboriginal expenditure on administration rather than on services was much higher than it is now, and he should have known. What he said today about the dismissal of the commissioners was outrageously inaccurate and was either wilfully inaccurate or grossly ignorant. Rewriting history is not--

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of rhetoric. How about giving us your version?

—My version is clearly written. I know that Senator Alston has not read it, but it is on the record and I stand by it today. However, as I have only five minutes in which to speak, I do not intend to be diverted on to that matter. I do not wish to reflect on the individual commissioners who were dismissed. For the information of the ignorant, I point out that my position on that is set out in the majority report. They were honest people who were given bad advice. They acted in what they thought were the best interests, but they were wrong. That committee--

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief in concluding my remarks in the second reading debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and the Migration Amendment Bill 1989, which are very important Bills. Several matters are worthy of further consideration. One which has been brought to my attention since I spoke yesterday evening relates to a particularly grubby and shoddy press release by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, when it was first indicated that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats had serious reservations about the form and content of the original legislation and sought to discuss the matter with the Government. Instead of adopting the statesmanlike position that has been adopted in recent days, when the Minister has been prepared to negotiate what we think is ultimately a sensible conclusion, the Minister simply resorted to cheap criticism and abuse and said, for instance:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition and the Democrats have placed political expediency ahead of logic and principle in their decision to oppose the . . . Bill.

He accused us of having rejected the chance to bring greater logic and justice to the administration of the immigration program. He claimed that we had either not understood the issues involved or had become the unwitting puppets of a small group of vested legal interests, or a combination of the two. He decided to defame the legal profession for good measure when he said of the Bill:
A campaign against it had been orchestrated by a small group of people from the legal fraternity, who had a vested interest.
Finally, after accusing us of opportunism, he said:
Any discussion though-
that was an invitation to the parties to consider the form of the Bill-
will be based on the clear understanding that the Bill's fundamental principles will remain intact.

Ultimately, what happened was that the Government saw the merit of the arguments that it simply was not good enough for the Minister to wash his hands of a number of the hard cases that inevitably present themselves for decision. He was not prepared to acknowledge that it is not a matter for bureaucrats to be forced to make those sorts of judgments; it is a matter for a Minister exercising political power to withstand the vested interests, to not cave in to any unfair or unwarranted interference, but to make the right and sometimes courageous decisions. I would have thought that this Minister would have had the political capacity and the intestinal fortitude to have withstood those sorts of pressures, but the sort of language he used was that the situation as it currently stands is open to political interference and to petty favouritism of the worst kind. He has now entirely accepted our argument that it is not appropriate to devolve discretion or responsibility to the bureaucracy; indeed, that it is proper that the Minister retain discretion. He says that, presumably, against the background that the discussions that would take place would not compromise the legislation's fundamental principles. If this is not a fundamental principle, it is hard to understand why he had to resort to that sort of violent language in the first instance.

The joint select committee that will be established, as I understand it, has one additional element-that is, to include a Democrat member. It is our expectation that the provisions of the Bill will be reviewed by that committee after a period of two years. We would certainly not object if there were to be an independent review which would then report to parliament on the operation of the Bill or, indeed, if there were an assessment of it by the Administrative Review Council.

I understand there is also a provision in relation to the limits that will apply under the floating pass mark arrangement that would apply a cap to the concessional family quota, but would leave uncapped the priority area. I would not like there to be any misunderstanding of our understanding of the position. I think it is an important matter of principle. We were determined-I think the Government has accepted the validity of the argument-that there should not be a compromise or an arbitrary limit imposed on the entry of those in the priority category and, if necessary, restraint would have to be imposed in the concessional category in order to enable the numbers to continue to come in under the priority area. We welcome the proposed restructuring of interline arrangements to prevent abuse of embarkation cards and to halt what has apparently happened in the past-when people have swapped cards and used boarding passes which were not their own. We also welcome the easier arrangements which will now apply for the prosecution of those engaged in illegal fishing activities.

I conclude by saying that the Opposition regards the final outcome as satisfactory. We take great pride in and credit for the fact that, despite all its bluster and bravado, the Government was prepared to stand the matter down, to give some serious consideration to the arguments advanced by the Opposition and, ultimately, to accept all of those recommendations which we regarded as fundamental. I think the outcome is a great tribute to the persistence and determination of those on this side of the chamber who saw the need to ensure that when we have a new and updated Migration Act, it will be one that is very much in the interests of all those parties to migration proceedings. It is a very difficult area of human relations and one that must be handled very sensitively. We think there has been a vast improvement in the approach that the Government originally had in mind. The nation will be stronger as a result of the amendments.

We look forward to an indication from the Minister during this debate that undertakings will be given to fund some specialised support agencies. On the basis that the Minister will outline the amendments which have been provided to me, I do not see the need to go into any greater detail at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating two migration Bills-the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and the Migration Amendment Bill 1989. These are two vastly different Bills. The first Bill, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill, contains an enormous number of amendments and comprises 93 pages, whereas the second Bill comprises only two half-pages, in order to correct an amendment Bill which we passed last year which cannot be proclaimed until this Bill is passed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston has given us some of the history of these Bills. Indeed, I shall elaborate on that. It has been apparent to us all for a very long time that the Migration Act 1958, which is the principal Act which we are amending, is very unsatisfactory and is in need of a complete rewrite. The FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, which produced the report known as the FitzGerald report, criticised the Migration Act in very forthright terms, characterising it as outmoded, non-specific and lacking in direction. FitzGerald pointed out that the 1958 Act preserves the mood and flavour of the 1901 Immigration Restriction Act. The mood and flavour of that earlier Act reflected the value systems of Australia's dominant class of 1901. That value system included a belief in the absolute superiority of white people over Aboriginal people, Asians and other non-Europeans. Provisions of the 1901 Act were most concerned with how to keep people out of Australia and, if they had managed to get in uninvited, how to get rid of them.

FitzGerald described the 1958 Act as more neutral, but pointed out that it pre-dates the final demise of the white Australia policy by 15 years. FitzGerald produced one volume dealing with model legislation. In the introduction to that volume he stated:

One of the Committee's terms of reference was to address the relationship between immigration policies and legislative processes. The Committee decided that a fundamental aspect of immigration reform was the updating of the Migration Act 1958 to provide a more positive foundation to immigration policy and administration.
Part of the FitzGerald report reads:
The mood and flavour of the 1901 Act prevail today.
The influence of the Migration Act on immigration policy makers, administrators and the wider Australian community is immeasurable. Its tone permeates each layer.

Since the present Migration Act was drafted, in the Fifties, there have been considerable changes in Australia's approach to immigration, and in administrative law. Amendments to the legislation have provided band-aid solutions to pressing problems, and have compounded confusion in the interpretation and administration of the Act.

If we turn to the final pages of the 1958 Act we can see how many times it has been amended. Many amendments have not even been included in the Act. The FitzGerald Committee recommended that a draft Bill drawing on the Committee's model be introduced into Parliament as soon as possible to replace the existing Migration Act. That recommendation should have been followed but it has not been followed. What we are left with is yet another set of amendments which are extremely hard to follow. It is very complex to amend amendments that have been amended a great number of times. I hope that during the committee stage, when we look at the approximately 130 amendments from both the Government and ourselves, we can address those amendments properly.

When we discuss immigration programs we must realise that we are talking about people. We are not talking about economic units; we are not talking about numbers that come in each year; we are talking about human beings. We must think: What makes the best Australian? Of course, it would be the person who has a commitment to stay and who wants to make his or her life here. As well as encouraging family reunion on a humanitarian basis, it often makes very good sense to encourage it on a commonsense basis. If a whole family is here, it is a stable family; therefore, we can work towards a stable society. We also need to ask ourselves why so many people leave Australia each year, which is wasteful in terms of the funds spent on our immigration program. We need to look at the sorts of people who leave and the reasons for their leaving. I suggest that that aspect should be considered very carefully.

Having listened to Senator Alston speak last night, I make it plain that the Australian Democrats' view on immigration is very different, obviously, from the coalition's view. We believe that humanitarian and compassionate grounds for immigration should be the whole basis of our policy. As I said before, that is a way of bringing stability to Australian society. Of course, we have a moral requirement to fulfil our obligations under refugee convocations and conventions to which we are a signatory.

We must not forget that those who come to Australia on a family reunion or refugee basis bring skills with them and they can contribute very well to Australian society. In fact, we have been importing skills since the late 1940s. If we still need to import people deliberately on a skills needs basis, it has taken us a long time not to get it right. There is a problem with the skills category of migration. People coming in on a skills basis believe they will get a job which will fit in with their skills but that does not necessarily happen. People who have visited my office were assured that they would obtain work in Australia but they have been out of work for a year, even two years in one case. Another aspect that must be addressed is whether we should deliberately solicit migrants on a skills basis when we have such a high level of unemployment. Indeed, we must ask whether, at present, they would be able to pay for their homes. It is time for the Government to look beyond the short term economic issues concerning immigration.

An unfortunate lesson that we have learnt from our immigration policies is that in Australia we continue to cluster around our coastline. A combination of land degradation and other factors has seen our population decline in rural areas of central Australia. These very complex matters and problems should be addressed openly and honestly.

As Senator Alston said, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 was introduced some weeks ago. It came under immediate criticism from a whole section of our community. I will mention the names of some of the groups who were very opposed to the legislation: the Association of Non-English Speaking Background Women of Australia, the Australian Council of Churches, the Australian Council of Social Service, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, the Immigration Rights and Advice Centre, the Indo-China Refugee Association, the Public Interest Advocacy Centre, the Refugee Council of Australia and the Law Council of Australia. In addition, there were various groups of lawyers, particularly those working in legal aid areas, individual ethnic groups, individuals and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

The Government has come forward with some 82 amendments. In response to that, and matters that we believe have not been addressed, the Democrats have come forward with 43 amendments to the Bill and two amendments to the Government's amendments. I commend the Government-despite Senator Ray's words in his press release-for coming forward with amendments. As I said before, not all of the issues have been addressed. Some have and it is to be hoped that at the committee stage we can work through the legislation and come forward, finally, with a Bill of which we can be proud.

Clearly, we are presented with an opportunity here to bring forward better migration legislation than we have had for some time. The Act which we need now should be clear and unambiguous. It should set out in plain language who is eligible to apply for entry to Australia for permanent residence and what selection criteria should operate. It should recognise the reality that many more people wish to live in Australia permanently than we can accommodate and that applications exceed acceptances by a factor of more than 10:1. Setting out very clear selection criteria and providing for wide dissemination of those criteria to intending applicants would create a situation in which a large number would exclude themselves from the application process and, thus, reduce the enormous log jam of applications waiting to be processed. That is one of the problems that we have with our selection system. On many occasions, when people front up to an Australian embassy or the point of contact overseas, they are not given the right sort of advice. If they are accepted and come to Australia, they do not have the full facts of the situation in which they find themselves. I hope that we have improved from the days when we brought all those unfortunate migrants to Wittenoom in Western Australia. They were used as economic units and sent to work in the most appalling conditions. Currently a number are dying from mesothelioma and asbestosis.

FitzGerald went so far as to draft what was represented as a model for a new Migration Act. It is disappointing that the Government's Bill perpetuates some of the faults of the old Migration Act, especially in its original form, and adds a few more problems to it. An important element of the present Bill is that it confers considerable responsibilities and powers on non-elected bureaucrats. To a certain extent that has been changed by some of the Government's amendments, but my first reaction on reading the legislation was that it was legislation created by bureaucrats for bureaucrats. It was a bureaucrats' dream. Everything was laid out by line and number. Decisions could have been made behind closed doors without any reason being given for those decisions. That has changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition required major changes and the Government has agreed.

—The legislation has changed to some degree, as I have said, but not completely. That is why the Democrats have drawn up a further 43 amendments. A classic example is the wording in proposed section 61 (1):

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations may provide for prescribed decisions of the Secretary to be reviewed by prescribed review officers on application, as prescribed, by prescribed persons.

I am happy to say that the Government has removed that proposed section and substituted another. If we were to pass legislation expressed in such terms, we would essentially be handing the powers of the Parliament over to the Executive and the bureaucracy. One might be able to advance arguments to support some delegation of responsibility if one were dealing with a department with a high reputation for efficiency and concern for the protection of the rights of its clients. However, as the FitzGerald report comments, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is a department which has an image problem. I quote from the report:

The image of bureaucracy. A labyrinth of rules and requirements that confuse and bewilder. A creator of uncertainty, dependence, frustration and anger. A mass of ill-fitting, unintegrated parts that resent change, that react rather than anticipate, that sink inexorably into inertia.

Right or wrong, this is largely how government administration is viewed by its clients and the broader community. The immigration administration is not immune from this perception. It is accused of being conservative, slow, insensitive, secretive, inefficient, and unfair in its application of policy.
Bearing those remarks in mind, we should indeed be thankful that we have a number of amendments addressing the original legislation.

One of the most significant areas in the legislation is the issue of independent review of migration decisions. This was one particular section that gave rise to concern to many people. It has been a highly unsatisfactory aspect of the administration of immigration policy for many years. Several reports and inquiries, which I have spoken about previously, have strongly pressed the need for a genuinely independent system of reviews in which justice would not only be done but would also be seen to be done. In recent months we have experienced the long running charade of the $240 fee charged illegally by this Government for the review of migration decisions. Eventually we had the tabling of documents under the freedom of information legislation. Nevertheless, the fee had been collected since September 1987 even though, as from November 1987, it was deemed to be not completely legal. It will be refunded to people who paid after December of last year. But we are left with a situation in which there is no review of migration decisions. People are invited to make second applications, which of course is not the same thing at all.

The Australian Democrats' objection to the $240 fee, when the legislation came before the Senate in December 1987, related to its being a charge for a satisfactory review process, which I described at the time as a Claytons review process. We did not believe, and we do not believe, that there should be a charge for an internal review of an administrative decision. That is what we could now find ourselves with, where the first level of review will be by an officer in the Department. That should be standard; all decisions should be reviewed, especially if a negative decision is made. We could have stomached a fee for a strong, just, independent and effective review process but the process provided by the immigration review panels-IRPs, as they are known-offered no guarantee of justice, independence and effectiveness. The decision was made on the papers, with the case presented to the IRP by the Department. There was no opportunity for the applicant to present his or her case in person. There was no right for the applicant to be present to observe the hearing of the case. There was no right to call or examine witnesses. There was no right to legal representation.

Although the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) indicated that the new review process would be genuinely independent, the legislation we are being asked to approve does not provide such a process. Frankly, I find this very hard to understand. Tribunals for the independent review of administrative decisions are an established aspect of our system of government. We have the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The FitzGerald Commission recommended that this tribunal be the appropriate one to review immigration decisions. It was specifically set up to provide a mainstream avenue for the review of administrative decisions to avoid proliferation of review mechanism, all operating at considerable expense in various jurisdictions.

In a letter which the Minister sent to all honourable senators he stated that the Government wanted to avoid an adversarial type of review process providing for gladiatorial contests between lawyers, which would not necessarily produce the most just outcome for either the applicant or the Australian community. The Democrats accept that the adversarial model is not necessarily the best one for the review of decisions in the migration area. But there are other operating models on which the Government could have relied in drafting the present legislation. One such tribunal deals with appeals in the veterans affairs area. Another is the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT). The latter is a non-adversarial tribunal, which gives the appellant clear rights. It functions informally; it is regarded as fair; it is speedy and efficient; and it protects the rights of individuals. Indeed, it is interesting that in part the proposed amendments are based on the SSAT model. Proposed section 64e on page 54 of the Bill, which sets out the objectives of the proposed migration appeals tribunal, is identical to section 176 of the Social Security Act.

It seems ridiculous that, having followed the SSAT model in establishing the objective of the migration tribunal, this legislation does not institute the same rights and procedures in respect of the handling of the appeals but rather institutes vastly inferior ones. Legal interpretation of the clauses of the legislation before us is that the appellant has no guarantee of the rights to an oral hearing, to be present at a hearing, to present argument, to call or to challenge witnesses or to representation.

The Migration Act 1958 has rightly been criticised because it confers an enormous range of discretion on the Minister. The fact that so little has been codified and so much left to discretion and interpretation has caused enormous difficulties and has led to significant inconsistency in decision-making. To a certain extent that has been corrected, but not totally. An avowed intention of the present Bill is to reduce the exercise of discretion and to provide rules which would lead to more or less automatic decisions in the vast majority of cases. The Democrats applaud the intention to provide more consistency and predictability in migration decision-making. But in the legislation the Government has gone overboard; in many crucial areas all discretion has been removed. This will inevitably result in some severe injustices. Immigration decisions deal with human beings. Unfortunately for the Government and for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, human beings do not fit neatly into boxes and categories. There will always be cases at the margin where flexibility will be needed because regulations cannot fit in with every decision to be made.

In fact, I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the decision which needs to be made about the Orionia people, who are currently in Albany in the south of Western Australia. Two of their community are shortly to rejoin them after they were extradited to Israel. These people cannot fit into any category because they did not choose to enter the country. They were here simply because their ship stopped in the port of Albany for provisions. For honourable senators who know the history, they were subsequently taken off their ship. Their boat is no longer in the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —`The' boat.
—We cannot legislate or regulate for all categories. It is simply not possible. Discretion is necessary for cases such as the one I have just quoted.

SPEECH.PARA: In other areas extraordinary levels of discretion are reserved to the Secretary and the Minister. The Secretary and the Minister may, for example, revoke a valid visa or a valid entry permit. Although those aspects have also been addressed to some extent, the Democrats have further amendments.

The question of the determination of refugee status is left to discretion. Cases will be investigated by departmental officers in secrecy. Recommendations will be made to the Minister, who will make the decision. The applicant has no right to be present nor to put a case. The decisions are basically unreviewable. That is not in accordance with the conventions to which we are a signatory.

The Bill also takes an extremely harsh position on illegal entrants. Estimates of illegals in Australia range from 50,000 to well over 100,000. Obviously, no one knows the true number. Some have been here for very many years. Some are married to Australians and have Australian children. We need to ask ourselves why there are so many illegals in Australia. How do they get in? Even departmental officers are not beyond advising people to break the rules. Only the other week my own office heard of a case in which a citizen was experiencing lengthy delays in an attempt to nominate for permanent residence a spouse who was currently overseas. On contacting the Department, the applicant was advised to bring the spouse in on a tourist visa and then have her apply for a change of status. Essentially, here was a departmental officer advising an applicant to breach the Department's own rules. I certainly do not condone cheating and I do not condone illegal immigration. But we are at best very foolish if for years we leave the front door open, expect that no one will take advantage of our casual attitude to security, and then suddenly, in legislation, give these people only 28 days to regularise their status or be subject to deportation from this country without warning and without a review of the situation. Another aspect of the Bill that worries the Australian Democrats a great deal is that of the fluctuating points system. We are also concerned about the clause which relates to the Christmas Island people who are currently in Australia.

I wish to make a few remarks about the Migration Amendment Bill, which is a small measure. If it passes without amendment it will empower the Minister to create classes of visas and entry permits. It will empower the Minister to determine arbitrarily which person's visa has single document entry privilege and which person's does not. It does not necessarily exclude the application of an `instrument in writing' to give authority for departmental charge for granting a visa `in a specified manner and form'-that is, establishing a tax for which no legislative warrant may exist. It generally provides the Minister with wide arbitrary powers which are inconsistent with the professed spirit of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill-the other Bill that we are now debating. That Bill aims to minimise arbitrary decision making and provide certainty where uncertainty previously existed. Presumably, the provisions of this Bill would enable the Department to bring in selected visitors who are not registered in a notified database, pending full implementation of the computer system. I have some amendments to bring forward to the Migration Amendment Bill, which I will address at the right moment.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats would have preferred to see new legislation as recommended by FitzGerald. Instead, we have further amendments to a Bill which has been amended many times since 1958. The draconian measures originally in the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill have now been softened somewhat by the amendments put forward by the Government and certainly we will support many of those amendments. We have our own amendments to put forward which will address areas the Government has not addressed in its amendments. The Democrats are looking also to improving the review system so that reviews are heard at different levels and fairly and justly so that the decisions made can be seen to be just.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 is very important legislation because it addresses a number of major deficiencies in immigration decision-making in this country. It also brings in a dozen other specific, more minor reforms. When the Opposition was first faced with the Bill in its original form on 2 May it decided that despite its many advantages the legislation was not acceptable because of three or four deficiencies which I will address in a few moments. After withdrawing the Bill from further consideration in the Senate the next day, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) very rationally and sensibly entered into informal and eventually formal negotiations with the Opposition so that the three or four major remedies that we wanted in the Bill were incorporated. We now have the Minister's tabled amendments-some 82 of them-as a consequence of those sensible negotiations. On the new basis this legislation is approved by the Opposition and, in a true bipartisan way, we will, through this measure, go a long way to restoring the basis for public confidence in immigration decisions in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I speak in such glowing terms about this outcome, let honourable senators not forget that we have seen six years of deterioration in immigration matters under this Labor Government. Immigration has become a disaster area and there has been a lamentable failure of public confidence in immigration decisions. The beginnings of the repair of this disaster were seen in the appointment of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies chaired by Dr Stephen FitzGerald. In earlier speeches I have commended the findings, conclusions and recommendations of the FitzGerald inquiry. The Government, which was so severely criticised by many aspects of the FitzGerald Committee findings, has not been so generous towards that important review of immigration and has accepted only some of its recommendations, some of which are involved in this legislation. Let the Senate not forget that, by failing to accept the further recommendations of that most important inquiry, the Government is leaving this country still in disarray on immigration, still with a want of public confidence that will be restored only by the election of the coalition to government. The most urgent question in immigration matters is the restoration of public confidence. At present any sampling of public opinion in any part of Australia would, I believe, result in most Australians saying that they do not want any immigration at all because they do not have confidence that this Government has a sufficiently firm decision-making process or good principles of fairness, stability and justice. More than that, Australians do not believe that this Government takes decisions based on the best interests of Australia-decisions that emphasise the acquisition of skills and the encouragement of young migrants, not only for their own good but also for the clear advantage of this country.

I wish to say how much I welcomed the statement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in his first press conference on 9 May, following his election as Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia. At that press conference he said most clearly and with total conviction that has made the situation abundantly clear to the whole nation that the Opposition stands firmly in favour of non-discriminatory immigration and that we will proceed with a bipartisan policy for the good of all Australians. Later that week a debate on a motion on immigration introduced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also gave Mr Peacock a clear opportunity, of which he took full advantage-and that was a debate he won-of confirming those commitments. The unfortunate immigration debate of August 1988 is behind us all in this chamber; it is behind the Parliament and it has been put behind the Opposition. Thankfully, those extraneous elements of debate have now been relegated to history. So in this chamber we can forthrightly concentrate on seeing this Bill enacted in a genuine bipartisan spirit, and we can then concentrate in subsequent debates on those further deficiencies which this Government has not yet addressed and which I fear, through its populist and Australian Labor Party dominated policy approach to immigration and ethnic affairs, it will not address, and hence the remedy can be found only in the election of this coalition to government.

Let me focus directly on the Bill. There are three broad features of this Bill which, as amended by this package of amendments negotiated with the Opposition, are to be commended to this chamber. The first feature is that all administrative decisions are now placed in a legislative framework. It should be understood that up until now immigration decisions in this country have proceeded on the basis that the Minister for this portfolio has decision-making discretions which are totally unfettered. Whatever the Minister decides, stands. The present migration law gives that power to the Minister. Whilst the Government chooses to publish statements of policy and the Minister chooses to give administrative orders to his Department, on the basis of which decisions are to be made, nevertheless any of those decisions can be appealed to the Minister, and the Minister can, without any affront to the views of this Parliament or without any affront to any regulation or law in this country, reverse the decision. There have been thousands of cases in all of these years referred to Ministers for immigration with a view that the Minister might review the administrative decisions. Even then, there have been appeals to courts.

We have found the deplorable situation of a lack of firmness in decision making; hence this Bill is put forward as a just and competent beginning of a remedy. What is required is a distinct legislative framework which sets out the basis for any application for immigration to this country being approved or not approved. Then the members of the Department, in drafting those decisions, will be required to act according to the law and the regulations under that law. The Minister's discretions are, to that extent, confined by this law. In the form in which this Bill was first drafted, the movement in this direction was excessive, in that there was not in all cases an ability for the Minister to show sensible flexibility or sensible compassion, or indeed, to have the right of review. These matters were limited to refugees and similar areas of decision. But now, because of the Opposition's insistence, the Minister is answerable for all of the decisions in the Department. It is not a question of a computer working upon the law as it was originally drafted, determining immigration decisions, nor is the Minister able to say that he is not responsible for the decisions that his Department has made, or able to put himself at some distance from those decisions. The legislative framework has now been achieved, yet the Minister is totally responsible and accountable to this Parliament.

The problem being addressed is not just the question of illegal immigrants, of which there are now estimated to be some 70,000 living in this country. That is a disgraceful situation and clearly the whole of this Parliament wants to see that number greatly reduced and, if possible, even eliminated. We do not want to see a backdoor advantage being gained by these queue jumpers over the 1.3 million persons who apply each year to come to live in this country. We need to have a fair and sound system for making these decisions.

Another problem area that is being addressed is the ordinary administration of immigration decisions. There is a need for consistency and a need to ensure that once a decision has been taken, it cannot be evaded, undercut or chased about either with many appeals through the process to the Minister or to the courts. Meanwhile, the whole process bleeds to death and the public does not have confidence that the Government is in fact governing. We believe that this is the major reform in this legislation, and we support it.

A second major feature of the Bill is that it gives a more definite review process, and the two-tier determinative review process is one which we support. A third major feature of the Bill is that it gives a framework for simplifying into two broad categories migrant applications: those who are concessional migrants, that is, family reunion applicants; and those who are independent migrants, that is, skilled migrants. I have already said in the past how this will come under considerable scrutiny when we actually have the regulations for these two categories before us. But it is a welcome feature of this legislation. The floating pass mark is a practical and fair method for determining the actual numbers of persons who in any period will be coming to Australia under either of the two categories. The right to stay will become the critical factor in determining deportation and compliance with the Migration Act. A 28-day period has been defined in the legislation whereby a person here illegally will not forever-as it would seem now-be able to evade a firm decision on the necessity to comply with the Government's decisions.

Other specific reforms that are to be commended in this legislation are the collection of costs from deportees and consumer protection for clients of immigration agents. Another feature regards the balance of family test. This matter has gained some further review as a result of discussions with the Opposition in the last few weeks. I support not only the flexibility here-despite the objectives that are set out by the Government in this area-but the flexibility generally to do what is sensible and compassionate, even if the main structure is as was originally set out in the Bill. There is also a tightening of the assurance of support which a sponsor gives towards an applicant coming as a sponsored immigrant to this country.

Another good reform is the ability through this legislation to allow the release of illegal migrants on bond rather than their having to be retained in State prisons after their detention. Another reform is the tightening of the change of status procedure, which is currently an area of great abuse in this country. There is also provision for the search and entry of premises without a magistrate's certificate for departmental officers who are following up immigration matters.

Let me say very briefly-I am imposing upon myself the discipline of speaking for only half the allotted time so that others may be able to take part in this debate-that the three documents that are before us represent very welcome contributions by the Minister alongside the legislation. I refer to a letter, which the Minister addressed to a number of honourable senators and maybe some honourable members of the House of Representatives on 28 April, dealing with certain gossiped criticisms of the Bill at that time. To the letter is attached a paper addressing the supposed criticisms and giving clear answers. This was a most welcome action by the Minister. It played a considerable role in setting the stage for the discussions of the last few weeks.

I have referred already to the 82 amendments that have been circulated by the Government as a result of discussions with the Opposition. I note the sunset clause of two years on the main regulations under the Act, which will enable the Government of the day to keep the initiative and avoid being chased about by a haphazard majority in one or other chamber. I refer also to the notice of motion given by the Minister today, setting out the description of a select committee to review the regulations before their introduction in the next session of parliament. Having examined that notice of motion, I believe it is in good faith that the discussions have taken place with the Opposition. I believe that it can be adopted and that the spirit of this debate can continue in the select committee. Indeed, afterwards there may well be a standing committee on immigration. It may have a longer life and may be charged with undertaking a continuing review not only of the regulations but also of policy.

On the question of ministerial discretion, it is very important that there should not be any inequity in that only some applicants are able to appeal to the Minister for a review of decisions. There is considerable inequity at the moment, as there has been for many years. There is unfairness if 10,000 people can have their applications reviewed by the Minister because they have access to him, even if through us as senators, whereas one million, or more, people do not have that opportunity. In this respect there should be fairness. I welcome the provision that will enable the Minister to distance himself more from the day-to-day review of cases. It will also allow him properly to govern policy and to see to the management of the Department and the immigration decision process, and not to be so bogged down with 1,000 new files a month that he loses sight of the overall role that we expect of the Government. Indeed, the more legally defined basis for these decisions will achieve greater consistency. It is against the background of these advantages that, nevertheless, the Opposition insists that the Minister, and not the Secretary to the Department, or some other part of the Department, be responsible for all immigration decisions. So, we have seen the amendments to which I have referred.

The Minister, in his notice of motion today, as well as in statements in April and December of last year, said that the regulations under this Act will not vary from current government policy. That is a matter for the select committee to review, but I note those undertakings by the Minister, and we shall examine them in the select committee. We shall also see that the regulations make it possible for the Minister to bring compassion and some flexible discretion to bear, for reasons that he can subsequently declare to Parliament.

My final point is that the new two-tier review process needs to be fair and sound. We think that it will be, but we note the Minister's agreement to our request that there be an evaluation within two years of the operation of the review process beginning, and that the results of that evaluation be reported to this Parliament so that the Government of the day may vary the process, after consultation with all interested parties in Australia, to ensure that it is no less effective than is envisaged in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and the Migration Amendment Bill 1989. I am glad that we are doing so because relatively recently it looked as though we would not. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), whom I am glad to see now in the chamber, was foolish initially to react so negatively when the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Democrats, plus a wide range of the ethnic communities, expressed opposition to important parts of the legislation on its introduction. I think it was uncharacteristic of the Minister to spit the dummy in the way that he did. I am glad that, subsequently, he has adopted a much more commonsense approach.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bills is to introduce new measures relating to the issue of visas and entry permits, to allow those rules to be contained in regulations, and to provide for a review of immigration decisions.
