The Bills reflect the Government's response to the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, which was produced in the course of 1987-88 and was tabled in Parliament on 3 June last year. That was an extremely important report, and probably the most wide-ranging examination of immigration in our history. Indeed, it was an excellent report, which provoked a great deal of community debate. By no means was everyone in full agreement with every aspect of it. Indeed, I disagreed strongly with parts of it-for example, the proposal to wind down the Indo-Chinese refugee program, which I feel is very important to us as a nation. However, overall, there was an enormous number of recommendations that indicated an excellent examination.

One of my criticisms of the legislation before the House is that I doubt whether, in its proposals for legislative change, it does full justice to the recommendations of the FitzGerald report. Nevertheless, it is important legislation, as the FitzGerald report was an important report. Regrettably, the tabling of that report last June was followed by a disgraceful and scurrilous campaign of divisiveness and misinformation by the Government as to the coalition's attitude to migration. For example, speaking at the Australian Institute of International Affairs on 14 November of last year, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), following the public debate on immigration of the preceding three months, said:

. . . one of the first effects of the immigration debate was a reduction in applications from potential business migrants . . . by possibly more than 30 per cent. Such damage to Business Migration Program could slash capital inflow from Asia into Australia from $1.1 billion to about $750m with the potential long term cost much higher . . .

Other Government Ministers had already jumped on this band wagon, notably Senator Gareth Evans and Mr Michael Duffy. Fortunately, the present Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, displayed a little more intelligence and honesty. In doing so, of course, he blew the claims of the Prime Minister and his acolytes right out of the water. On 2 February this year, in a statement to journalists in Hong Kong, Senator Ray admitted that there had been no effect on business migration created by the immigration debate in Australia. I quote him as reported:
Nothing major has shown up in the Government statistics . . . Even if there was some dropoff it's not essential to assume it's to do with some debate in Australia.
On 1 March this year the Minister said in the Senate:
It is quite clear that the business migration program this year is going to run 2,000 under target. Of those, 700 would have been business migrants, the rest their families.

The program does have difficulties, but I want to stress too in fairness that the Asian migration debate is only one of the factors operating in the business migration area. A second factor is competition from New Zealand and Canada, which have far less rigorous requirements, not only in monetary amounts but in character checks, et cetera. A third factor . . . was the fact that an appreciating dollar in Australia made it harder for people to meet the requirements.
Senator Ray continued:

I also went on to say in Hong Kong . . . that the gap between the first approach and development of business migration applications by business migration agents and their lodging in our office is quite often 10 to 12 months. So we still have not seen the evidence as to whether, in fact, we are going to go into a decline, let alone a failure to increase.

The Australian Labor Party, since mid-1988, has been trying desperately to poison the Liberal Party's traditional close relationship with the ethnic communities in Australia. In some instances, I must say, it nearly succeeded. Fortunately, however, most ethnic communities have seen through this quite dishonest, poisonous plot. My own personal experience is a clear indication of that. As I have gone about my duties as a senator-which, of my own volition, involve a very heavy emphasis on meeting with the leaders of many ethnic communities and joining in many ethnic celebrations, commemorations and festivals-I have found that Labor's attempts to misrepresent the Liberal Party have failed and, indeed, have backfired.

The relationship between the Liberal Party and the ethnic communities has been strengthened over recent months. I have been welcomed both as a member of the Liberal Party and as a friend. When I have spoken with migrants and their families from Vietnam, Greece, Turkey, Italy, Scotland, Ireland, England, Lebanon, Cambodia, China, the Ukraine and the Baltic states their response has always been the same. They say to me, `We understand you; we know what you are on about and we support you. We always have, because we have always had this close relationship'. The Liberal Party was the party which basically founded the immigration program in the postwar period which has been so enormously beneficial to this country. They say to me that they are aware of the nine principles in our policy and that they agree with them. They also say that they support the wording of the Liberal and National parties' policy document on immigration and ethnic affairs released last August.

Whether it has been at a vigil for peace in the Lebanon, at a seminar on the Middle East, at a commemoration of the independence days of Vietnam, the Baltic states or the Ukraine or at a Greek or Italian ball, the story is the same: `We like it in Australia. We have a commitment to Australia and to its democratic and legal traditions. We are proud to be Australian. We enjoy the vast opportunities that this country has to offer for us and our children'.

They tell me of their concern with the way that the economy is going and their fear of the burden that their children will face as a result of the massive national debt that is being accumulated as a result of the complete economic mismanagement of the Hawke Government. They also tell me of their concern at the breakdown of the traditional concept and role of the family in our society and their concern at the declining quality of life.

Many of them also tell me of their concern about those policies of the Hawke Government which divide communities within themselves and from other communities. Of course, this is a concern which was also heavily reflected in the findings of the FitzGerald Commission. This is an issue of fundamental importance for the future of this country. It ought to transcend party political lines. Instead, to its eternal shame, the Hawke Government has attempted to play cheap party politics on these matters and to gag rational debate on them by painting those who point to its divisive policies as somehow racist or opposed to continuing immigration into Australia.

Of course, nothing could be further from the truth; therefore, all the more reason for bringing to public attention some of the facts. These clearly show that, despite the Hawke Government's attempts to emphasise the differences between ethnic groups in Australia rather than their common interests, and whilst recognising at the same time their rich cultural diversity, Australia is fast becoming a nation populated by people not of any single ethnic origin but a mixture of ethnic origins.

The distinguished Australian demographer Charles Price recently produced data on inter-ethnic marriages in Australia. That data is quite startling. It shows that over two-thirds of the Australian population have at least two ethnic origins. This ethnic mix has occurred at a rapid pace. Of the 712,000 second and third generation Australians born to parents originating in the same country in the postwar period up to 1981, some 627,000 married persons whose parents did not originate in the same country as their own parents. Only 85,000 married persons with the same parental country as themselves. Present marriage trends show that the mixing is continuing. Of single immigrants arriving and marrying in Australia between 1981 and 1987, only 27 per cent married persons born in the same country. For second generation persons, the figure is even less.

There are enormous implications here for the Australian national identity. The 1986 census data shows that one-fifth of respondents-that is, some three million Australians-when asked about their ancestry, simply responded `Australian'. The rapid inter-mixing that is occurring suggests that by the next census there will be many more who think of themselves as simply Australian, by ethnic origin and ancestry as well as by birth, upbringing and culture. The continued creation of unity through diversity has been a hallmark of Australian's development throughout our history. We have always been a multi-racial society. We have also been one of the most racially tolerant societies on earth. It is of the most crucial importance that the divisive policies of this Labor Government, policies which are based essentially on patronage and attempted populist buying of ethnic votes, not be allowed to damage or destroy this precious jewel of our social fabric.

In leading for the Opposition in this debate, Senator Alston has made most of the points of detail in relation to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill that I would have wished to make, so I will not go over all the ground again in this second reading debate. Of course, there will be further consideration in committee as we move to amendments. However, there are a few additional things that should be said.

Honourable senators will be aware that the original legislation introduced into the Senate in early May contained three major features and quite a few matters of somewhat lesser significance, although they too were important. The three key features were, to paraphrase the Minister, firstly, a radically revised approach to immigration decision making based on a near complete abolition of the ministerial discretions which have been a longstanding component of our immigration policy and administration; secondly, the introduction of a new two-tier review system, the first tier of review being departmental, the second a new immigration review tribunal; and, thirdly, the spelling out of mechanisms for ensuring that the planned immigration program intake are not exceeded.

Another key feature overlying all these others was that the Act would contain very little detail of Australia's immigration policy. The detail was to be contained in Government regulations which were to be introduced progressively over a lengthy period of time and only after these Bills had gone through the Parliament and the Acts had been proclaimed. The Minister made great play of the need to treat the Bills as an integrated package. He concluded his second reading speech by saying:

The Bill is a package and its constituent elements are closely integrated. If this total package is not adopted, then the Government would be faced with the piecemeal introduction of some of its provisions. The end result would be that the current situation would simply continue. This is unsatisfactory from the point of view of those affected directly by the operations of the Act, and from the point of view of determining policy and protecting the wider public interest.

The Minister should not have been surprised at the negative reaction of the coalition and of the many ethnic organisations to parts of the so-called integrated package. He was surprised and obviously he had not done his homework amongst the communities concerned.

The Liberal and National parties endorsed many of the objectives of the legislation and, of course, still do, In particular, we endorsed a better defined and genuinely independent review process, a clear policy to reduce the number of illegal immigrants in Australia and recover the costs of deportation proceedings from illegal immigrants, the protection of clients from unscrupulous immigration agents and their operations, tightening of assurances of support, and tightening of change of status provisions. However, we pointed to several major weaknesses in the legislation and said that it should be redrafted to remove those weaknesses.

The original legislation was deficient in several respects. The Government was proposing an undue reliance on regulations of which at the moment the Parliament has no knowledge and in some cases, as I said, would not be available for parliamentary scrutiny for up to the next 18 months. There was no mechanism put in there for parliamentary involvement in the interim period. We were also concerned at the denial by the Government of its role and the Minister's responsibility in administering and controlling Australia's immigration and the placing of complete authority with non-elected public servants, a point about which much has been made in the debate so far. We were concerned about the withdrawal from effective parliamentary scrutiny of the administration of immigration. We were concerned about the deficiencies in the legislation in relation to the expensive and lengthy legal procedures which will follow the introduction of the legislation, making much of the legislation, in effect, unenforceable. At the time, we reaffirmed that it is the role of the elected government to make the final and absolute decisions in regard to who enters Australia for any reason. It is not the responsibility of the bureaucracy.

As I said at the outset, after an initial fit of pique when he said he would not proceed to have the Bill debated, in the light of these responses common sense fortunately prevailed and Senator Ray sat down with the Opposition and the ethnic organisations to negotiate ways of meeting the widely held objections. I pay particular tribute in this context to the then coalition shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, Alan Cadman, for the constructive role he played in helping to initiate these negotiations. Admirably, the new shadow Minister, Philip Ruddock, took up where Alan Cadman left off. I pay tribute to the constructive role played by the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council and other ethnic organisations involved in the negotiations. I also pay tribute to the Chairman of the Council, Mr Carl Harbaum, and his Deputy Chairman, George Wojak. I congratulate them on the role they have played.

The result of the negotiations is that the Government is proposing several major amendments to the legislation. The Minister has agreed to reinstate himself for the Secretary to his Department where the issue of discretion is relevant. Discretion will be incorporated in the decision-making process so far as the regulations are proposed. Instructions for drafting regulations will require that they be prepared in accordance with the Government's announced reforms to establish entry criteria. There are many others as well of a complicated nature. It is understood by all concerned that the drafting will take at least a year or more to complete. Although it is not part of the Bill, the Minister has agreed, in order that parliamentary scrutiny may be undertaken-a fundamental point from the Opposition's point of view-that a select committee be established for a period of two years to review regulations in advance of their promulgation. The Committee's task would be to ensure that regulations accurately reflect announced policy and that discretions for compassionate consideration are properly incorporated.

Other amendments are proposed. We propose the inclusion of sunset clauses in the regulations. The Minister has given an undertaking that, whilst not being prepared to change the inquisitorial role of his review process, to evaluate the review process after two years, either independently with a report to Parliament or by the parliamentary committee. Another very welcome amendment is that, whilst enabling closure of all or any part of the program, if numbers exceed annual program targets the Bill will exclude the immediate family category from this. We also welcome an undertaking by the Minister to table in Parliament relevant statistics to demonstrate the need to cut off all or any part of the remainder of the program. Other changes are proposed in the amendments. One proposal relates to the 28-day rule, and so on. They are all very desirable and welcome changes.

There are one or two points about which I have some concern on the question of ministerial discretion. I can personally understand the Minister's original view. I think he went too far in removing his discretions and he was rightly criticised for that. Many of those discretions, as I understand it, have now been reinstated. Perhaps we might have gone too far back the other way-I do not know. The matter, I would think, is one that should be kept under review. I also have some doubts about the precise application of the floating pass mark system. I have a feeling that it could lead to inconsistencies, anomalies and unfairness. I understand what the Minister is getting at. The floating pass mark system that is proposed in the legislation is very close in concept to that proposed by the FitzGerald Commission to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. But it is a new and novel concept and it also should be kept under review.

Finally, I regret that the Government has decided to keep the total immigration intake at 140,000 for each of the next two to three years. I believe, as does the coalition, that 150,000 would have been a more appropriate level with the increase from 140,000 to 150,000 being concentrated particularly in the area of the entry of skilled migrants. With those qualifications, I support the Bill with the amendments that are to be made. I note that the Bill, as amended, will look significantly different from the Bill that was introduced originally and which the Minister said needed to be considered as an integrated package. He said that if parts of it were changed or deleted, we would have a less than satisfactory situation. I would hope that he would now agree that that is not the case. The flexibility in approach to this Bill adopted on all sides has been a very worthwhile and important experience. We now have a better Bill than we had at the start. It is an important piece of legislation. I, along with other members of the coalition, am very pleased to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I should make it clear at the outset, to clear up one misconception, that the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 and the Migration Amendment Bill 1989 were never withdrawn. They were merely relegated to the bottom of the Notice Paper. I said at the time in press interviews that they would only be promoted back onto the Notice Paper if they could secure a second reading in this particular debate. A lot has been said by other senators about my spitting the dummy in a fit of pique, and so on. Senator Hamer would realise the value of strategic withdrawal in military matters until one's reserve regiments are ready to come up. If that degree of censure or humiliation for me is necessary to get the Bills through, I will happily accommodate those charges. It would have been churlish not to negotiate on the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to put on the public record my thanks to the Liberal spokesman, Alan Cadman, for his discussions on this matter; to Mr Phil Ruddock, for his subsequent discussions on the matter; and to Senators Puplick and Alston for their discussion on the clauses of the Bills. I would also like to publicly thank Senator Baden Teague. It was a casual conversation with him that acted as a circuit breaker to getting discussions going. Whilst I will not be responding to his speech in the chamber today, I must say that I thought it was an excellent speech showing a great grasp of the issues. I would also like to thank Senator Jenkins for her correspondence on this immigration matter, in which she detailed her concerns for the Bills. Some of those concerns will be met; some will not. I just say to her that the difference between the idealistic clause and the running of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs happens to be fairly wide. I hope she will appreciate that.

There will be a number of Government sponsored amendments in the committee stage. We have tried to meet the concerns of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Where possible I have met those concerns in nearly all cases. I have also tried to meet those concerns raised by the coalition and by the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils. I have met some of the objections of the Australian Democrats, but not all. I will give an example of some of the smaller amendments that we have agreed to. One amendment relates to 70 days for appeal for people overseas. I still stick by the 28 days for those in Australia because they have the benefit of what is in Australia. But I clearly saw that with postage problems in places such as Lebanon and Vietnam and other communication problems with eastern Europe, a 70-day rule would be far more appropriate. On the question of the right to have an interpreter at the Immigration Review Tribunal, it was a view of my Department and me that this is covered by other law and administrative law in this country. Having raised this issue that it may be a problem because it was not a right that was so asserted, we have included that in the Bill to make it absolutely unambiguous as a right.

In relation to the question of split decisions by the Immigration Review Tribunal, we have amended the legislation so that if there is a split position, the more senior member will have the determination in his hands. Another example is that we have inserted a 28-day clock in terms of deportations. I always accepted-because of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act-that the clock would stop if there was an appeal to the Federal Government. People were worried about that and the Bill has accordingly been amended.

I wish to spend a little more time on the more principal amendments to the Act. The first question is that of ministerial responsibility-discretion. I have compromised on this issue in order to get this Bill through. I want to put on the public record-even though it has been in the press and asserted by spokesmen who should know better; I do not say it is anyone in this Parliament-that the accusation that this decision was made to remove a workload on a Minister is absolutely baseless. I point out to visitors to my office that I am up to date on case work. I do not resent it. It is done. It was never conceived as a way of shifting workloads from a Minister to a bureaucrat. I have only one objection to ministerial discretion. It is a remaining objection and one I will probably always have. What I do not like about it is access. Who has access to a Minister? Can a Minister personally decide every immigration case? The answer is always no. Those who tend to get access to a Minister are members of parliament and other prominent people around the country. I worry for those who do not have access and whether they are being treated equally by not having access to a Minister. That has been my sole concern in regard to this matter.

There is another side to the coin. I always believe that a Minister should be responsible for the decisions, whether he or his department makes them. Even under the original Act it was never intended that the Minister would no longer have responsibility for decisions made by his department. I am quite proud of the fact that in spite of a long discussion in my Party, my Party came down on the side of equity and fairness on this issue. We debated it. There were all sorts of points of view made. In the end the Labor Party, in its deliberations on this matter, came down on the side of principle. I am very proud of the fact that it did. That is not to imply that the Opposition is not arguing a principle case in this particular matter. But there are different views on the way ministerial discretion has been exercised in the past. I do not make accusations. Under the old system it is open to abuse in terms of political patronage and favouritism, but, more importantly, who has access to a Minister is the critical issue. That has always been the critical issue in considering these migration matters.

The second large issue relates to the question of regulations. Quite properly, an objection has been raised that a lot of the content of immigration will be done under regulations. I remind this chamber of how immigration has been run in the past. It has been run not by regulation or legislation but purely by ministerial directive, subject to no scrutiny in this Parliament and subject to no control by anyone. The great revolution in this particular piece of legislation is that it requires policy in the future to be put in regulations. Those regulations can be disallowed by this Parliament. Those regulations will now be a fixed body of law. The decision makers will be controlled not by an arbitrary whim of the Minister to change his decision or directive but by regulations which become law. That is a large step towards improvement.

To overcome this problem we have set up a joint select committee-I am anticipating that it will go through both Houses-to oversee those regulations. It will be looking at those regulations to make sure they fit Government policy and that they have sufficient flexibility to make decisions as good as possible. That is not to say that the Government will not continue to change its immigration policy in the more minor areas to catch up with different developments in immigration. For instance, I do not think anyone in this chamber would deny that, if a new scam was discovered by which illegal immigrants could gain entry to this country, the Government would close them off. For the most part, regulations will reflect announced policy.

In addition, the suggestion from the coalition, and an excellent one at that, was to apply a sunset clause to the regulations governing the criteria for entry. What the coalition did not want was to be locked in forever on regulations. That is a philosophy that I support. I do not believe that the Government of the day should lock future governments into an immigration policy forever, nor do I believe that the Government wants to be locked in forever. By having a sunset clause, two years down the track after the regulations are promulgated, a government will want them reviewed. It may want to reissue the regulations. It may want to change them. Having a sunset clause means that an immigration policy is not locked in forever as holy writ.

The third area I want to move into is the review of the Immigration Review Tribunal. I have made a commitment and I am about to make it here, that two years into the operation, that is at the end of two years of operation of the Tribunal, the Government will review the operations of the Tribunal. I understand that, in another place, Mr Ruddock will make a similar commitment. It is a very welcome commitment. Two years down the track the Immigration Review Tribunal will be reviewed by an independent body. It may well be a parliamentary committee appointed by the parliament or an independent inquiry appointed by the Minister. It is essential that that commitment be made so that everyone knows that, down the track, the Immigration Review Tribunal will be reviewed. Things such as natural justice, efficiency, speed of operation and fairness can be canvassed to make sure that the Tribunal is operating according to the intention of the Parliament.

The final matter I want to mention is that, under the Act, the Minister and the Secretary have the ability to close off a specific category of entry. Immediately, this was blown up by the various advocates around the place to mean that this Government, the Minister or the Department could close off preferential family reunion. That was never the intention, for a variety of reasons. To make it absolutely clear, the Government will amend the Act to exclude that category. Would any rational government, Labor or Liberal, wanting to be re-elected, close off that area? Absolutely not. To make it absolutely clear the Government will exclude preferential family from an area of closure.

A variety of matters were raised during the debate on the second reading. I cannot go through them all but I will deal with some of the issues raised. Senator Alston, in his opening remarks, went back to the report of the FitzGerald Commission to Advise on Australia's Immigration Polices (CAAIP). Basically, as I read it, some people believed that we made a mistake with regard to citizenship where he advocates what are really punitive measures to force people to become citizens, that is, preventing them from getting social security and other benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incentives.

—Senator Alston regards it as incentives. I do not regard taking away unemployment benefits and other benefits to be incentives. To me, good citizenship comes from a commitment from the heart. It does not come from a gun being held at the head or from other threats. A commitment from people to become good citizens will come from them when they give it positively. That is my view on it. There are certain circumstances in which people find difficulty in becoming citizens; for instance, property laws. It is a lessening problem, but under the property laws in some countries a person who becomes a citizen in this country forfeits his rights in another country and that could affect his relatives in the other country. There is another large category that refuses to take the oath to the Queen and to Australia. It is no secret that many Irishmen do not like taking that oath. The Parliament has twice considered that matter and rejected it.
—Americans don't, either.

—Yes, Americans, and there are others. I might be more sympathetic to the point of view of the Opposition if we could free up these parts of the citizenship legislation to give a much greater incentive to people to take out citizenship. I do not think the punitive path works. What happens when a person does not take out citizenship, for whatever reason, and is unemployed with several children? Should the children be punished or should the person be told that he can get certain benefits if he takes out citizenship? Is that the sort of commitment we want to Australia? I do not.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter referred to by Senator Alston was the English language test. Words such as `pandering to different groups' were mentioned in this context. The Government put a good deal of thought into whether an English language test should apply to the extended family, and rejected it. It was rejected mainly not for economic reasons, because the economic advantages are clear, but it was considered that an equal playing field in the family area was wanted. If there were an English test, it would apply dramatically to different regions of the world. The automatic assumption by some people-not those opposite-was that whacking in an English language test would reduce the number of immigrants coming from Asia. Nothing could be further from the truth because English is more a second language there than anywhere else in the world. It would have greatly affected potential immigrants from non-Commonwealth countries such as the Middle East, so a good deal of consideration was given to whether an English language test should be applied for extended families and the Government rejected that proposal. However, it was considered, to be totally fair, to have a language test for the independents, not based simply on English but on their language proficiency. That is very much the dog eat dog world of independence. May the best 23,000 win. So it applies in that area.

The third point made by Senator Alston was that we should go back to FitzGerald, which was not really relevant to this Bill, and a couple of the things he said. Mr FitzGerald was fairly complimentary about the package that we came up with after the CAAIP report. He was not happy with every aspect of it but he was complimentary about the package.

The fourth point raised by Senator Alston is one that I must contest. He said that the Government has been mean, that it should have made the immigration program 150,000. There is a variety of reasons not to go to 150,000, not the least of which was a point made by the Premier of New South Wales about some of the infrastructure problems. An increase from 140,000 to 150,000, taken out of context, might have some relevance to the debate but the figures that are not counted are the 27,000 New Zealanders who are settling in Australia. That number is increasing enormously this financial year. When we are talking about infrastructure, it is not simply a case of 140,000 or 150,000; it is starting off with a base of 167,000 and considering an increase to 177,000.

I think that the point Senator Alston made is that if the figure were increased by 10,000 we could get more skilled people into the country. That is one point of view and it is a legitimate point of view. Other people in the community could argue that, if there is a spare 10,000, consideration should be given to the millions of brothers and sisters of people in Australia. There is no correct balance and there is no correct figure. The Government has said the mix should be 50 per cent families, 40 per cent economic and 10 per cent compassionate. I would not argue with anybody about the correct balance. It is a matter of judgment. I hope that, when the Bureau of Immigration Research is well and truly under way, we will have better data on which to base our decisions on whether the figure should be 140,000 or whatever so that, in the future, we can establish a more rational immigration policy based on firm data.

Senator Alston accused me of publishing a grubby press release. I have a file full of grubby press releases on immigration including some from the immediate past shadow Minister, accusing my head of Department of wanting to become a commissar and, worst of all, wanting to be a Trevor Boucher. I do not know that Trevor Boucher would necessarily be held in poor esteem by any court because of the good job that he has done. There is always a good deal of head butting at the beginning of these affairs. It is how they come out at the other end that is important.

Senator Alston asked whether we would fund specialised agencies to give advice in these particular areas. That will be a matter for the Budget process but I can say that I am looking at it fairly closely.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are looking at it positively.

—Absolutely positively, because the reality is that many of these cases may be avoided by good advice. Immigration is different from any other area. There is an 8 per cent leakage in Social Security and 10 per cent in Veterans. Here the leakage is at least 40 per cent from one tier of review to another, because we are dealing with a different human dimension.
—What do you mean by leakage?

—I mean people who do not succeed under the first tier going on to the second tier. It is much greater in immigration than in any other area because people feel obligated. As they have sponsored a relative to come to Australia, they feel they must go through every possible step to prove to them their bona fides and that they have tried to assist. I think that is all I have to say on Senator Alston's point. Obviously, I have not commended Senator Alston for the positive points he has made; that is not the nature of these debates in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jenkins made a number of points. I cannot respond to them all, but she did make the point about people leaving Australia. The one point I make about that is that the leaving rate now is as low as it has ever been. It is nothing like it was in the fifties, sixties or seventies. Another point she made was that she was not too happy about skills being taken into account. Every bit of research and data that we have relates skills to employability. I know there will always be an exception, but the more skilled a migrant is, the more employable he is and the lower the unemployment rate will be. That must always be a consideration. The last thing we want to do-and, I am sure, the last thing that Senator Jenkins would want to do-is bring people to this country merely to be placed on the unemployment line. There will always be an exception of someone who is skilled in a certain area not being able to find a job, but on the whole there is this relationship.

Senator Jenkins looked at environmental factors as they affect immigration. I hope that she notes my record on this matter. I have never dismissed those factors; I have always said that they should be debated seriously. I do not know what our optimum population is. There must be an optimum population level for this country, that will enable it to remain a major net exporter of food and energy. It could well be argued that we should not continue to increase our population forever because we badly affect the rest of the world by no longer being such a net exporter of food. I do not know where that level lies at the moment. I suspect we are nowhere near that critical level yet.

Senator Jenkins, I thought rather unkindly, quoted the view of FitzGerald on the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Basically, he was talking about the situation that existed two or three years ago, not today. There was no recognition of the Department's use of computers for the benefit of the client or the decentralising of its operations in the two big cities. It should be remembered that we do not have an easy task in the area of immigration. There will be delays. What we are doing is saying no to 80 per cent of people and that is never easy for any government department to do. We are issuing two million visitor visas a year, as well as undertaking a range of other activities, on a total budget of about $225m. We have 125 A-based staff overseas, which is half the number that Canada has, yet even Canada argues that we deliver a far better program with more efficiency than it does. So some of those remarks made by FitzGerald about the operations of the Department concern the past.

This Bill seeks to remove the rest of the criticisms by making all future decisions subject to regulations and the law, to do away with secrecy, to put in a decent appeal system, and to reinvigorate the Department. I believe that process is under way. I hope Senator Jenkins will come to see that that process is under way. She asked why we did not use the model of the veterans' appeals body or the social security appeals body. We did not do so because they involved the first tier review process. We are talking about a second tier process, and that is why we did not slavishly follow those models. That system involves a first tier review, with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal at the other end of the line. We are dealing with second tier appeals.

Senator Jenkins asked, I think quite properly, to what extent flexibility will be done away with. There is flexibility in the current Act. There will be flexibility under the new Act and via the regulations. The trouble is that at the moment one could drive a truck through the flexibility. `Yes, Ministers' and departments will always say, as in the case of the Orionia family that Senator Jenkins referred to, that there will be exceptions that are made outside policy. There was provision in the old Act and there will be provision in the new Act to do exactly that. There must be that sort of flexibility. What people sometimes want is the flexibility to grant every case. Tragically, that is not possible. For every compassionate case that we grant outside the guidelines, someone else queued up somewhere in the world misses out.

I now refer to some remarks made by both Senator Jenkins and Senator Teague. I acknowledged earlier the very positive contribution to the debate made by Senator Teague; I thank him for that. The question of illegals was raised. People say, `Why are there so many illegals?'. Having regard to most comparative countries, they ought to ask, `Why are there so few?'. It should be remembered that two million visitors enter this country every year. We are an immigration country, so people tend to do a runner and decide to stay here. It is interesting that the virtually unanimous view around this chamber and in newspaper editorials is, `We do not support illegals'; that is in the macro sense. But every time there is a micro case, nearly every newspaper and nearly every television program runs a tear-jerker segment, saying, `How can this heartless Minister possibly deport this individual?'. This can occur thousands of times. We have the tough job of balancing the macro and the micro in these cases. At least under the new Bill it will be much easier, with multiple decision making at the one time, to make deportation more feasible and quicker than it has been in the past.

I think that covers the contributions made to the debate on this legislation. On the question of the general criticisms of the Bill, it is interesting that I have not had many criticisms from ethnic groups. I have had criticism from the peak body, but not from individual groups. It could have to do with the complexity of the Bill; I am not sure. Of course, the one word used constantly by the advocacy groups in respect of the Bill was `draconian'. They rarely illustrated how the Bill was draconian, but that word was picked up by everyone-by newspaper editors, by spokesmen, et cetera. I deny that. This Bill is about fairness and equity. It is not a draconian Bill. It will put fairness and equity into our immigration system. It is, however, tough on illegals; and it is tough on them because we have an organised immigration system.

I have compassion for those who obey the law, for those who come out of East Beirut, travel through West Beirut and past the Chouf Mountains, get shaken down by the border guards, wait three days in a queue in Damascus, are numb from travelling on public transport and by taxi, and then find out that because they do not have their birth certificate with them they have to make the journey again, being shot at all the way. Our compassion must lie with those people, not with the first person who jumps off QF2, bypasses our immigration system and does a runner. My compassion lies with those who obey the law, who fill out their 40-page form, work out their sponsorship and do all the right things. When I have to grant a change of status, I sometimes betray those people who line up in the queue and who are delayed or who never come here because we have been weak, because it is a lot easier to give in when someone is here. Of course, it is easy; a parliamentarian comes up to me and says, `Please let so and so's brother stay, he has a lot of votes'. It is a lot easier to make those decisions but they should never be made while someone else who is entitled to come here gets pushed out of the queue because some Minister makes a weak decision.

I understand that illegals in this country are terribly exploited. I think that in the long term we must do something about employers who exploit them and who knowingly hire illegals. Although I want barriers to illegals, we must at all times leave some chink in the armour so that genuine refugees cannot be turned away at our borders. We must always have within our Migration Act provision so that when someone lands in Australia as a genuine refugee he is not turned away but is given due process, so that each of his claims is listened to until the case is finally determined. If we did not do so, we would become a very barbaric country.

In conclusion, I say that this is a complex Bill. It is not a Bill that has been easy to understand. Its very complexity arises because everyone is looking for a loophole in immigration. Any loophole that is left will be exploited. Therefore, at times the language is convoluted. Quite often it is a defensive mechanism. I make no apology for that. Someone drew an analogy-it may have been Senator Alston-between this Bill and a tax Bill: everyone is looking for a way through, for the soft underbelly of the scheme. What we try to do is leave no loopholes but leave a defence for the Department and this country to have an orderly immigration system. I thank all senators for their contributions to the debate and wish the Bill a relatively speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —At present, section 37 of the Migration Act permits an officer, firstly, to board and search a vessel where there is reason to suspect that there are stowaways or persons seeking to enter illegally; secondly, to stop a vessel or a vehicle in the exercise of his powers-after a later amendment that will read `his or her'-above; and, thirdly, with a search warrant issued by an authorised officer, to enter and search any building, vehicle or place for prohibited non-citizens or for persons working illegally and seize papers, passports and documents of identity. This means that under the present powers an officer may enter, search and detain an illegal entrant but he cannot frisk him for weapons or documents nor search his property.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill seeks to give two additional powers: first, to search the person and any property of the person reasonably supposed to be an illegal immigrant for documents and, secondly, with a search warrant issued by the Secretary, to enter a building or vehicle in which there is reasonable cause to believe that valuables belonging to an illegal entrant may be found under section 21d (16). Of course, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee says that the power to enter and search for property should be exercised only under a warrant issued by a judge or magistrate.

We have here an unusual situation where an illegal entrant may be detained without warrant by an officer pending judicial examination within 48 hours, but his property that can be secreted quickly should not, the Committee says, be searched for with a warrant unless the warrant is issued by a judge or magistrate. Of course, by the time the authority of a judge or magistrate asserts a property can be obtained, even by phone, the property would have gone. That is despite the provision in the Bill that the detention of any property must be subject to judicial examination within three working days.

The power of search of buildings, vehicles and places sought in relation to illegal entry of persons in subsections 21d (16) and (18) is similar to, if not milder than, the power of search of buildings, vehicles and places in relation to illegal entry of goods under sections 59, 91, 184, 185, 187 and 197 of the Customs Act. The search warrant in that Act is, as is proposed in this Bill, exercisable by a senior officer. In relation to the illegal entry of both persons and goods, the search powers must be adequate to deal with the problems involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point Senator Jenkins sought to make is that it is necessary to have a formal mechanism to guard against abuse. That is the principal reason why both the Government and the Opposition ultimately have taken the view that `an authorised officer' was too low a grade of responsibility. We take the view that if the power is vested in the Secretary to the Department it is a formal responsibility. It is one that could be reviewed in due course if there were no good grounds for the issue of the warrant in the first instance.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the fact that time is often of the essence and in a situation such as is contemplated by the clause, it is often necessary to conduct a search at short notice. I think that there is sufficient flexibility in the proposal to make the Secretary the responsible person. As I understand it, the purpose of the search is not simply to detect goods that might have been brought in illegally, but also to enable access to the goods and property of an illegal immigrant which might then be available to meet the costs of deportation or of keeping that person in custody. I think there is good reason for this; it is not merely to boost public revenue. Assuming that there is power to review it ultimately, I would have thought that it strikes the necessary balance between flexibility and formality. We support the Government's amendment.

Amendment (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
(66) Page 58, clause 26, after proposed subsection 64p (6) and the following new subsection:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Proposed new subsection 64p (7), leave out the proposed new subsection, insert the following subsections:
`` `(7) A person whose native language is not English must be provided with an accredited interpreter during an appearance before the Tribunal to give evidence, provided that:
(a) the person has requested an interpreter because he or she lacks proficiency in English; and

(b) the Tribunal, after due inquiry, is satisfied that the person lacks proficiency in English and the provision of an interpreter would assist the person and thereby serve the interests of fairness in the proceedings; and
(c) an accredited interpreter is available.
`` `(8) Where an accredited interpreter is not available for the purposes of subsection (7), the Tribunal must:
(a) obtain the services of a suitable interpreter recognized by the National Authority for the Accreditation of Translators and Interpreters; or
(b) if a suitable recognized interpreter is not available, obtain the services of any other suitable interpreter; or
(c) if any other suitable interpreter is not available either:
(i) adjourn or postpone the taking of evidence until an accredited, recognized or otherwise suitable interpreter is available; or

(ii) if an adjournment or postponement would cause prejudice or injustice to the applicant, take the evidence in such a way that communication between the person and the Tribunal is facilitated to the fullest possible extent in the circumstances without causing greater prejudice or injustice to the applicant than would be caused by an adjournment or postponement of the proceedings.

`` `(9) For the purposes of subsection (7) and `accredited interpreter' is a person qualified under the rules of the National Authority for the Accreditation of Translators and Interpreters at the standard known as Level 3.'.''.

The Australian Democrats were certainly very pleased to see the Government's amendment No. 66 because this is one of the provisions for which we called. However, in the view of the Democrats, the provision is not strong enough. I will explain why. The Government's amendment reads:

`` `(7) Where a person appearing before the Tribunal to give evidence is not proficient in English, the presiding member may direct that communication with that person during his or her appearance proceed through an interpreter.''.

The legislation simply states `is not proficient in English'. I can inform the Senate that I have viewed the process of such decisions being made. A magistrate or a judge in a court can make that decision by asking the person concerned, `What is your name?'. The person will give his or her name. `What is your address' is then asked and the person gives his or her address. The magistrate or the judge can then say that this person's English is quite proficient: he or she does not need an interpreter. Most people who have been here only for a short while or do not use the English language to a great extent can give their name and address. However, in a courtroom situation or in a situation such as this one where a tribunal is sitting, such a person would not necessarily be able to understand all the workings of the Tribunal without an interpreter to pass on that information to him or her. That is why I have moved this amendment, which is quite substantial and detailed, on behalf of the Democrats.
Part of the amendment, to be inserted in place of the Government's, reads:
`` `(7) A person whose native language is not English must be provided with an accredited interpreter during an appearance before the Tribunal to give evidence, provided that:
(a) the person has requested an interpreter because he or she lacks proficiency in English
In other words, very often the people themselves are the best judges as to whether they can communicate properly and can understand the proceedings. Paragraph (b) of the amendment states:

(b) the Tribunal, after due inquiry, is satisfied that the person lacks proficiency in English and the provision of an interpreter would assist the person and thereby serve the interests of fairness in the proceedings; and
`After due inquiry' are the operative words. Sometimes it is felt that people ask for an interpreter for reasons other than their need. The amendment continues:
(c) an accredited interpreter is available.
To that we have added:
`` `(8) Where an accredited interpreter is not available for the purposes of subsection (7), the Tribunal must:
(a) obtain the services of a suitable interpreter recognized by the National Authority for the Accreditation of Translators and Interpreters; or
(b) if a suitable recognized interpreter is not available, obtain the services of any other suitable interpreter; or
(c) if any other suitable interpreter is not available either:
(i) adjourn or postpone the taking of evidence until an accredited, recognized or otherwise suitable interpreter is available; or

(ii) if an adjournment or postponement would cause prejudice or injustice to the applicant, take the evidence in such a way that communication between the person and the Tribunal is facilitated to the fullest possible extent . . .

Then there is the definition of an accredited interpreter. We have chosen to go into these details because, having some knowledge of abuses by interpreters in a courtroom or where unaccredited or unrecognised interpreters are used, we feel that this detail is necessary. The tightening up of these clauses is necessary also. I must tell the Minister that I do not believe that there is such tight legislation anywhere else in Australia at present. However, as this is an immigration amendment Bill, I think this would be the place to start. Therefore, I canvass very strongly the Senate's support for this Democrat amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment. I draw Senator Jenkins's attention to where the clause was drawn from, which is the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. In our inquiries, we have found that there has been no difficulty in the way this clause has operated with that Tribunal. We see no reason why it should be transferred over. We have a second problem and that is the use of the words `accredited interpreter'. That would make the Act unworkable. Senator Jenkins must remember that many of our inquiries and interviews will be done overseas. If an accredited interpreter is simply someone qualified under the rules of the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters, those people will not be available to take evidence overseas. That clause is simply not workable.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Jenkins's implied suggestion was that it is a matter for the discretion of the head of the Tribunal. Let me assure her that the head of the Tribunal will not quibble over the use of an interpreter. One might face the prospect of a denial and then an appeal to the Federal Court. Again, it comes back to this conception that the Tribunal is not someone sitting up on high, antagonistic to the client. We want to imbue in the Tribunal a desire to assist the inquiries of a client-not go the other way. As such, what Senator Jenkins is suggesting could well become a bureaucratic nightmare. It would not only be unworkable with people overseas but also become a bureaucratic nightmare. This section of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal has worked well for it and it is dealing with the same clients.

I also say for the record that most people applying before the Tribunal do not fit the sort of stereotype that we have of them that they cannot speak English; most of them can. It is on that ability that they are able to be employed and sponsor relatives. If what we are saying is that most of the clients will not be able to express themselves in English, I must have a much more thorough look at immigration than I ever have before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we all share the concern of Senator Jenkins that persons appearing before a tribunal such as the Social Security Appeals Tribunal should not be unfairly deprived of the opportunity to convey their message in the best possible manner. Quite clearly, interpreters will be required in a number of instances. But I think there is a misconception in what Senator Jenkins was saying if she was intending to convey the notion that, as presently worded, this clause would require the Tribunal to make a judgment about a person's proficiency after having heard only the name and address of the witness. That clearly is not the case. As it reads, the presiding member would be under an obligation to make that judgment at any stage as to whether a person is not proficient in English. I am certainly very familiar with situations in which people can give evidence in a court of law and can quite often string together a series of yeses or noes. It only becomes apparent, perhaps during cross-examination, that the person's English is pretty limited and that the witness is not doing justice to himself or herself. In a situation such as that, it would still be open to the Tribunal to decide that it was necessary to obtain an interpreter.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the rather complex language put forward by the Australian Democrats, at the end of it all, there is still a requirement that the Tribunal be satisfied after due inquiry. So, I do not really see why that amendment takes the matter any further. To hinge it on the need for a person to request an interpreter because that person's native language is not English is almost a tautology. It is highly unlikely that an English speaking person would be seeking the assistance of an interpreter. Perhaps some of us speak the language better or worse than others; but it certainly would not be appropriate to seek an interpreter in situations such as that.

The second leg of that qualification occurs where the person has requested an interpreter because that person is not proficient in English. If that is a matter of subjective assessment on the part of a witness, it is clearly open to abuse. If it is an objective assessment to be made by the Tribunal, one is back where one started. At the end of the day, the Tribunal has to be satisfied that the person is not proficient in English. The only concern that I have-and I address this to the Minister-is the fact that there is still a discretion. If the Tribunal is satisfied that a person is not proficient in English, in what circumstances would the presiding member not direct that communication proceed through an interpreter? We need assurances on that matter rather than on the basis that seems to concern the Democrats. I would have thought that implicit in the whole proposal to provide an interpreter is the assumption that an interpreter will be made available where necessary. Because of the discretionary rather than mandatory nature of the clause, on the face of it, it is still open to the Tribunal to decline to provide those services, even where necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to some of the remarks that were made about the Democrat amendment. It is very easy to presume a facility in English because people can manage their day to day affairs very well-they can carry out their work, do the shopping and manage their household duties and so on. However, when people find themselves in a more formalised situation it is very often a different state of affairs. In fact, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has backed up what I said initially-that is, that it is presumed that because a person can carry out necessary daily duties comprehensively, he or she can both communicate and comprehend in a situation which is very different and in which very different language is used. Because of that I suggest that where these tribunals take place in Australia-or indeed elsewhere-I was previously not aware that they would sit outside Australia--
—They take evidence overseas. Another section of the Act says that evidence can be gathered overseas.

—My amendment deals with the Tribunal only and so does the Government's. In any case, that authority could cope with overseas qualifications, but as I see it, we are looking at a situation which deals with the Tribunal within Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this is a very good opportunity for this more comprehensive sort of provision for an interpreter to be incorporated into legislation and the Migration Amendment Bill would be the best piece of legislation to start with. The Minister said that he had taken the wording from the Social Security Act with regard to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. One of the problems is that when the wording is loose-and the Minister has said that he is prepared to tighten up his own wording, and I appreciate that-there is a danger that proper proceedings will not take place. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to this question, I acknowledge the three sound reasons that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has given. TALK.START.PARA: —I have two possible courses of action in regard to the interpretation of this. I would respectfully suggest that my first course of action is best, that I have stated my interpretation of it for the Acts Interpretation Act. I think we should leave it there and it can be subject to the review in two years' time.

—I make it clear that it is only on the basis that the discretionary word `may' operates satisfactorily in the Social Security Tribunal arena that I am prepared to allow it to proceed on that basis. I have an inbuilt reservation about imposing the mandatory `shall'. It is very difficult to articulate in advance whether problems might arise. But I know from experience that it can cause unforeseen problems. Given that there will be a review and that the experience in the social security area has been positive, I do not foresee too many difficulties arising as a result, assuming always that the Tribunal will act sympathetically. I think it has been made clear from the debate on this clause that we all expect the Tribunal at all times to err on the side of a person who appears not to be proficient in English.

—I am also disappointed that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is not prepared to change his `may' to `shall'. If Senator Alston wishes to move that himself, it certainly will have Australian Democrats support. One of the problems is that people do shy away from using interpreters because it can make the proceedings lengthier when one has to go through a third person, although the use of an interpreter when required does add to the justice of the situation, so I would appeal to the Minister to reconsider his decision.

—I make it clear, if I have not done so already, that our position is that we presume good faith. We proceed on the basis that if a situation did arise where a tribunal chose not to order an interpreter where it was clearly necessary, that would probably be the subject of a prerogative writ. In that situation the tribunal would be told in no uncertain terms that it was not to exercise a discretion arbitrarily or against the interests of a person not proficient in English. On that basis, and in view of the precedent of the Social Security Tribunal which does seem to work satisfactorily, we are prepared to leave that discretion there in case unforeseen situations arise in which it may be desirable that one not be simply compelled to order an interpreter. As I say, it is very difficult to spell out the precise circumstances in which such a situation might arise. But I know from my own experience in the courts that it is very desirable to have that discretion. As long as we assume that the tribunal is not going to act in bad faith, then I do not think we will come to too much harm.

—I note that the arrangements for the Tribunal will be reviewed after perhaps two years and the evaluation will come to this chamber. I specifically ask the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to draw the attention of the Tribunal to these exchanges and the expectation that the Tribunal will, in all but exceptional circumstances where there is a need for it, actually see that there is an interpreter available. May the Tribunal, in its report to the Minister, from time to time address this question so that we are fully informed as to the intentions, which we all have, being actually followed by the Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity again to reinforce the fact that these 82 amendments have been determined by discussion between the Government and the Opposition.
