TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say this only once throughout the debate on the Australian Democrats' amendments: one of the great problems I have with them-and I must say that I have looked at them only this afternoon-is that they tend to be almost a package within themselves. It takes us 180 degrees away from where the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill is heading. To adopt any one of them does not necessarily fit in with the previous package. But I will go to each clause as it is raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I have two problems with the amendment. Firstly, it would defeat any capping of entry permit because it would permit illegal entrants a period of amnesty from deportation. Secondly, it would also allow a very well funded illegal entrant to buy an unlimited amnesty while every recourse is pursued. For those two reasons, I cannot support the amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 9, after clause 5, insert the following new clause:
``5a. The Principal Act is amended by inserting the following new Part after Part I:
`PART 1A-FAIRNESS IN DECISIONS
Avoidance of injustice etc.

`5A In spite of any other provision of this Act, a decision under this Act, by an officer, a review officer, the Secretary, the Minister, the Tribunal or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal must be in favour of the applicant if:
(a) because of the special circumstances of the case it would be manifestly unfair, unjust and oppressive to decide otherwise; and
(b) the decision is otherwise not inconsistent with the objects of this Act.'.''.

I did hear the Minister's comments. Nonetheless, amendment No. 2 is crucial to the Australian Democrats. The Migration Act 1958 has been widely and justifiably criticised because it gives an enormous range of discretion to the Minister and the departmental decision-makers. As the Minister well knows, as a result, a very large number of requests on behalf of individual applicants are presented to him for consideration. The Minister thus becomes burdened with a large case load of individual decisions. In these circumstances, I am sure it is possible for the Minister to wilt under pressure when faced by a decision which has obvious political implications.

The aim of the Government in this legislation is to correct the situation by removing the element of discretion. However, the Democrats are of the view that under the Bill before us the pendulum has swung from one highly undesirable extreme to the other equally undesirable extreme-that is, to a situation in which there is virtually no discretion left at all. In other words, the Government has thrown the baby out with the bath water. The immigration decisions have been compared with taxation decisions, but we are not making taxation decisions. We are not dealing with figures and numbers, and we are not dealing with the national accounts; we are talking about people, about human lives. We are making major decisions. We are talking about whether Australians will be permitted to live with their children, with the partners of their choice, or with their elderly parents. In refugee cases, for example, it is about whether people will be deported from Australia to their countries of origin in which they might face imprisonment for long periods, or face persecution or, as has happened in extreme cases, even execution. Human beings do not fit into convenient pigeonholes. There will always be the occasional special circumstance. There will always be difficult cases at the margin. The new part proposed in my amendment which is headed `Fairness in Decisions' states:

`5a In spite of any other provision of this Act, a decision under this Act, by an officer, a review officer, the Secretary, the Minister, the Tribunal or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal must be in favour of the applicant if:
(a) because of the special circumstances of the case it would be manifestly unfair, unjust and oppressive to decide otherwise; and
(b) the decision is otherwise not inconsistent with the objects of this Act.'.''.

In other words, the objects of the Act may well be to be fair and just, et cetera, but we cannot legislate for every single case. This amendment provides a very suitable-I do not want to use the word `loophole' because I do not mean loophole-part of the legislation for the Minister to use if he knew that the decision he was forced to make, because the terms of the Act were tight, would be unjust. I put it to honourable senators that this amendment would lead to a more just, a more equitable and, above all, a more efficient system. I do not believe that legislating for every single dot and comma is necessarily efficient. We are talking about human beings. We all know what happens to very efficient regimes, and I do not think we want to go in that direction. With this proposed amendment we can arrive at decisions which will be respected and will be even more cost-efficient. The Government has proposed a rigid system in which there is virtually no discretion at all. This, inevitably, will lead to a proliferation of appeals, since decision makers will have no choice but to refuse `special circumstances' applications and the applicants will, therefore, be inclined to use the appeals process. So we need a system with enough flexibility to ensure that cases, which do not precisely fit the prescribed criteria, but which obviously have special merits, can be approved without having to be dragged through the full and expensive appeals process.

TALK.START.PARA: —This sort of provision provides a field day for lawyers, but I do not think it does much for decision makers. It throws out all the other guidelines, provisions and requirements, and allows a catch-all discretion provision which, in a sense, is a classic invitation to hopeless cases to throw themselves on the mercy of the courts. Let me illustrate one example of where it would not be, presumably, the intention of the Australian Democrats. If we were to find that because of the special circumstances of a case it would be manifestly unfair, unjust and oppressive to decide otherwise but, in fact, the decision was inconsistent with the objects of the Act, we would fail on that test. That seems to be a ludicrous proposition because presumably what the Democrats have in mind is that the ultimate discretion should override everything else. It renders it a nonsense. I could perhaps understand it if they confined it to part (a) of the amendment, but to add in (b) as though it is a savings provision is an invitation to any litigant, no matter how hopeless the case might be otherwise, to seek to have those sorts of criteria taken into account despite overwhelming evidence of the necessity to make a firm decision. I think we are all acutely aware of the political and other pressures to which a Minister can be subject. The last thing we want is to find compassionate pleas being made to a whole range of decision makers which are, in effect, contrary to the bulk of the evidence. I simply cannot support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This proposal opens up the area of discretion. In listening to Senator Jenkins tonight, firstly, one would think that that power in the Act, which gives the Minister the ultimate right to intervene in favour of the client, was not there. Secondly, it presumes that all regulations will be written without flexibility. But the point should be made that the subjective discretion relies on the objects of the Act, which appear nowhere in the Act. That is one of the problems we would face if this amendment were carried. It would mean that the Government, firstly, would lose control of its immigration program. Secondly, the selection criteria on regulations would be virtually redundant. Thirdly, it would be very hard to administer the legislation. Under this clause any decision maker can justify any decision, however unwise and uninformed, and indeed, however corrupt. Officers could be paid money to use this clause. There would be no comeback if they were paid money to let someone in. So, firstly, it knocks over straw persons who are not there, and, secondly, it would make the whole Act redundant because the amendment would insert overriding criteria. It makes the rest of the criteria a waste of time.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the difficulties I always have in these matters is people saying to me, `You only do the compassionate cases'. I must say that I have hardly dealt with an immigration case, out of the thousands I have dealt with, that has not had in it an element of compassion. That is part of the difficulty. So the Government strongly opposes this particular amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Alston and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs overestimate people, to a certain extent. People do appeal on compassionate grounds. If the Minister were to look at the statistics he would find that by far the vast majority of cases involve people who seek to come to Australia on a family reunion basis. We must all realise that every time we bring in a migrant on a skills basis, or on a business migration basis, or whatever, we are setting up moral, ethical and extremely difficult decisions for ourselves. Once we accept people, they are here. To deny such people the right to stay in Australia, based on circumstances which, as I stated in my amendment, would be manifestly unfair, unjust and oppressive, is extraordinary. This country takes in migrants, and migrants are people. I realise that the Government and the Opposition are not in favour of this amendment, which is headed `Fairness in Decisions', but many Australians will be disappointed by that decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not want it to be thought that somehow we are taking a callous approach. I would have thought that the fairest possible approach that one can take in setting the rules of the game is to have them written in such a way that they are understood in advance. To me, it is the height of inefficiency to have a system that depends ultimately upon the length of the chancellor's foot. In other words, it is in the eye of the beholder as to what is manifestly unfair, unjust and oppressive. That is a system that invites everyone to say that his case is somehow special and compassionate. As a result of this sort of proposal we would never be able to make objective judgments; everything would be relative.

SPEECH.PARA: In my experience everyone is able to come up with some element of sympathy and compassion when presenting a case. I have never come across a criminal case, for example, where something cannot be said in favour of the accused. If he is that bad he must be insane. That is an excuse in itself. It does not help at all to somehow suggest that fairness in decision-making has to involve subjective assessments. In our view fairness is best arrived at in the interests of the community and the speed of the justice delivered by having a set of rules that are clear, well understood and able to be objectively applied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Compassion! I do not wish to speak on any of the other Australian Democrats amendments unless I am really provoked. I rise, firstly, because Senator Jenkins said that this was a most significant amendment amongst those listed by her. Secondly, in her speech in the second reading debate she placed a great deal of emphasis upon the word `compassion'. I happen to agree entirely with all that Senator Robert Ray and my colleague Senator Alston have said. I happen to hold the view that all of us in the chamber place great significance upon compassion and the relevance of compassion, as those preceding me have said, in most decisions relating to immigration. It would be entirely wrong for anyone to purport that, because this particular Democrat amendment is being opposed by the rest of us in this chamber, there is any want of compassion on our part.

SPEECH.PARA: The analogy that comes to mind and illustrates why I disagree with the way Senator Jenkins put this principle as a foundation point of her speech on the second reading debate is the analogy that amongst the churches in Australia we occasionally get a warmhearted person saying, `Theology doesn't matter, only love'. It is as if that kind of appeal to love-or in this case, appeal to compassion-were so pre-eminent and self-evident to everyone participating in any decision that we did not need any other kind of definition at all. That is not the experience of the churches in this country. It is found to be the case that in determining questions of decision in churches, or in any advice about ethical matters or moral advice, a whole series of matters ought to be defined and logically applied.

Without carrying that analogy too far let it be made very clear that the Opposition supports the view that there needs to be defined policies by the elected government of the day and for those policies to be set forth from time to time in regulations under this Act. Every word of those regulations is important. It is superficial to think that we can, without the need of any of those particular regulations, just rely upon compassion, wisdom or fairness. Without making any more of a meal of it, without conceding one jot to anyone who would decry those not supporting this Democrat amendment, and whilst accepting that we all place a great weight upon sensible compassion, we should accept that there must be regulations and that the decision-making under the immigration legislation of this country should be on the basis of the whole of the regulations and policies of the elected government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HAINES
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs a real life example and ask him how it would be dealt with under this legislation. In 1982 under the Fraser Government the immigration laws were fairly strictly controlled. From memory, Ian Macphee was the then Minister for Immigration. I was approached by an Iranian female who was out here under the overseas student scheme. She was requesting permanent residence here. She had been turned down by the Department and was quite distraught for a fairly simple reason-that is, she had come out here when the Shah was still in power. She was due to return to her country of origin after the Ayatollah took control of that country. She was therefore probably the worst type of person in the eyes of the new ruler of that country-a Western educated female. Her chances of survival if she had been returned to Iran were somewhere between Buckley's and none.

SPEECH.PARA: Between the efforts of my office and her attempts, the Minister exercised whatever discretion he had under the Act as it stood in 1982 to grant her exemption from the normal requirement that applies to people who come here under that overseas student program; that is, the requirement that they return to their country of origin and put into effect for the benefit of that country the skills and education that they have developed in this country. It is a part of our overseas aid program. What would happen in a case like that under the legislation that the Minister has before him if there was no discretionary element on the grounds of fairness, justice and compassion when we have a situation caused not by a change in this country but by a change in another country that leaves somebody vulnerable under a scheme that to all intents and purposes should require them to return but which puts them in jeopardy if they do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hardly a unique case that Senator Haines has put to me because I have had to deal with a number of such cases already along similar lines. The example the honourable senator raises concerns the eligibility to apply for a change of status given changed circumstances. The circumstances in this case would be under section 6a of the current Act which will transpose in the next Act under refugee status. I do not think the example has to be anywhere near as stark as the one Senator Haines raised. She has brought up an automatic case that can be dealt with under the old Act and under the new Bill.
—It took three months last time.

—A change of status for refugee cases takes three months. In the meantime there is no action taken to repatriate, or anything else. In terms of the events that have occurred in Sri Lanka on occasions and in Fiji and elsewhere in the world-and maybe in China-where there are changed circumstances back home which places that person in a refugee status, of course that overrides any other provision that the person has to be returned home. Each case is dealt with individually as in this case, not as a class of people.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said before, direct ministerial intervention depends on two matters. The first is the degree of flexibility written into regulations. It would only be a stupid department which would have no flexibility because that would up the appeal rate and the cost. The second is the residual power retained in the Act to say that if a person has an appeal, via the two-tier appeal mechanism, the Minister may intervene in that person's favour. If this were not a refugee matter, but another matter, Senator Haines may have advised her constituent to go through the appeal process and, if unsuccessful, bring the case to me and say, `Look, there are special circumstances'. The only proviso to make sure Ministers actually look after the genuine cases is that I, or my successor as the Minister, has to put the reasons down in Parliament for that decision. He does not have to name the person. It is very much like Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions in criminal deportation cases. He has to say why it was in the public interest to do so. So I would argue that there is ample provision in the new legislation and the proposed regulations to cover that case, but that is an easy one in which a result can almost be guaranteed. There are much more difficult cases to decide involving, for instance, illness, as the honourable senator would know from her electorate office work.

It is a bit of a straw man to say that, under the new legislation, there will be absolute inflexibility in decision-making. Nobody is proposing that. There will be a degree of flexibility. If this amendment is adopted, every other criterion-points system included will go out the window, because it is up to an officer to decide what is unjust and what is oppressive. If that officer had been given $5,000 in his pocket, he would still be entitled to make that decision and could not be challenged under the amendment, even though he agreed corruptly to issue a migrant visa. This totally redefines. As I said before, if we leave a loophole in the legislation it will not be a case of a few individuals diving through it; it will be tens of thousands within a few weeks.

Unfortunately, that is always a problem with immigration. An attempt is made to have one big, fair hurdle which people jump over to get into the country. If I may continue with the hurdle analogy, if the hurdle is lower at one end than at the other, some people get an advantage, and we do not seek to do that. It is very wrong to provide that the Minister or the Department cannot intervene. Many cases are fixed up in the Department and will be able to be fixed up under this new legislation, where commonsense prevails. The last thing the Department and the Minister want to do is to send people back to their deaths.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 13, subclause 6 (1), proposed subsection 11a (8), at end of proposed subsection, add ``, provided that a reasonable person in the same circumstances would have known or suspected that the document was a bogus document''.

(4) Page 13, subclause 6 (1), proposed subsection 11a (9), at end of proposed subsection, add ``, provided that a reasonable person in the same circumstances would have known or suspected that the information was false or misleading in a material particular''.

(5) Page 13, subclause 6 (1), proposed subsection 11a (10), at end of proposed subsection, add ``, provided that a reasonable person in the same circumstances would have known or suspected that the information was false or misleading in a material particular''.

These amendments are certainly very tight and are certainly in keeping with what Senator Alston was talking about earlier. They relate to the clause headed `Circumstances in which non-citizens may become illegal entrants'. At the bottom of page 12 and on page 13 of the Bill, there appears:
``(8) A reference in this section to a person producing, or causing to be produced, a bogus document . . . whether or not the person knew that the document was a bogus document.

``(9) A reference to a person producing, or causing to be produced, a passenger card containing information that was false or misleading . . . whether or not the person knew that the information contained in it was false or misleading in a material particular.

``(10) A reference . . . to a person making, or causing to be made, a statement that was false or misleading . . . whether or not the person knew that the statement was false or misleading in a material particular.

Those additions about whether or not the person knew that the document or information was true or false go against the laws of intent in this country. The amendments add, after the `whether or not' clauses, the words, `provided that a reasonable person in the same circumstances would have known or suspected that the document was a bogus document' in the first amendment; `that the information was false or misleading in a material particular' in the second case; and `that the information was false or misleading in a material particular' in the third case.

The amendments soften the strict liability element of the subclauses by providing that an applicant cannot be penalised for the production of a bogus document or false or misleading information if the applicant could not have reasonably been expected to be aware that the document or the information was false. Without these qualifications there is a possibility of a great injustice being done to individuals. While it is important to prevent fraud, it is plainly foolish, in doing so, to go to the extreme of penalising those unwittingly responsible for tendering documents which are known to be false. Of course, that can happen and I am sure that Minister Ray could give us examples of it. I do not propose to speak at length to these amendments. I have made my point. As I said before, as the proposed subsections stand, they go against the basic tenets of the laws of justice in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I provide the following information. The courts have long held that it is not necessary to provide that a person who entered Australia with a forged passport knew that the passport was forged, nor is it necessary to prove that a person who provided a false material statement in a passenger card knew that the statement was false. This was affirmed by the full Federal Court in Naumovska v. the Minister, 5 Australian Law Reports, 357. The provision in proposed subsection 11a (9) restates the position in relation to proof in the body of the legislation to avoid any doubt in relation to this critical fall-back provision. It is misleading, in our view, to suggest that the provision intends to catch unknowing innocents. Such unknowing innocents would have no difficulty in establishing their entitlement to an entry permit.

SPEECH.PARA: As is the case with many other suggested amendments, we are moving from objectivity to subjectivity equals litigation equals long delays. Whenever there is a choice, objective criteria are much better than subjective criteria because not everyone has the same subjective approach to matters. In this case I would very strongly argue a subjective view of what is a reasonable person. All of those things create enormous difficulties and make this provision unworkable, in my view.
Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins, do you wish to take amendment No. 6 by itself?

—Before I do that, I have not sought to move amendments to the transitional provisions relating to Christmas Island, which are on page 14 of the Bill. If it is in order, I seek to ask the Minister a question about that clause.
—We should proceed in the order set out on the list of Democrat amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Page 14, subclause 6 (1), after proposed section 11c, insert the following new section in proposed Division 1:
Notice of deportation

`` `11ca. In spite of section 5J, a person who gives the Secretary a section 11A notice may not be deported until 28 days have elapsed since the day on which the person was given a notice stating that:
(a) he or she is to be deported; and
(b) setting out the details of his or her rights to seek review of the decision.'.''.

This amendment relates to the notice of deportation and seeks to insert a new subsection 11ca. Under the provisions of the legislation as it stands, a person becomes an illegal entrant upon entering Australia illegally and, 28 days later, automatically becomes subject to the mandatory deportation provisions. A person who has gone beyond the 28-day period of grace is debarred from making a change of status application and deportation is automatic.

Inevitably, some people will become illegal entrants through ignorance, misadventure or the actions of others. Some illegal entrants may well have experienced a significant change of personal circumstances subsequent to their illegal entry. Many of the currently estimated 100,000 illegal entrants fall into such categories. Some of them have been here for many years and may well be admired members of the community. Under the Government provisions, all such people, whether they have children or grandchildren here, or whatever, would be mandatorily deported at great cost to themselves or to the taxpayer and at the cost of great dislocation in some cases to their relatives here. This amendment provides for the 28-day clock to start ticking, not on the date of entry but only when such persons are notified that they are illegal entrants and subject to deportation, and are further notified that they have a right of appeal. The vibes I have are that everyone here wants everything strictly and neatly tied up. This amendment would not untie anything. It states:
. . . a section 11a notice may not be deported until 28 days have elapsed since the day on which the person was given a notice stating that:
(a) he or she is to be deported; and
(b) setting out the details of his or her rights to seek review of the decision.'.''.
This amendment seeks not to deny people, even illegals, basic human rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me clear up one serious misapprehension under which Senator Jenkins is operating: once a person is apprehended he may immediately apply for change of status. It is not true to say that he has no other choice. At that stage of being apprehended, he may apply. I think that cuts the ground from under a lot of the amendment. I think the 28-day period gives people a reasonable balance. It will encourage people to regularise their status in that time. It is a provision that very few other countries offer people in their own country. I think it provides a quite reasonable balance. I reiterate that a person may apply immediately upon apprehension. Whilst that decision is not reviewable, that course of action still remains open to the person who has been apprehended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens to a person who chooses to become scarce? In that situation presumably a notice cannot be given to the person and the stay of execution would be delayed indefinitely. I also wonder what the purpose of the exercise is. If a person is given a section 11a notice in the first instance, it would not seem to be asking too much for that person to be made aware of his or her rights to seek a review of any ultimate decision. Indeed, one would expect such a person to be acutely aware that time is limited and that deportation is imminent. In those circumstances it seems odd that the intention is to somehow freeze the process before formally advising the person of his or her rights. If those rights are made known to the person at the outset-one could almost assume that the person will be made aware of them-I do not see why one would want to hold up the process beyond the 28-day period.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 15, subclause 6 (1), proposed subsection 11d (4), line 7, leave out ``The conditions'', insert ``Subject to subsection (5), the conditions''.
(8) Page 15, subclause 6 (1), at end of proposed subsection 11d (4), add the following new subsection:
`` `(5) Subsection (4) applies only in regard to the visa of a person who is a passenger on a pre-cleared flight declared by the Minister for the purposes of section 9.'.''.
(11) Page 19, subclause 6 (1), proposed subsection 11p (4), line 35, leave out ``The conditions'', insert ``Subject to subsection (5), the conditions''.
(12) Page 20, subclause 6 (1), after proposed subsection 11d (4), add the following new subsection:
`` `(5) Subsection (4) applies only in regard to the temporary entry permit of a person who is a passenger on a pre-cleared flight declared by the Minister for the purposes of section 9.'.''.
Amendment No. 7 is a technical amendment to make way for amendment No. 8. Amendment No. 8 reads:
Subsection (4) applies only in regard to the visa of a person who is a passenger on a pre-cleared flight declared by the Minister for the purposes of section 9.'.''.

The Government is reported to have indicated informally that the provisions of the section will apply only where Australia has entered into specific arrangements with other countries to facilitate group travel for tourism. But as the Bill is worded it could be applied to any type of visa. This amendment seeks to restrict the operation of the section to group travel for tourism on pre-cleared flights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This section does not apply just to pre-cleared flights. I make the point that in the long term we will seek bilateral agreements, but they are not yet in place. That may take some time. If the clauses are not in operation, a lot of expensive equipment will remain idle. I find it very hard to follow the purpose of the amendment.

—We were given to understand in talks that that was the intention of subclause (4) on page 15 of the Bill. Is it not the intention that that subclause will be restrictive in that way? Could the Minister say how extensively that is to be applied?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The clause will facilitate tourism. Demand is increasing enormously. If we are able to issue restrictive visas, the clause makes new relaxed procedures available to process the visas. We are processing two million visas a year at the moment. We have a desire, of course, to remain a visaed country. Those countries which have introduced a visa-free system have ended up with a disaster-three-hour waits at airports, et cetera. I argue that our visa system is much better. Immigration clearance can take no longer than 70 seconds, coming down to 45 seconds at the end of the year. I interpolate that if only baggage could be cleared that quickly, we would be much better off.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 17, subclause 6 (1), proposed section 11g, lines 3 to 5, leave out the proposed section, insert the following section:
Cancellation of visas
`` `11g. Subject to the other provisions of this Act, the Minister may cancel a valid visa if to do so would be in the public interest.'.''.

(15) Page 24, subclause 6 (1), after proposed paragraph 11zd (1) (c), insert the following new paragraph:

(16) Page 24, subclause 6 (1), proposed paragraph 11zd (i) (d), line 12, leave out ``he or she is the holder of a valid temporary entry permit and''.
(17) Page 24, subclause 6 (1), after proposed paragraph 11zd (1) (g), add the following new paragraph:
`` `(h) he or she:
(i) is not the holder of a valid temporary entry permit; and
(ii) there are strong compassionate or humanitarian grounds for the grant of a permanent entry permit to the non-citizen; and
(iii) to grant a permanent entry permit would avoid manifest unfairness, injustice and oppression, while not being otherwise inconsistent with the objects of this Act.'.''.

With regard to amendment No. 9, the Government's declared intention is to remove wide and untrammelled discretionary provisions. The legislation gives the Minister absolute discretion to cancel a valid visa. This appears to be counter to the Government's declared intention and opens the way for a Minister to make a decision on political considerations. It is also possibly legally, and definitely morally, questionable because the days when Ministers were empowered to exercise absolute discretion without challenge or scrutiny by the Parliament, have passed. This amendment provides that the Minister must have grounds for cancelling a valid visa and such a decision would become subject to challenge. If the reason that the Minister must give for cancelling a visa is in the public interest, it can be a challengeable matter. I suggest that in those circumstances it should be challengeable. The amendment adds the following words to the legislation:
Subject to the other provisions of this Act, the Minister may cancel a valid visa if to do so would be in the public interest.

I believe that would take away some of the untrammelled discretionary possibilities that the Minister has at present. Amendments 10 and 13 are very similar. Amendment No. 10 adds the proposed subsection:
and such notice must specify the reasons, including any relevant statistical data for the direction.

So amendment No. 10 would require that, if the Minister proposes to stop the processing of applications for any particular class of visas, he or she must give reasons and provide any relevant statistical data to justify giving such a direction. Here again, without such provision, it remains open to a Minister to manipulate the composition of the migration intake, for political or other purposes, by opening or closing the various categories. There again, although our intentions are the same, perhaps we are simply looking at things from a different angle. As I said before, amendment Nos 12 and 13 are very similar to amendments Nos 9 and 10 and I would give similar reasons for their adoption. I will speak to Nos 9 and 10 initially.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a fairly well defined administrative law mosaic in this country. I think one can say that the concerns of Senator Jenkins would have been well founded prior to the mid 1970s but nowadays to vest what, on the face of it, appears to be an untrammelled discretion in fact is one that is very much subject to review by the courts. I think the view would be taken that a secretary could not arbitrarily or without good reason cancel a visa. That is as it ought to be. One does not want to arrive at a situation in which a decision can be made corruptly or capriciously. But to simply add the criterion of the public interest, to my mind, does not advance the case; indeed, it probably confuses it. As we all know, what is in the public interest is a matter of constant debate at all levels of society. I cannot for a moment imagine that that would be of any assistance to a court or to a secretary in determining whether the exercise of discretion was valid in the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: If the notice of reasons were a matter affecting an individual, I could understand it, although once again these days the rules of administrative law virtually require the provision of reasons. But where we are talking about a policy decision it is hard to imagine that a government could simply turn off the tap without explanation. I would have thought that the political process in this country would ensure that a Minister would have to give fairly persuasive and powerful reasons to the public at large in order to justify such a decision. Those reasons would undoubtedly involve the provision of any statistical data or numerical concern that the Minister might have. One would have thought that the Minister, in his own interests and those of the Government, would be fairly forthcoming before taking such a step. It just seems to me that to imagine that somehow a decision will be made and no reasons given is not a plausible situation. Although one can understand the basis for the concerns, I do not believe they are well founded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, the section on the cancellation of visas has been in the Act for some 20 years. I think it is essential that the powers be there to cancel someone's visa if indeed he or she has made false claims to get that visa and has not provided sufficient information. This sort of case comes to my attention every week and fairly sensationally, I suspect, will come to my attention later this week.
—Tell us about it.
—No, not yet. This happens quite often.
—A criminal like one in the Ananda Marga.

—Let us not speculate. Part of the other problem is the technical flaws in amendment No. 9. It makes the provision subject to the other provisions of the Act. It does not specify which provisions. That leaves enormous uncertainty. It also imports a test of public interest and Senator Alston has gone a long way into demolishing that. So I very strongly oppose amendment No. 9.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 10 is almost a case of locking the stable door after the horse has bolted. The need for capping and closure of categories under the new system is far less than it ever would have been under the old system. If one goes back to the response to Cape and looks at the material we have produced one sees that for the most part we have an overall cap to begin with, with some demand driven areas and the rest residual. It will be only in rare cases, for a short period, mostly possibly caused by change of status blowouts, that we will ever need to invoke this particular section. But I think it is important that it is in the Act so that what happened in 1987-88 never happens again, when the immigration program blew out month by month. The Government believes that the public announcement of the capping and the notification in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette must have sufficient provisions which are consistent with the public administration of the Commonwealth. Where appropriate, a ministerial statement will be made in Parliament explaining the reasons for taking such a step and the circumstances that led to it.

My comments on amendment No. 13 are really the same as those on amendment No. 9. In relation to amendment No. 14, we simply say that the Government believes that this is necessary to discourage people going underground. In relation to amendment No. 15, the Government wishes to put walls around the grant of resident status in Australia. The expansion of this program obviously prejudice orderly migration. It is one of the fastest growing areas of immigration. Amendment No. 16 seeks to expand a provision that is now in section 6a (1) (c). This provision has worked well. No person who obtained refugee status in Australia was disadvantaged by its current operation. Hence the need for it has not been established. Again, amendment No. 17 relates to replacing objectivity with subjectivity. I will not reiterate all the arguments as to why I prefer objective assessment rather than subjective assessment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the Minister's previous words about discretion and wanting it all tied up, I must reiterate that I find it incredible that the Committee may be happy to leave clause 11g on page 17 as it stands. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretary may at any time, in his or her absolute discretion, cancel a valid visa.
That is how it is worded-without any amendments or additions to that clause at all.

I will now speak to amendment No. 15. This particular addition has been requested in representations from very many ethnic communities. This amendment would extend the family reunion category to include brothers and sisters. Given that there are people who do not have any relatives in any other family reunion categories, it is appropriate that categories be extended in this way. As I said when I spoke earlier, it is widely recognised that migrants who already have a close relative resident in Australia are more likely to settle successfully and are less likely to become dependent on welfare and less likely to leave Australia, as some skilled and independent migrants do after a relatively short time here. So in fact this will help reunite many families without opening the door to a flood of dependent persons.

Similarly, amendment No. 16 provides that persons who have the status of a refugee cannot be deported on a technicality. I would be interested in hearing the Minister's comments on those two amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 15 states that if a brother or a sister is here the person can come in as priority family. There are a million brothers and sisters of Australians outside Australia. For a start, we do not have enough 747s to get them in here in the year in which this operates, because that is as long as it operates. It is demand driven, so there is no cap. It is absolutely impossible to accept amendment No. 15; I have not heard one ethnic group argue for such an amendment. I would like as much as possible to try to accommodate brothers and sisters, but no ethnic group wants a million brothers and sisters of present residents coming here in one year.
—Too right!

—I know that Senator McKiernan does not want them here for other reasons, but we will let him be. I can tell honourable senators that if this clause goes through I will do the right thing-I will just go into the library and pull the drawer out!

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Page 29, clause 8, proposed subsection 17a (3), line 7, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:
`` `(3) A deportation order made under this section may be revoked.'.''.
(19) Page 29, clause 8, after proposed subsection 17a (4), add the following new subsection:
`` `(5) Nothing in this section authorizes the deportation of a person who has the status of a refugee within the meaning of:
(a) the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees that was done at Geneva on 28 July 1951; or
(b) the Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees that was done at New York on 31 January 1967.'.''.
(20) Page 29, clause 8, after proposed section 18, add the following new section:
Voluntary departure of illegal entrants

`` `18aa. Before making a deportation order under section 17a or 18, the Minister must accede to a written request from the illegal entrant that he or she not be deported but be permitted to leave Australia voluntarily, under the supervision of the Minister, for an agreed destination.'.''.

It is a simple fact of life that mistakes are made-even by Ministers on occasions. I am sure that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs does not need to be reminded of the $5 arrival fee and the $240 impost for migration appeals. On both occasions the Australian Democrats put up amendments against both those provisions. I would also suggest that it is ludicrous to create a situation in which an obvious mistake cannot be corrected by providing that orders for deportation cannot be revoked-not by the Minister, the Appeals Tribunal or the courts. My amendment No. 18 provides for the sensible option of revoking decisions which may be found, after the event, to be incorrect. Amendment No. 18 proposes the insertion of the following subsection:
. . . A deportation made under this section may be revoked.
As the Bill stands at the moment, there is no possibility of the revocation of deportation orders because they are mandatory. It could well be that a mistake could be made.
Amendment No. 19 provides protection to ensure that bona fide refugees cannot be deported. In that amendment I propose to add a new subsection which says:
. . . Nothing in this section authorizes the deportation of a person who has the status of a refugee within the meaning of:
(a) the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees that was done at Geneva on 28 July 1951; or
(b) the Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees that was done at New York on 31 January 1967.
Of course, Australia is a signatory to both the convention and the protocol.

Amendment No. 20 relates to the voluntary departure of illegal entrants. As the Government has drafted its amendments, illegal entrants in Australia have to be deported; they do not have the option of leaving voluntarily. This is plainly unnecessarily aggressive and liable to be unnecessarily expensive. Amendment No. 20 would make it possible for illegals to leave voluntarily and of their own free will under the supervision of the Minister. The new subsection reads:

. . . Before making a deportation order under section 17a or 18, the Minister must accede to a written request from the illegal entrant that he or she not be deported but be permitted to leave Australia voluntarily, under the supervision of the Minister, for an agreed destination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 17a is planned to be the end of the road. There must be finality to the processes of selection. To add a discretionary power to revoke a mandatory order is, in my view, simply a nonsense. It defeats the purpose of the whole provision. A deportation order under section 18 can be revoked and is an auxiliary to section 17a. Of course 17a can be quashed by the Federal Court in an error of law. If an officer has signed an order based on a defective decision, it is open to the Federal Court to remit the case back for a fresh decision.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to amendment No. 20, the distinction must be made here between a right to go voluntarily and a practice. Quite clearly, if we have apprehended someone and that person says, `Look, I am leaving on tomorrow's plane, here is my ticket', we are not about to deport him. He can go voluntarily. If a person says, `I have $20,000 in my pocket. If you take me to the Qantas office I will buy a ticket and you can see me off tomorrow', there is no reason for us to deport him. Why should we pay for his air fare if he wants to leave? There is always that sort of flexibility. I suppose that these days if we deported all these people we would take part of that $20,000 to pay for their air tickets-and we would probably send them first class just to make sure they went home happily! In regard to amendment No. 20, I would not like to make it a right for a person to be able to volunteer to go because this would have all sorts of other consequences. But it is certainly a practical administrative matter. If a person volunteers to go, proves that he is going and we can arrange for him to leave, that person would always be allowed to go voluntarily rather than be deported. That is just common sense.

I have a note on amendment No. 19 which I wish to put on the record. It should be borne in mind that the protection of the convention and the authority to remain pursuant to the Migration Act are two distinct streams. While the two streams are joined at various places for the sake of administrative convenience, they are nonetheless separate and apart. There can be protection and asylum in Australia without the benefit of an entry permit. There are two provisions of the convention relating to the status of refugees which are relevant. The first is paragraph 1 of article 31, which reads:

The contracting States shall not impose penalties on account of their illegal entry or presence on refugees who, coming directly from a territory where their life or freedom was threatened in the sense of article 1, enter or are present in their territory without authorisation, provided that they present themselves without delay to the authorities and show good cause for their illegal entry or presence.
The second is article 33, which reads:

1. No contracting State shall expel or return a refugee in any manner whatsoever to frontiers or territories where his life or freedom would be threatened on account of his race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion.

2. The benefit of the present provision may not, however, be claimed by a refugee whom there are reasonable grounds for regarding as a danger to the security of the country in which he is or who, having been convicted by final judgment of a particularly serious crime, constitutes a danger to the community of that country.
The Bill allows a period of grace for a refugee claimant if he or she presents himself or herself without delay as required by article 31.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister saying what Senator Jenkins has in mind already applies, assuming that people come forward early and act in good faith? In this case I am referring to amendment No. 19.
—Does that relate to refugees?

—Yes, it does. Is the Minister saying that Senator Jenkins's amendment is unnecessary because there is already provision to allow refugees to remain in this country provided they act in good faith and come forward at the earliest possible opportunity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. This is provided for in section 6a (1) of the Migration Act.
—Although I was happy to debate these three amendments together, I would like a vote to be taken separately on amendment No. 19.
—There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed. The question is that amendments Nos 18 and 20 be agreed to.
—The question now is that amendment No. 19 be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Page 38, subclause 12 (1), proposed paragraph 21e (5) (a), at end of proposed paragraph, add ``provided that to do so does not cause undue and manifest hardship to the arrested person or any of his or her dependants, whether in Australia or otherwise.''.
(22) Page 40, paragraph 14 (a), proposed subsection 27 (1), line 8, leave out ``A non-citizen who'', insert ``Subject to subsection (1a), a non-citizen who''.
(23) Page 40, paragraph 14 (a), after proposed subsection 27 (1), add the following new subsection:

`` `(1a) Subsection (1) does not apply to a person who is a refugee or who has come directly from a territory where that person's life or freedom was threatened, and who has within the prescribed period of grace shown good cause for the illegal entry or presence.'.''.
(24) Page 41, paragraph 15 (a), proposed subsection 31a (1), line 21, leave out ``The Secretary may'', insert ``Subject to subsection (1a), the Minister may''.
(25) Page 41, paragraph 15 (a), after proposed subsection 31a (1), add the following new subsection:
`` `(1a) Nothing in this section authorizes the Minister to order a person to leave Australia if:
(a) that person has the status of a refugee within the meaning of:
(i) the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees that was done at Geneva on 28 July 1951; or
(ii) the Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees that was done at New York on 31 January 1967; or
(b) the requirement would constitute, or would lead to, a violation of Article 33 of the Convention or Protocol.'.''.

The paragraphs of clause 12 to which amendment No. 21 relates contain Government amendments giving unrestricted powers for the freezing of bank accounts and the seizing and disposing of property in order to recover the costs of detention and deportation, whether or not the property is disposed of on just terms, whether or not it is held jointly by the deportee and other quite possibly innocent persons, and whether or not innocent persons would be grossly disadvantaged by the freezing of bank accounts. My amendment would place just and reasonable constraints on the Minister and authorised officers in the exercise of what the Democrats consider to be quite draconian powers.

Amendment No. 22 is a technical amendment paving the way for amendment No. 23. Amendment No. 23, which would add a subsection, provides that individuals whose life or freedom is under threat in their country or territory of origin will be exempt from being declared illegal and deported, provided that they make application for change of status within the prescribed 28-day period of grace after their arrival in Australia. The subsection proposed by my amendment reads:

Subsection (1) does not apply to a person who is a refugee or who has come directly from a territory where that person's life or freedom was threatened, and who has within the prescribed period of grace shown good cause for the illegal entry or presence.

Amendment No. 24 is a technical amendment paving the way for amendment No. 25. Amendment No. 25 again provides protection for genuine refugees against their being required to leave Australia. It would insert the following new subsection (1a):
Nothing in this section authorises the Minister to order a person to leave Australia if:
(a) that person has the status of a refugee within the meaning of:
(i) the Convention . . .; or
(ii) the Protocol . . .; or
(b) the requirement would constitute, or would lead to, a violation of Article 33 of the Convention or Protocol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —When someone claiming refugee status enters the country, that is an illegal entry. However, the moment such a person is given refugee status, the entry is no longer illegal. It is as simple as that. I really do not see the point of the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (26) Page 42, after clause 17, insert the following new clauses:
Custody of prohibited non-citizen during stay of aircraft
``17a. Section 36a of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by inserting in subsection (5) ``, subject to this Act,'' after ``under subsection (4) shall''; and
(b) by omitting subsection (8).
Powers of entry and search
``17aa. Section 37, of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (3) and substituting the following subsection:
`(3) A magistrate or a justice of the peace may issue to an officer a search warrant in accordance with the prescribed form.'.''.

This amendment deals with custody of prohibited non-citizens during the stay of an aircraft. The Government has refused to take the opportunity to repeal section 36a of the Migration Act, which section creates a legal fiction by deeming that people have not entered Australia, even though they are physically present, if they have not been issued with an entry permit. The effect is that the right to seek entry on humanitarian grounds will continue to be unavailable to persons who make unsuccessful frontier applications for refugee status. Yet many people who fail to meet the onerous individual-persecution standard for refugee status can meet the still rigorous level of proof required for grant of residency on humanitarian grounds. Democrat amendment No. 26 would remove this legal fiction, which makes a mockery of the spirit of our international obligations to protect people fleeing from gross violations of their human rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that we are not going to have a long argument over section 36a. I am on public record as having said that it will be done away with over my dead body. To accommodate the honourable senator's amendment we would have to do something that the Canadians do-something that has turned out to be a total disaster. We would have to keep everyone at the airport, and the airport would have to be extended. It is not a fiction to deem that people have not entered Australia if they have come without papers or a visa and are put in a detention centre. That affects all their other appeal rights. While people in the United States and Canada condemn section 36a, the moment they are out of earshot they say, `Stick with it. I only wish we had it'. If we were to adopt Senator Jenkins's proposal, people would have to be given entry into Australia, giving them all legal and other rights, or kept at the airport. I do not know where they would be kept, unless we were to take over the car parks. I see the motive behind the amendment, but I do not think that Senator Jenkins has thought through its consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (27) Pages 50 and 51, clause 26, proposed section 61, line 37 (page 50) to line 12 (page 51), leave out the proposed section, insert the following sections:
Internal review of certain decisions

`` `61. In spite of any other provision of this Act, until the regulations provide otherwise, a decision under this Act, other than a decision of the Minister, must, on application by a person adversely affected by the decision, be reviewed by a review officer.
Review by the Tribunal

`` `61a. In spite of any other provision of this Act, until the regulations provide otherwise, a decision of a review officer or the Minister under this Act must, on application by a person adversely affected by the decision, be reviewed by the Tribunal.
Disallowance of part of a regulation

`` `61b. (1) In spite of any provision of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, but otherwise without prejudice to the operation of that Act, a House of the Parliament may pass a resolution disallowing part of a regulation made for the purposes of section 61 or 61a and the part so disallowed shall thereupon cease to have effect.
`` `(2) For the purposes of subsection (1) a reference to a part of a regulation includes a reference to any provision of, or words, figures, drawings or symbols in, a regulation.'.''.

This amendment relates to the review of decisions. Some improvements have been made in the legislation. The Government, by its own amendments, has made certain substitutions in proposed section 61. However, the Democrats have sought, all along the line, a further review of decisions. This amendment would leave the present two levels of review as proposed by the Government. The first level of review would be carried out by a review officer. We regard that as something that should be automatic after a decision within the Department. If the person comes back and says that the adding up has been done wrongly, or that a certain circumstance has not been taken into consideration, that review should automatically be reviewed internally.

The next level of review is that by the Immigration Review Tribunal. Although it is not what the Democrats recommended, as it has been proposed by the Government and agreed to by the Opposition we would be happy to leave that level of review in place. However, the Democrats are proposing a third level where there is a need for a further review. This review could be carried out by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It has been our proposition all along the line that if an initial application is made before staff who give full information to the prospective migrant about the likely number of points, and so on, and if there is then a proper review by a review officer, very often matters will not be taken any further. As I said before, it is really only the family reunion categories that proceed further. If people know where they stand-and here I agree with the Minister and with Senator Alston-it makes things easier for them. But if the procedures are so tight that people feel genuinely that they are disadvantaged, they will seek reviews, and the matter will go on and on. The proposal in amendment No. 27 is to leave out the Government's clause 61 and insert new clauses 61, 61a and 61b.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government totally opposes this proposal. It is pointless setting up and immediately enacting our internal review without the regulations. However, I do assure everyone that not only the second application review but the normal internal review will proceed until we can meld the two systems together. If the second suggestion of having a third tier appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) was to be carried I would sink the Bill. It would cost us $15m, by our estimation, maybe up to $18m. It is a terribly expensive process, especially given, as I indicated before, the leakage rate that occurs in the immigration area. That would make that untenable.

SPEECH.PARA: Even worse, it would mean that all decisions under the act would be appealable, including the two excluded categories of refugees and criminal deportations. This Government has a view that it is the ultimate arbiter on criminal deportations, subject to advice from the AAT but it is only advice. In regard to refugees, we have made it quite clear as Government policy that we will not allow the courts to reinterpret the 1951 convention or the 1967 protocols. If the courts did reinterpret the definition of `refugee', it may imperil the whole refugee program to Australia. It is a program that we can be proud of. We take eight per thousand of our population in refugees, which is the highest per capita intake of any Western country. To throw all that out on the whim of some ruling from a court is not really worth it.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins, amendment No. 28 has the effect of removing new subsections 62 (3) and (4) which have been inserted by Government amendment No. 60. Do you still wish to proceed with amendment No. 28?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I will not proceed with that amendment. I proceed to amendment No. 29. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (29) Page 52, clause 26, proposed subsection 64 (3), lines 8 to 10, leave out the proposed subsection.

The proposed subsection places an extreme and unwarranted restraint on the appeals process by providing that humanitarian grounds cannot be considered by a review authority in determining whether to grant an entry permit. This amendment seeks to delete that subsection. I add that it is disappointing that the Government has not accepted the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) as the third tier for appeals. With the AAT in place as a third level for appeals, a codified pattern of determination would emerge in a short time. I believe that that would tend to reduce the number of appeals that were made. It is to be hoped that a codified pattern will appear with the tribunal system, but I personally think that that is less likely to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For similar reasons to opposing amendment No. 27, I stress that `humanitarian' is not the classic definition of humanitarian taken out of the dictionary. It is a specific subsection of the refugee area. We would not seek at this stage to have that included in the Act. I point out that in another subsection of the Act it is possible to move into the reviewable areas that are not currently reviewable. It is not contemplated in the short term that this will move into that category, but I cannot ever preclude in the long term that it will be.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (30) Page 52, clause 26, proposed subsection 64b (1), line 32 (page 52) to line 4 (page 53), leave out the proposed subsection.
(31) Page 53, clause 26, proposed paragraph 64b (2) (a), line 9, leave out ``or'' (second occurring).
(32) Page 53, clause 26, proposed paragraph 64b (2) (b), leave out the proposed paragraph.

Proposed new subsection 64b (1) is headed `Some decisions not reviewable'. The Government's draft here prevents appeals in respect of quite crucial decisions. For reasons already stated, the Australian Democrats are not in agreement with that. The decisions which are not reviewable, according to the proposed legislation, are a decision made on an application for an entry permit, where the application was able to be made only because the person's circumstances had changed since the person had last made an application for an entry permit; a decision to cancel a visa or entry permit; a decision to order the deportation of a person; a decision by the Minister that a person does not have the status of refugee within the meaning of the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees, that was done at Geneva on 28 July 1951; or the Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees that was done in New York on 31 January 1967.

Amendment No. 31 is a technical amendment preparing for amendment No. 32. This relates to page 53, clause 26. This amendment deletes the paragraph, which is an unnecessary limitation and could be used to suppress a wide range of appeals. TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have one amendment to the Migration Amendment Bill 1989 and a contingent amendment if that amendment is not passed. The ostensible purpose of the slim Bill we have before us is to rescue the 1988 legislation from the specific flaw which has deterred the proclamation of that legislation and to enable the implementation of elements of the Government's master plan for passenger processing. It is a lightweight package. It rescues the tourist pre-clearance plan from postponement, pending full implementation of the database system on which it is supposed to be dependent. The Democrats agreed to accept the 1988 Bill when it was introduced. We accepted the Government's assurances that all was well. SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have moved amendments to the legislation because we believe the current Migration Amendment Bill 1989 is too wide in scope and it would provide unnecessary discretionary power to be exercised in a potentially non-accountable manner by instrument in writing. There is no limitation of the new power to the temporary circumstances for which it is claimed they are required. Our amendments would have two advantages. Firstly, they will cease to have effect when all the overseas posts are equipped with database access. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few general observations to make. The legislation introduced in 1988 dealt with two principal issues: visas that may operate as entry permits in certain defined circumstances, that is, entry visas; and preclearance of passengers overseas boarding certain direct flights to Australia. Entry visas as such are not related to precleared flights. Most passengers carrying entry visas will not travel on precleared flights though preclearance of flights cannot be implemented without entry visas.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1988 legislation cannot validly be said to have failed. Owing to the necessary administrative preparations, it is yet to commence. The need for amendments arose out of technical difficulties in introducing a worldwide network and the obvious need to provide for ongoing contingency plans in the case of computer equipment failure or data communication breakdown. If the Bill is enacted, both the 1988 Act and this Bill will commence on 1 July 1989, thus the Bill is separated from the major Bill we have been considering. Senator Jenkins said last year that the Australian Democrats intended to monitor the results closely over the first year or two of its operation. If that is so, there is a rush to judgment in calling the 1988 Act a failed measure ahead of its commencement.

I now turn to the first amendment. The concept of an entry visa operating as an entry permit on entry to Australia at the proclaimed airport is premised on data relating to the issue of a visa being available at the entry point at the time the holder seeks to enter Australia. It is also essential that the entry visa document be readily identifiable by all persons as one which is capable of operating as an entry permit. Our original legislation formulation anticipated the installation of necessary equipment to permit widespread application of the concept from the date the Act was proclaimed.

While equipment is in place at overseas missions which now enables some 90 per cent of visas to be machine issued, and we are progressively installing equipment to transfer the visa data to Australia and to facilitate entry processes, it will be some time before 100 per cent coverage is achieved. The Government does not want to delay the benefits to productivity and passenger facilitation which are achievable from those systems which are already in place and has decided to provide the legislative amendments to permit this. Hence the provision for the Minister to determine by instrument that the visa entry permit concept will apply only to those visas granted in a specific manner or form, that is, where computer based visa issue equipment is installed overseas and data links established to Australia.

The amendment proposed by the Democrats seeks simply to focus on a prerequisite for a person's visa record being held in a notified database. The amendment contains no provision to link that record to a specific form of visa so that the passenger, the carrier or an officer at the airport can recognise that visa as being an entry visa. It would thus be most difficult for persons to differentiate between what is an entry visa and what is not.

While the proposal may be seen to be consistent with our broad approach, it will be extremely complicated to administer and prone to confusion. We seek to ensure that the procedures to apply to the visa entry permit system are as uncomplicated as possible, especially at entry points in Australia, whilst maintaining the necessary disciplines. The legislation and the Government's Bill meet those requirements. The amendment proposed by the Democrats would deny the Government the opportunity progressively to achieve the benefits flowing from the new visa issue and entry processes I have outlined. It would also place the Government at a disadvantage in facilitating the burgeoning tourist growth to Australia. I am therefore not able to accept the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it not be simpler for the airports that have a database to use the database, and those that do not to continue to use the present system until they can hook on to the database? Why is that not possible?
