SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In beginning the debate on this package of Bills which were introduced into the chamber on 23 May and which are being taken together, I notice that the only Government speaker listed to debate this important issue is the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is at the bottom of the list and presumably will summarise for the Government. That indicates the lack of care and attention that the Government is giving to the question of superannuation and indeed the important question of the need to encourage savings, particularly with the figures that have come out this week.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate is also quite belated. It follows a press release which is some 12 months old, and we have reached the stage where perhaps we ought to be asking for sunset clauses to be built into press releases so that if legislation is not brought in within a reasonable time the whole thing lapses because of the confusion that is introduced into the community at large and also because legislation, when it finally comes before the Parliament, can often be introduced in a totally different climate and something that may have been relevant 12 months ago may no longer be so.

There never has been a more appalling example of Labor's arrogant record of legislation by press release than this package. The Government having finally tabled the complete package following three Bills in November 1988, this is one of the most complex packages of Bills on record, yet the Government has allowed totally inadequate time for scrutiny of the Bills either by the industry or by the poor superannuant, the person who is most affected. Because of the inordinate delays and confusion, some in the industry will be inclined to panic and accept anything while other cooler heads will have only a few days to assess the proposed legislation which the great minds of Treasury took a year to complete.
A good example of how that has occurred is the press release of LIFA, the Life Insurance Federation of Australia Inc., which was published on 5 May:
Although LIFA remains opposed to the taxation of superannuation, it is critically important that the legislation now proceeds to finality as soon as possible.

Whilst the life insurance industry, therefore, welcomes the introduction of the legislation into Parliament, and urges its speedy passage, we, nevertheless, need an opportunity to comment to ensure that the legislation resolves the uncertainties and does not produce unintended consequences.

That is in contradistinction to the expressions of concern that have come from the rest of the industry somewhat later than 5 May. For instance, on 23 May, the Life Underwriters Association of Australia Ltd wrote that it remained:
. . . deeply concerned over the potential impact of the proposed taxation arrangements, outlined in this Bill, on the attractiveness of superannuation as an investment option.
A most important paragraph in this letter written to me on 23 May reads:
We urge you to disregard calls from some sections of the life insurance industry, for the immediate passage of this Bill, regardless of its faults, in order to avoid administrative inconvenience.

That is quite an important aspect. People who have issued press releases commenting upon the unacceptable nature of this legislation include the Chairman of Trustees of the superannuation funds sponsored by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Mr Rogers, the Chairman, speaking on behalf of 42,000 members of the company-sponsored scheme, referring to the legislation said:
. . . administratively very complex and unnecessarily burdensome . . .
. . . impacts harshly on Private Sector sponsored superannuation funds in comparison with Public Sector . . .

On all these grounds, the Government is urged to withdraw its present tax proposals on superannuation funds and revisit the issue, if necessary, only when it has established an appropriate retirement income policy which will serve this country well into the 21st century.
A letter from another outspoken and concerned superannuation group, the Coles Myer Superannuation Funds, simply states:

The Treasurer has, on a number of occasions, commented that superannuation funds will be able to reduce the actual tax liability by increasing their exposure to Australian equity shares paying fully franked dividends. This simplistic approach fails to recognise that:

many superannuation funds invest in `capital guaranteed' funds which have a very high fixed interest component (for which there is no imputation tax relief). The majority of retirees below age 65 `roll over' their retirement benefit into a capital guaranteed or fixed interest Approved Deposit Fund.
Clearly those employees and retirees for whom security of capital is paramount will be adversely affected by the proposed tax on fund ADF earnings.
It concludes:

I believe that the proposed tax on super fund investment income has adverse consequences that far outweigh the revenue that will be received. I urge you to press the Government for the withdrawal of the tax on investment income. At the very least the passage of this part of the legislation should be deferred pending the release, and consideration of, the Government's statement on retirement incomes which is due to be made next month.

Clearly the industry is concerned at the effects of this package of Bills. When we reach the committee stage I will move amendments which will seek to excise the 15 per cent tax on investment income payable in the hands of the funds. I think it is most important that we look at the taxation points that this Government has now imposed on superannuation and on superannuants and realise that since this Government came to office the tax take from the superannuation industry-and that is out of the pockets of people who have invested in it as a savings method for their old age-has increased by 1,000 per cent.

Let us look at the four tax points to which superannuation is subject via this package. There is a 15 per cent tax on employer contributions to public and private sector superannuation funds. There is a 15 per cent tax on superannuation fund income, and this is the major concern that we have. There is the 16.25 per cent tax, which includes the Medicare levy, on lump sums over $60,000. In this instance we will seek, by amendment in the committee stage, to raise that sum to $125,000. There is the capital gains tax on assets bought and sold by superannuation funds after 1 July 1988. This package, after six years of constant change, has resulted in 20 major changes to superannuation law in six years. I refer to the raising of the 1983 lump sum tax to 31.25 per cent from the previous figure of 5 per cent and the bringing forward of the three super taxes in the 1988 May statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those figures are not even comparable.

—While we have had these tremendous alterations to the superannuation industry, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has sought to mislead the public and, indeed, prefers to enjoy the fleshpots of Europe and to look at the interesting architecture of Moscow instead of being here to deal with this country's economic plight which the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), as well as Senator Button, have admitted to. The Minister's embarrassment cannot be done away with simply by interjecting. At the time of the 1988 press release, of which this legislation is the embodiment, the Treasurer said that three things were important:

SPEECH.PARA: The taxation of superannuation benefits is to be radically yet sympathetically changed, putting it on a more logical long-term basis without reducing lump sum and pension entitlements.
He then said:
Together these changes complete the Government's review of superannuation tax arrangements. People can now plan their retirement with complete certainty and confidence.

He said that this would allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money. The theory was that the money would be payable at the end when somebody actually got a benefit from the superannuation savings plan, but the Government claims that that is its money and it is entitled to have it up front, long before the benefit is enjoyed. It was stated that that money is now lying in superannuation funds. He said, further, that he would make these changes without diminishing any personal end benefit by one cent.

Let me give one very specific factual example of how people who had been looking forward to enjoying superannuation payments can be disadvantaged. A longstanding employee was recently paid in the vicinity of $100,000 by his employer on termination of his employment in consideration of his past service. He is aged in his mid-40s. Under the existing tax regime that would be an eligible termination payment on which the tax rate would have been 30 per cent. On the advice of his accountant he rolled over the payment to an approved deposit fund (ADF). The trustee of the fund, in anticipation of the passage of the proposed legislation, deducted 15 per cent tax from the amount paid into the approved deposit fund. As such, an unfunded benefit, when paid into an ADF, is a taxable contribution as proposed by new section 274 (1) (a). If he now called for the benefit remaining to be paid to him, the tax rate and the resulting eligible termination payment would be 27 per cent under the proposed legislation, with a total tax take of 42 per cent. Under the existing tax regime the tax payable would have been 30 per cent only on the eligible termination payment when payment of the roll-over benefit was paid to him from the approved deposit fund. It is quite clearly not true that nobody will be worse off under this legislation. At the very minimum the anti-detriment provision in proposed section 270ca should apply to persons of all ages.

Another important aspect of this package deals with the public administration implications. There had been a move by a majority of States to make their superannuation schemes funded-that is, to make this generation fund the superannuation schemes and not leave it to the next generation. That is sensible, good management and planning, but it has been well and truly killed off by the Treasurer's 15 per cent tax package. Queensland announced on the 25th of this month that it had moved quietly to change the arrangements to fund its superannuation scheme. At the end of the last session of the Queensland Parliament the Government passed retrospective legislation abolishing the State's separate super funds, making all contributions in and out from Consolidated Revenue; that is, Queensland's super schemes are now unfunded. The 15 per cent tax on contributions and earnings applies only to funded schemes. The change also removes the parliamentary superannuation schemes for members of parliament from any potential exposure to the same 15 per cent tax.

At the recent Premiers Conference the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) undertook to write to all States concerning the application of the new income tax provisions to State Public Service superannuation schemes and, as a result, other States which had expressed interest, such as South Australia, the Northern Territory and others, have opted out from funding those superannuation schemes. It is well to remember that it can occur: schemes can fail, as happened in New York when it came close to bankruptcy. What would happen if the private sector suddenly decided that it would be more interested in looking at unfunded schemes. It is undermining the solidarity and the acceptability of a concept of something that has been regarded as a very safe investment.

The coalition has constantly stated that our attitude is that all legislation in this area should be predicated on two things: first, the need for the Treasurer's promise that no individual would be disadvantaged by 1c to be met; and, secondly, the need to ensure that the level of tax will not become a disincentive to superannuation savings. At this very moment we are seeing the effect of the rundown in savings of this country. We have these problems because we do not have a good savings ratio. Yet this package of Bills is designed as a disincentive to savings. Quite clearly, as our population ages, as more and more people are required to be supported in a period of their lives when they will not be in the paid work force, if we are to have a satisfactory situation we need to attract more people into the scheme.

Quite simply, the people who need to be attracted into superannuation are the people on the lower marginal rates. Accordingly, with the Government's personal tax cuts in the April statement, it is clear that the comparative attractiveness of superannuation under Labor's new tax regime has been diminished for those people on lower marginal rates. It is particularly interesting to observe and to note that only 39 per cent of people in the private sector are in superannuation schemes. In the public sector-I remind honourable senators that those are the schemes which are unfunded-some 67 per cent of people are covered by superannuation. Of course, there are another million people who are covered by the 3 per cent productivity funds. Those funds are largely invested in fixed interest fund investments.

It is interesting to note that two people of tremendously diverse political leanings have come to a similar conclusion. I will quote Mr Gary Weaven, the Assistant Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), and Professor Michael Porter, both of whom spoke, on 15 May, at a seminar dealing with superannuation and incomes policy. Professor Michael Porter said:
Further, the present taxation of superannuation and means testing of the government pension significantly penalises many Australians saving for their own retirement relative to spending income today.
Mr Weaven said:
The fact is that to get people to prefer a lump sum or income stream to current cash in hand requires a very major incentive.
Speculation and uncertainty about future government policy in the area only increase the preference for current cash rather than preserved savings.
Mr Weaven, the Assistant Secretary of the ACTU, also said:
. . . ultimately, pay as you go . . . superannuation will inevitably apply universally at a significant level.
That argument he rejects. He continued:

We must ask ourselves what would bring about the substantial future development of superannuation. After all, even after the successful completion of the ACTU's campaign the majority of workers will only have coverage at the level of 3% of ordinary-time earnings-in many cases as little as $9 or $10 per week.

As I said earlier, our main concern is on the 15 per cent tax on investment income. The two amendments that we will move to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 will relate to this. The critical element in the Government's taxation policy package is the allowance of imputed tax credits to offset the nominal 15 per cent tax on fund earnings. According to the Treasurer, the superannuation funds can bring the 15 per cent nominal tax on earnings down to a lower effective rate of 4 per cent only by pushing more of its investments into the stock market shares in Australian companies which return fully franked dividends. The interesting thing is that approximately only 25 per cent of investment in roll-over funds and in approved deposit funds (ADFs) will have any connection to the market. The size of that investment is now in the vicinity of $12 billion.

There is a wide variety of reasons why superannuation funds, with the exception of large funds such as the Australian Mutual Provident Society, do not hold a greater proportion of their assets in equities. Principal among that is that the value of shares is subject to wide and unpredictable fluctuation over time. Those funds holding roll-over funds and approved deposit funds are the ones where a more conservative investment line is taken and investment in the stockmarket is not sought. That similarly applies to the union based superannuation funds or the 3 per cent productivity funds, where the contributions come mainly from employers and of course are usually capital guaranteed. Therefore, the funds that will have to pay the 15 per cent tax on employer contributions across a wider base than other funds will be severely disadvantaged by their lack of access to the offsetting imputation credits. In other words, we have fish and fowl. Those people in the more conservative investment funds will be disadvantaged because of the 15 per cent tax on those investment earnings in the hands of the fund.

The coalition believes that the imposition of the 15 per cent fund income does reduce people's end benefit, not only in ADFs and roll-over funds but also in normal superannuation funds. Mr Connolly, in his speech in the House of Representatives, dealt very adequately with examples of classes of people in various age groups who are disadvantaged and who will continue to be disadvantaged by this package of Bills. Thus, there is a high incidence of losers, which demonstrates that the promise that the Treasurer made in his statement in May 1988 simply cannot be met. The tax is a clear disincentive to savings and will simply discourage people from entering superannuation which, as I said earlier, is desperately needed if this country is to have a proper and planned retirement package for people as our population steadily starts to age. Far from seeking to encourage more people into superannuation, the Government has reduced the incentive for self-provision even further with the income tax reductions announced on 12 April.

In speaking to this package of Bills during the second reading debate, I have outlined why the Opposition is taking a strong and a firm line and why the Opposition is seeking to excise the 15 per cent tax on superannuation income investment. Put simply, this is because people will be disadvantaged. It is not a good enough reason to say, `Because the Government has been negligent, has not been diligent in getting this package of Bills into the Parliament so that there could be more accurate and reliable planning by the industry, ordinary Australians will suffer by the enactment of this package of Bills'. This is the reason that the Opposition is taking such a strong stand and wishes to see that 15 per cent tax excised.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make this statement in reference to remarks made in the Senate earlier today by the President of the Senate, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, and Senator Harradine. Honourable senators would be aware that at the end of my speech during the adjournment debate last night, Senator Tambling moved that I table notes from which he claimed I had quoted. That motion was defeated.

SPEECH.PARA: After the adjournment I had a meeting with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Robert Ray, about the status of the material from which it was claimed I had quoted. In particular, my primary concern was that if the material was circulated, it would jeopardise the confidentiality of my sources and it was on this basis that I sought Senator Ray's advice as to what I should do with the material. Senator Ray advised that as the Senate had rejected the resolution that the material be tabled, I was free to do what I liked with it; therefore, to ensure the protection of my sources, the material was destroyed late last night in Senator Ray's office.

It has been requested that I make a statement on how I obtained any documents from which I quoted. I cannot make a statement giving details of how I obtained any documents as this could lead to my revealing my confidential sources, and like other politicians I will not disclose my sources; but, I can state unequivocally that I did not tape the meeting of the Pro-Life Group which took place last week.

In view of the President's statement today that he is investigating ways in which committee rooms in Parliament House can be made more secure with regard to their audio facilities, I will be more than willing to offer any assistance regarding this matter. In doing so, I again emphasise that I was not involved in the recording or taping of the meeting in question.

In his remarks in the Senate today, Senator Harradine made the point that he was disappointed that I did not have the courtesy to inform him beforehand that I was going to make some remarks about the Pro-Life Group and its meetings. I accept that I erred in not informing Senator Harradine and I apologise to him for that lack of courtesy. Although some honourable senators opposite believe it was improper for me to quote from sources about the details of the Pro-Life meeting, I note that in my short period in the Senate, Opposition members have never felt constrained from quoting in Parliament from documents which are clearly obtained by them in a clandestine manner. I have always accepted that an integral element of our democratic tradition is that when members of parliament obtain such information they will use it to their advantage. For example, during the Estimates debate last year Senator Tambling quoted extensively from leaked government documents. It is clear that he did not obtain those documents with the approval or consent of the appropriate authorities.

I reiterate my apology to Senator Harradine for not informing him beforehand. But I am not in a position, for reasons stated previously, to table any documents on this matter in the Senate and I am not able to detail how I received such documents because that may lead to the revealing of my sources. I do not believe that it is the Australian way to escape one's responsibility by dobbing in a confidential source.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are not to have any more general business Thursdays, I wish to raise some matters relating to annual reports which I think are important. Before I do so, may I say that Senator Schacht is not as attractive as Fawn Hall, but he certainly appears to have many similarities to Colonel Oliver North. On the matter of annual reports, I wish to deal first of all with the Aboriginal Development Commission and its annual report for the year ended 30 June 1988 but which was presented to this Parliament only this month. It is accompanied by a letter from Shirley McPherson, dated May 1988 which, I assume, means May 1989. This is yet another example of the disastrously incompetent annual reporting that comes from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw the attention of the Senate to the Australian Audit Office's audit covering this report dated 18 April 1989, which is very critical indeed and which is, naturally, a qualified report. Many of these matters have been covered in Senate Estimates committees and it was certainly most unfortunate that this kind of report was not available at the time when we had Estimates inquiries into governmental institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we complained about it at the time but got nowhere.

—As Senator Short said, we complained about it at the time but we got nowhere with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, or the Minister, in particular. Apparently this Government has no interest in the sort of honest reporting which is required for the Senate Estimates system to be effective.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor's report says that the receipt, expenditure and investment of money and the acquisition and disposal of assets by the Aboriginal Development Commission during the year had been in accordance with the Act with the exception of various matters. It says:

the commission provided capital for Yeperenye Pty Ltd for the future benefit of Aboriginals and not for the purpose of enabling particular Aboriginals to engage in business enterprise as required by sub-section 24 (1) of the Act. The amount provided-
in other words, improperly provided-
in 1987-88 was $1.5 million . . .
The report went on to say:

the Commission in some cases, when providing funds for enabling Aboriginals to engage in business enterprise, had left no specific evidence that it had complied with the requirement in sub-section 24 (3) of the Act, that it was satisfied that the Aboriginals were capable of engaging in that enterprise.
It continued:

The auditors' report on Baruwei Enterprises Pty Ltd and Baruwei Enterprises Unit Trust, dated 16 November 1988, were qualified because, in the opinion of the auditors, the valuation of the assets of the company and the unit trusts on a going concern basis was dependent on the continued support of unit holders.
The fact is that a provisional liquidator of Baruwei Enterprises Pty Ltd was appointed by order of the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory on 16 March 1989. The Auditor went on:

The auditors' report on Morr Morr Pastoral Company Pty Ltd was qualified because the company's valuation of cattle inventories at net realisable value represented a departure from Australian Accounting Standard AAS2.

The significance of that is that if normal accounting practices had been proceeded with, there would have been a substantial loss for the year, not the phoney profit claimed in this most unsatisfactory annual report.

It is interesting to note that the balance of the provision for doubtful debts for both housing and enterprise loans has been based on the assessment of Commission officers. I must say that I do not have massive confidence in that assessment of `bad and doubtful debts' and I will come to those in a minute. In the meantime, it would be nice if the annual report revealed why $529,000 was spent on consultants compared with only $28,000 the previous year.

The report is extraordinary in some respects. We see that enterprise loans have been made to a number of subsidiary and associated companies including Baruwei Enterprises Unit Trust, which received $2.37m, an increase from $1.78m the previous year. That company is now in receivership. Smiths General Contracting Pty Ltd received loans of $530,585. That company is not only in receivership but had its shareholding written off in 1979. The loans were not written off; they are still appearing in the balance sheet. Heaven knows why! Bad debts charged to the provision during the year totalled $2.2m, and I cannot find here a satisfactory explanation for those write-offs.

The annual report continues to be a saga of extraordinary and incompetent management. I am not saying who is responsible but I make this point about Morr Morr Pastoral Company. The auditor's report for that company, as disclosed in Note 1, says:

The company values cattle inventories at net realisable value. This method of valuation represents a departure from Australian Accounting Standard AAS2-`Valuation and Presentation of Inventories in the Context of the Historical Cost System.' Had the company's opening and closing inventories been valued at cost, the operating profit after income tax would have been decreased by $764,486, with consequent adjustments to current assets--

That is for the last two years. When we recognise that the claimed operating profit for 1988 was $56,215, such a decrease in the operating profit would have brought about a loss of almost three-quarters of a million dollars. Here we have this annual report pretending that the company has made a profit when, if we make the adjustment that is required by normal accounting standards, we see that it has in fact made a loss. The whole of the report raises serious questions about this kind of organisation. When we get to Yeperenye, we see an operating loss of $1.18m, which is almost double the total gross revenue of about $1.2m. We have interest charges on the bill facility of $1.07m. We have this extraordinary situation where it now seems impossible that these bodies can make a profit, or ever would have made a profit. Not even the doctoring of the accounts, by not adopting normal accounting standards, can hide this from any kind of reasonable examination.

According to the financial report Baruwei Enterprises Pty Ltd incurred an extraordinary loss amounting to $763,311. This amount represents a provision in respect of a shortfall of assets available to meet the liabilities of the company as trustee on behalf of the Baruwei Enterprises Unit Trust. It is no wonder that this annual report is so late, it is such a sorry saga.

I now turn to the annual report of the Australian Institute of Health for the year to 30 June 1988, which has been presented in this chamber towards the end of May, but which is dated April 1989. Surely this Government can do better than this. In passing, I mention some problems in the annual report. According to the report's `Achievements':

Perhaps the most serious problems have been concerns on the part of some State governments about the adequacy of the confidentiality provisions of the AIH Act. The Queensland Government, for example, has been concerned that the Act would appear to allow data provided to the Institute to be released to third parties, and has urged the Commonwealth Minister to amend the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to shut up?

—I thank the Minister for his advice. I know he does not want these annual reports and the detail in them to be revealed to the Parliament. That is why they are rushed in so late in the session when we are given no time to deal with them on General Business Thursday, which has been wiped out. So I understand his concern. I am also concerned in this matter that a very large amount of money has been spent on consultants with basically no explanation about who they are. I understand that is one of the requirements of reporting-that the consultants and the amounts being paid to them should be made available. Yet they seem to have been used very substantially.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple more points I want to make very briefly about this. There is a quarter of a million dollars worth of travel in the $937,000 worth of administrative expenses. No doubt someone at the Australian Institute of Health is travelling for the good of his health. This is yet another of those annual reports that are qualified by the Auditor-General. Do we have to have qualified reports every time? Cannot this Government smarten up its capacity to produce annual reports that are accurate and that do not have to have auditors' qualifications? For example, on capital expenditure commitments the annual report states:

This amount represents the value of a contract placed in 1987/88 for the upgrading of the Institute's computer system during the 1988/89 financial year. Under sub-section 23 (a) of the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987, the Institute is required to seek written approval from the Minister for Community Services and Health to enter into contracts exceeding $200,000. As the Minister's approval for the contract was not obtained until 3 November 1988 the Institute breached this sub-section of the Act during 1987/88.

Perhaps we can explain to the Institute of Health that $440,000 is more than the $200,000 limit for its activities, and that this kind of improper behaviour really should cease. The important thing is that this Government has got to smarten up its reporting act. No wonder Senator Walsh wants people to keep quiet, because obviously they have got a hell of a lot to hide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to take this opportunity to talk about the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) because we will not be able to continue that debate on General Business Thursday. I will not repeat the points which I made during my foreshortened contribution on the debate on the papers this afternoon. But at the time I was expressing concern about the fact that the debate on Aboriginal affairs in this Parliament is sadly distorted by the fact that every time there is an attempt to talk about Aboriginal affairs, all that is discussed is sensationalist allegations by the Opposition, often without any foundation, like the outrageous black Mafia allegation which everybody knew was untrue.
—Including Senator Tambling.

—Senator Tambling's black Mafia allegations distorted the whole debate. The Opposition has been lowering the tone for six to 12 months, and the victim is not this Government, which I regret to advise honourable members opposite has not lost a vote out of all those outrageous allegations. It has been the Aboriginal people in Australia who have suffered from it. I think we saw an example of it this evening. Senator Michael Baume was so enthusiastic to attack the Aboriginal Development Commission in its annual report, he apparently failed to note--
—I have attacked a whole lot of reports. I have not discriminated against anyone.

—No, I am not accusing the honourable senator of discrimination, I am simply saying that he failed to notice that the 12 months' service on which he was attacking this Commission, was the 12 months in which it was run by the commissioners so strongly defended and advocated by all his colleagues, and the organisation about which he was making those allegations is the organisation which his colleagues had so spiritedly defended. By saying that, I do not want to reflect upon the people who did run the Aboriginal Development Commission, neither Shirley McPherson, the Chairman as she called herself, nor those eight commissioners who were dismissed. SPEECH.PARA: I do want to take this opportunity to say that in my experience in dealing with Shirley McPherson I received nothing but cooperation from her. I found her to be a competent and responsible individual. I certainly dis- agreed with some of the things that she did in chairing the ADC but that is not unusual. One disagrees with a lot with people of goodwill and merit. I think she made some significant errors of judgment and I told her so. I would not say so in here without having said it to her. However, I think the goodwill which I feel and I hope I have expressed towards Shirley McPherson, and which I, with my colleagues, reflected in the majority report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs to those dismissed commissioners, has certainly not been extended to the seven commissioners who were appointed in their place, who were also honest people trying very hard to do a good job on behalf of Aboriginal affairs. I have not agreed with everything that they have done either, but the accusations that have been made about them and the way in which their reputations have been dragged through the mud have done the Senate, in which most of the allegations have been made, no credit at all. I have found it very sad that such circumstances should have taken place; not that those people should be exempt from criticism. When they make mistakes, they ought to be criticised, although of course it was not them who made the Woden Town Club decision. It is quite clear in here who made it. Nevertheless, they took the rap.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who made the decisions in September and October?

—I am not saying they should never be criticised; I am saying the honourable senator makes outrageous allegations, and he knows he does, because he just wants to get cheap publicity in the Darwin press. It does him no credit and it does this chamber no credit. Fortunately it does not win him any votes. I want to say some positive things about Aboriginal affairs. That will give everybody a bit of a shock, because nothing positive has been said in the Senate for quite a long time because it has all been cheap stuff. We ignore too often the positive achievements that have been made in Aboriginal affairs. To the credit of former commissioners, including Shirley McPherson, and of current commissioners and current staff, a lot of those positive achievements are recorded here. Sadly, none of them were referred to in today's discussion of the report, despite the fact that there is a large number of them. I will not try to detail them-that would be an abuse of the adjournment debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to a couple of significant things about forthcoming debates. One of them-a positive matter to which I want to refer in order to project into the future-is the fact that the Commission provided capital for Yeperenye Pty Ltd for the future benefit of Aboriginals. The Auditor-General expressed a concern not that it was a bad investment but that it may have been outside the terms of reference of the ADC. No-one says that the investment was made other than with propriety and, in this instance, proper auditing; the point that is made is that the Commission may have been entitled to make decisions not purely for the future benefit of Aboriginals, but rather for Aboriginals to engage in business enterprise. If that interpretation is correct-and the Auditor-General probably is correct-it is certainly a shortcoming in the ADC legislation which will be overcome when the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation is passed. The new corporations body within ATSIC will be able to make loans such as that, which will be successful and which, as the Auditor-General says, will be for the future benefit of Aboriginal people.

Now that the ADC has made a substantial contribution for quite a substantial period, it is time we moved on from appointed commissioners to elected commissioners. I welcome the fact that that reform is in the pipeline. It seems to me that the ADC annual report provides a record of some very substantial pluses, and also some minuses-some areas where it should be complimented, and some areas where it should be criticised. I simply want to take this opportunity to try to balance the ship a little because it has a tremendous list to the right. Everybody is leaping on every possible criticism of well-meaning people-whether former commissioners or current commissioners-trying to do the right thing on behalf of Australia and on behalf of their fellow Aboriginal people. I want to put on record the fact that I accept that they are all trying very hard honestly to do a good job, and in the main they are succeeding.

The Aboriginal people at Wreck Bay, which is in my constituency, have been advantaged substantially by the good work being done by the ADC. I want that to be on the record. There are continuing positive achievements in Aboriginal affairs. There is so far to go that it is somewhat premature to say how pleased we are with positive achievements, but the comment that a lot of people have done a lot of very good work on behalf of the Aboriginal people is overdue. Those people are not well served by the continuing sniping and mud slinging that goes on in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for long. I speak on the adjournment for the same reason as Senator McMullan and Senator Michael Baume. As the General Business days have been cut out, I will not have an opportunity to speak briefly to the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). First, I want to praise Shirley McPherson. Secondly, I want to condemn Senator Tambling. I do so for the same reason as Senator McMullan has just given. I did not intend to offer one word of criticism of Senator Tambling in my contribution-none at all. I would have been the last speaker in the debate today, but time ran out. My sole purpose in speaking, as on previous occasions-I refer not just to transcripts of evidence given to the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, but also to press statements-would have been to say something about the great contribution that Shirley McPherson has made.

SPEECH.PARA: My reason for wanting to devote some attention to Senator Tambling is that I note on the AAP news scan brief that has been going around today that, once again, he has achieved precisely what he continually sets out to do. He has got his bit of cheap publicity with a statement which is utterly false. He got to his feet in the Senate and accused the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) of having politically edited the ADC's annual report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Somebody did.

—Senator Tambling qualifies this once again by interjecting, `Somebody did'. It was not `somebody' that Senator Tambling accused today; it was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. That, of course, is reminiscent of the loose accusations that Senator Tambling has fallen into the habit of making. I refer, for instance, to his `black Mafia' accusations. On the very day on which he had made those accusations he retracted them in an interview on the 7.30 Report, saying, `I had to say something as sensational as that to attract the attention of the press'.

SPEECH.PARA: As we said at the time, and as Senator McMullan has just repeated, in the sensitive area of Aboriginal affairs there is endless room for criticism. There is no shortage of issues to criticise. It takes no talent or wit to criticise in the area of Aboriginal affairs. There is endless opportunity to do so. All previous Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs, from whichever side of the Parliament, know full well that it takes no great talent to drop buckets on Aboriginal affairs. In my view, where such buckets deserve to be dropped, in most cases they should be dropped. Indeed, I have run foul of Aboriginal organisations in the past by criticising them publicly. At times I have been criticised in some interesting joint acts. I still have on tape a joint press conference that was conducted by a Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Ian Viner, and a Chairman of the Northern Land Council, Galarrwuy Yunupingu. Some years ago, because of criticisms of the Land Council that I had issued, they, in a press release, confidently predicted my downfall in my Aboriginal seat of Arnhem at the next election. In fact, my vote went up from 69 per cent to 79 per cent. But never mind-I go back a long way in this business.

It is so easy to make those criticisms. Where they deserve to be made, they should be made. But where they do not deserve to be made, they should not be made. Unfortunately Senator Tambling has developed the habit-it is now almost like a nervous twitch-of making broad, sweeping statements, in some cases slanderous, and subsequently having to admit that they were not true at all. He has just done the same thing again tonight in an interjection. He does it simply to attract attention, to get a bit of publicity. I regret to say that in most cases he succeeds. People in public life should be a bit more responsible.

I know why Senator Tambling does it. As Senator McMullan said a few moments ago, the conservatives have not got a vote out of it. Nationally, in my view, Senator McMullan is perfectly correct. But I have no doubt that Senator Tambling has picked up a few votes out of in in the Northern Territory-and, by God, he would need to. Senator Tambling created history at the last Senate elections in the Northern Territory: he was the first conservative candidate in history not to get a quota-unheard of in the Northern Territory. However, it is not surprising that he could not get a quota, could not scrape 33 per cent.

I might add that in a front page story in the Northern Territory News, prior to the ballot, the former Chief Minister of the Territory, Paul Everingham, who was also the member for the Northern Territory in the House of Representatives, predicted it. He was right. He went further. These are Paul Everingham's words, taken from the front page of the Northern Territory News as he left the Territory to go to Brisbane. Not only did he predict that Senator Tambling would do worse than any other candidate in the Federal election; he said that when Senator Tambling got to Canberra the only thing he would do about anything would be to talk about it. That is from one of the honourable senator's own Country Liberal Party colleagues.

Senator Tambling has fallen back on the cheapest and easiest solution for any conservative politician in trouble in the Northern Territory: when in strife and in need of a few cheap votes, bash blacks. He has been doing it consistently for two years, in the absence-and this is my chief objection-of doing anything else. Speaking today about the ADC report, Senator Tambling said that it was important for what it did not say. If ever there is tabled in this Parliament a report on Senator Tambling's lasting contribution to public life, it had better be important for what it does not say because it will not be important for anything else. Not only do I not criticise Senator Tambling for making public criticisms of faults and failings in Aboriginal affairs; I have also joined him on a number of occasions, and he knows it. It is about time he stopped making these sweeping assertions on the basis of no evidence whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—In response to Senator Tambling's interjection, it was Senator Tambling himself who admitted on national television on the very evening he made his sensational statement about black Mafia-and it got the press he was looking for; it did enormous damage to the Aboriginal people of Australia-that he did not think it was correct but he had to say it in order to attract the attention of the press. There is endless material available to him that will get him legitimate press coverage for bucketing blacks any time he wants to do it. He does not have to manufacture it. He does not need to do it. It is not necessary to do it. So he should stop doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question at all that Senator Tambling's continual attacks have won him a few votes. It is true that he has developed a small and loyal group of people around him in the Northern Territory who constantly come up to him and say, `That's great work you're doing'. The Northern Territory News has said in editorials what a marvellous job Senator Tambling has done in uncovering all this graft and corruption. What did Senator Tambling do? What he did was to rip pieces of paper off his fax machine. I mention that because of what we are debating tonight in respect of Senator Schacht. Senator Tambling has been taking pieces of paper off his fax machine. They have dried up since the first onslaught. There is a small group of disaffected officers in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs who had to have someone to leak to, and he was the best leakee. He had a fax machine, so they sent him the pieces of paper. It does not take a lot of effort, wit or talent to pull pieces of paper off a fax machine and then run them in front of an Estimates committee. Anybody can do that. Of course, at the second Estimates committee, he fell on stony ground; the leaks had dried up. Despite a huge fishing expedition, with 400 questions he caught a minnow. That is all we have heard about since. When his leaks dry up completely, so will his so-called successful campaign on uncovering graft and corruption in Aboriginal affairs.

Once again today we have had the same performance from Senator Tambling. In the Parliament today, he accused the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs of politically editing the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission. That assertion is totally untrue, and in fact has been denied on behalf of the Government and the Minister by his representative in this chamber, Senator Tate. What was Senator Tambling's reaction to that being laid in front of him, after he had made the statement, not before? By way of interjection across the chamber, he said, `Well, somebody did'. If any proof positive was needed that there was no evidence there for him to make that statement, honourable senators have just got it. It is very easy in this business to make public slanders and then fix them up with what amount to private apologies. Once one gets one's headline, one is right, one is home. When it is revealed afterwards that the outrageous assertions and claims that were made are false and untrue, that does not rate a mention. The story is stale when it is old and gone and one has got one's bit of press. It is not up to me to offer Senator Tambling gratuitous political advice, but the worm in the Northern Territory, as well as here, is starting to turn.
I want to conclude by placing on public record here today my personal appreciation for the work of Shirley McPherson.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have redeemed yourself, Bob.

—Again, in relation to the interjection, if Senator Brownhill wants to provoke me, I will speak for the rest of the 20 minutes. Senator Tambling has been one of the chief bucketers of the ADC in this Parliament. There was another great bucket from Senator Michael Baume tonight. Again, I am not suggesting that some of those criticisms are not deserved. But the trouble with the Opposition in the area of Aboriginal affairs is that it does not know what it wants. It wants two bob each way and as much cheap publicity as it can pick up on the way through. That is its policy on Aboriginal affairs. The Opposition is quite happy to bucket the ADC-not just the existing commissioners chosen by the Minister but the previous commissioners-for what they did and decisions they made. It says at the same time, `This is the body that has to be preserved. This is the status quo that has got to be kept. It should be preserved and nothing should take its place'. Yet at the same time it buckets the daylights out of the Commission. That is the problem with the performance of the Opposition. It has as many policies and as much principle in respect of Aboriginal affairs as it has with every other portfolio area of good government.

SPEECH.PARA: Shirley McPherson was the Chairman of the ADC from 1984. I have had the privilege and pleasure of knowing her for all that time and of knowing and respecting the tremendous job she did with that organisation. To correct the record, because of what some honourable senators opposite said today, I have made public statements to that effect previously. I am not simply saying that in this Parliament today because it is convenient or proper to do so. In my view, in consideration of the fact, and it is a fact, that the tabling of this annual report coincides with the cessation of Shirley McPherson's tenure as Chairman of the ADC, it is appropriate that honourable senators on both sides of this House express appreciation-and I thank all honourable senators who have done so-for the work she has done. There are not very many Aboriginal women in Australia at this time who have the depth of experience, the tertiary education qualifications and the competence that Shirley McPherson has shown in that position. I regret to say that there are far too few. She is an exceptional person. She did an exceptional job as Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission. I regret the fact that she is no longer working in that area. I wish her well in her future endeavours. I have no doubt whatsoever, knowing Shirley McPherson as I do, that her absence from the area of Aboriginal affairs will be a temporary one and that she will return to make a further valuable contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak in the adjournment debate about a friend of mine who was today arrested and charged with a very serious crime, the matter of the Hilton bombing which occurred 11 years ago. I do not propose to canvass matters of evidence which are presently before the courts or the details of the conviction of Tim Anderson beyond what I raised in a notice of motion this morning. What I want to put on record is something of the history of my association with Tim Anderson and some of the difficulties he has already had in the Australian court system. I first met Tim Anderson in 1979 when I was working in the New South Wales gaol as a project officer. I was a sort of education officer concerned with the literacy of prisoners. I met Tim Anderson and his two colleagues, Ross Dunn and Paul Alister. At that time it was very clear to me from their appearance and manner in the gaol that they were quite different from other prisoners. From their manner, I could tell that they were truthful and sensitive people and that they had managed to make the best of a bad lot in prison.

SPEECH.PARA: I met them shortly after their second trial. Indeed, they have certainly got to see a lot of the court system during the last 10 years. They had one trial which resulted in a hung jury. They then faced a second trial, at which they were convicted. They were not convicted of the Hilton bombing but of conspiracy to murder Robert Cameron, the National Front leader. Ross Dunn and Paul Alister were convicted of attempting to murder the arresting police. I put this on the record because the media continue to make mistakes. Even today, I heard some media say that Tim Anderson was being arrested and charged for the second time for the Hilton bombing, which is absolutely not true.

I became interested in the case and read the transcripts. After reading the transcripts of those two trials, I was persuaded that they should not have been convicted on the basis of the evidence in the transcripts; so I decided to do something about it. I began to work on their campaign, along with Sydney lawyer-journalist Tom Molomby and New South Wales Labor parliamentarian George Petersen. In 1983 I decided to make a film about the case called Frame Up. Who bombed the Hilton? Who didn't?. I was not able in that film to answer the question of who had bombed the Hilton but I was able to answer the question of who did not bomb it. It was interesting that when Richard Seary, who was the police informer in the case, mentioned that he had been told in an alleged conversation by Ross Dunn and Paul Alister that they had confessed to the Hilton bombing, the foreman of the jury in the first trial said that he did not believe it. This was repeated by another juror in the second trial. The foreman of the jury in the first trial was, in fact, responsible for the outcome of the first trial. Then, in 1983, there was an inquest into the Hilton bombing incident at which much evidence was paraded before the Coroners Court in Glebe in Sydney, including what I would call a lot of shonky evidence. This included the evidence of one man who claimed to have seen Tim Anderson outside the--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I appreciate the personal concerns that Senator Dunn has in this matter, but I believe that canvassing evidence and the character of persons who may have given evidence, and making reflections upon those people, may be quite material to matters which are now pending before the court system in New South Wales. To use the forum of the Parliament and the privilege of the Parliament to make reflections upon the perception of the alleged truthfulness or otherwise of persons whose evidence is likely to play some role in determining future outcomes of judicial process is, in fact, getting very close to trespassing upon the understanding of the sub judice rule in this place. To that extent, I think some direction is needed from you, Mr President, as to the appropriate limits of what is permissible within the Standing Orders. Previous rulings on this debate might, in fact, be instructive to the Senate in its proceedings.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I am not canvassing any evidence that is a matter of a charge before the courts at present. In fact, everything that I intend to canvass tonight is, in fact, a matter of public record.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I have been listening very carefully to Senator Dunn. It is quite clear that she is moving into a very delicate area. I must say to the Senate that it seems to me that in her last few sentences Senator Dunn was canvassing possible evidence. Senator Dunn says that it is not evidence relating to the matters under which the accused is presently charged, but, with all due respect, I suggest to the Senate that Senator Dunn does not know what evidence the Crown will call in relation to that matter, nor does she know, for that matter, what evidence the accused will call on his behalf. She is, I submit with all due respect, talking about evidence in relation to two former trials. How those former trials may relate to this charge I do not know, but I suggest that Senator Dunn does not know. It is, I suspect, very dangerous for her to be canvassing any of these matters. She did start off by saying that she would tell the Senate something of the history of her association with the accused. Of course, the Senate has no objection to that. If she wishes at some stage to give evidence in relation to the behaviour of the accused in some way for his benefit, that will be up to her. I suggest to you, Mr President, that in the last few sentences of her speech, Senator Dunn started to open up areas of evidence in such a way that she ought not be allowed to continue.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tate

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you are faced with a very difficult situation, as indeed is the Senate. In all questions of sub judice you have to balance the absolute privilege of this place with the absolute privilege of the courts. It is a contest between the two. I think in this particular instance, the question of the Hilton bombing, the subsequent court actions and, indeed, the public inquiry, the pardon, the compensation, and the events surrounding the allegations are matters of very genuine public interest of a greater scope than attends normal trials to do with the killing of persons in our community. Unless this chamber were convinced that what Senator Dunn is speaking about could cause real prejudice to the trial in the sense of either creating an atmosphere where a jury would be unable to deal fairly with the evidence put before it, or would somehow perhaps affect a future witness in the giving of evidence, whether for the prosecution or the defence, and unless we thought that the matters Senator Dunn was trying to speak about were likely to cause real prejudice to the outcome of that committal proceeding or trial, I think, on balance, given the nature of the matters surrounding this whole incident over many years, that the public interest probably would allow her to continue.

INTERJECT.PARA: I think that she would agree that tremendous caution and prudence should be exercised. She must realise that some matters which she thinks are matters of history, in that they have been the subject of previous judicial proceedings or inquiries, could be very relevant to the future or foreshadowed committal proceedings or trial. It may be that she should refrain, if it is not pertinent to her real point, from discussing matters of evidence or giving her evaluation of the evidence. None of us really knows precisely-I have only seen media reports-what the police claim to be the new evidence which has allowed them to go to the magistrate. I think they opposed bail, but bail was granted. We ought to be fairly cautious but on balance, given the tremendous public interest in these matters over many years, I think the Senate is a forum in which these general matters can be discussed. I do not know whether that helps you, Mr President, in relation to the last two or three sentences about which Senator Lewis was speaking but I would not rush with a sub judice ruling to prevent a senator from raising a matter which is clearly of very great public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As Senator Tate has said, the Chair is in a very difficult position. There are no Standing Orders concerning this matter. A number of previous rulings have been made by previous Presidents. I will allow Senator Dunn to continue but I would advise her that she cannot question the merit or otherwise of likely evidence that could be used in the prosecution case, because it is obvious that this would prejudice any case that came before a jury. I will listen carefully to what she says.

—Thank you, Mr President. I certainly do not wish to prejudice the case at all, particularly when a friend of mine is concerned. My point was that there have been a number of legal forums-two trials, a Supreme Court appeal, a High Court appeal, a Hilton inquest and then a five to six month long inquiry into the charges against the three Ananda Marga people-in which much evidence has come out and which have canvassed what I would have thought was a fairly comprehensive range of evidence against them on all charges, relating not only to the Yagoona incident involving Robert Cameron but also to the Hilton bombing, which the police informer brought up at the trials.

SPEECH.PARA: The outcome of the 1985 section 475 inquiry was that Mr Justice White pardoned the three Ananda Marga people. Tim Anderson was pardoned on his conviction of conspiracy to murder Robert Cameron, as were the other two, and Ross Dunn and Paul Alister were pardoned on their conviction of attempting to murder the arresting police. They were also subsequently compensated. Each was paid $100,000 for the seven years out of a 16-year sentence that he spent in gaol. In the 11 years since the Hilton bombing Terry Griffiths, a policeman who was very badly injured by the Hilton blast, has been trying to get some kind of royal commission or inquiry going, without much success. I can only question why that has not occurred. It seems to me that that would be a very appropriate forum for an examination of what was purported to be Australia's first international terrorist incident.

At the time a senior Army man, Brigadier McKenzie-Orr, said at a conference that when the evidence from the exploded truck could not be found it was almost as if little elves had come and taken it away. That is a matter of record. The forensic laboratories failed drastically to provide very critical evidence about the nature of the Hilton bombing. I am very concerned that 11 1/2 years later any charges have been raised at all, considering the number of political forums.

I want to tell this chamber what Tim Anderson has done since he was released in May 1985. Since that time he has published one book and is about to publish another. I edited the first book, which was about the case he had been through. It was a very good book and was well received. The other book, which is about to be published, is about his gaol experiences. Tim Anderson is a highly intelligent, very articulate and very gentle person. He is very committed to social justice, as I mentioned in my notice of motion this morning. Since his release from gaol he has been particularly concerned to fight the practice known in New South Wales as police verbal. It is my contention that if innocence were restored to the three of them by pardon then we must conclude that at least 16 people were lying during the trial. Certainly there were unsigned records of interview. Mr Justice White chose not to comment on these particular matters. I accept that but it seems to me that this case is black and white and I have reached my own conclusions about it.

Tim Anderson has been involved in the anti-verbal campaign as a leading activist. It is a campaign which I have also supported. He has been writing his doctor of philosophy thesis, which is almost completed. He has bought a flat with the compensation money and he has settled down in a steady relationship. I doubt whether he would have been given bail today had there been any serious doubt about his threat to the community. I think the amount of bail was a bit stiff; he was asked to put up $60,000. I can understand his sense of shock and outrage when the police came to his flat and broke down his door at 7 o'clock this morning. On Australian Broadcasting Corporation television tonight he was so upset that he said that the witness who had come forward was a mark II Seary with a mark II frame-up. I sympathise with Mr Anderson's outrage because I understand that he has been through so much over the last 10 years, not only in the courts but also inside the gaol system, which is not the most enriching life experience, as we can imagine.

I do not want to say any more about this matter, except that if the charges are thrown out during the committal hearing or if a jury finds Tim Anderson not guilty after a trial then Mr Anderson will have been put through another awful ordeal which ought never have occurred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to remind the Senate that this afternoon when I spoke on the annual report of the Aboriginal Development Commission my opening remarks were:

SPEECH.PARA: This report is important for what it does not say, not for what it does say.

Initially I would like to commend the very hardworking staff throughout Australia of the Aboriginal Development Commission, which in the past year has laboured under extreme conditions of hardship and scrutiny and has got on with the work of fulfilling many great projects and targets for Aboriginal people. In any reviewing of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio I have attempted at all times to be constructive and to achieve major change that is significant for Aboriginal people. The two questions that I have repeatedly asked in the past year or so, either in this Parliament or outside, are: firstly, is the expenditure accountable; and, secondly, is the expenditure of that money on behalf of Aboriginal people efficient? The criteria I have used religiously are accountability and efficiency on behalf of increasing benefits for Aboriginal people.

As a result of that activity over the past year we have seen reports made to the Senate by Estimates Committee E in October last year and more recently in May. I remind the Senate that the majority reports of those two Estimates Committee E reports were signed by the Labor members of this Senate as well as by Opposition members. Whilst the Opposition members also handed down dissenting reports or reservations attached to them it is the results that need to be looked at. As a result of those appraisals by the Senate and Estimates Committee E we have seen instituted the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, of which Senator Collins and Senator McMullan are important members. We have seen the review of the special report of the Auditor-General, the special report of the Public Service Commissioner, the report by Mr Menzies, the investigations by the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges, the investigations and report of the Department of Finance, and a number of departmental and ministerial advisory investigations. There has been much information in all of those reports that requires urgent attention by the Government. Senator Collins made the point that he believed that my motives had been to bash blacks and bucket blacks. I reject those statements outright and say that Senator Collins, by uttering them in such a way, is totally misrepresenting me.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are accurate.

—They are not accurate, if one reviews them against all the areas of performance. The only Aboriginal people that I have ever named in the Senate, or anywhere else, as a result of those inquiries are people who have been subsequently shown by the various reports instituted by the Government or by Parliament to have been involved in areas requiring major investigation and report. I have never on any other occasion in any way bashed blacks or bucketed blacks and I challenge Senator Collins or any other honourable senator to come into the chamber and name any individual Aboriginal person to whom I have caused major embarrassment as a result of my naming him in any of the work of the Senate Estimates committees or the activities of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, which was referred to tonight by Senator McMullan and Senator Collins, contains some 40 recommendations, and the dissenting report contains other significant recommendations. The principal recommendations have been rejected by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and by the Government in the determination of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation that was recently tabled in the House of Representatives. The Minister and the Government have chosen to ignore the advice of Senator Collins and Senator McMullan. They have overridden or ignored them because they do not go along with those recommendations.

Both Senator McMullan and Senator Collins pointed out that there were many areas of positive achievement in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. If anyone should like to review the Hansard of Senate Estimates Committee E or my contributions in the Senate, they would see that there has been a recognition of those positive achievements. Certainly I accept that by far the greater weight of activity that I have been involved in has been in areas seeking to achieve change through either criticism or expose, particularly in the areas of accountability and efficiency.

I was highly complimented in an article in the Northern Territory News last Saturday by Senator Collins. While it essentially related to a number of other issues that must have equally upset Senator Collins in a political sense, my press secretary passed me a note on Monday morning and asked whether I had a new press secretary, because in the space of some 20 paragraphs of Senator Collins's article he named me some 16 times. Obviously the activities that we carry on in this place and in the electorate are upsetting and hurting him. I do not get involved in making broad, sweeping statements across the area of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio.

All of the comments on the areas that I address, in seeking to debate either the ATSIC legislation or the administration or expenditure of money, are based on hard facts. That is well demonstrated by all of the evidence that has been presented to Estimates Committee E and by the numerous inquiries and investigations.

Minister Hand must accept responsibility for the report tabled in the Senate today. The Minister tabled it in the Parliament. As I said earlier today, the report is important for what it does not say. The document has a glaring layout, and Mrs McPherson-who even Senator Collins acknowledged has done a remarkable job for Aboriginal people-is given a three-line appraisal in the biographies shown against the names of the commissioners.

The other potted biographies go into much more detail for the commissioners who were appointed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in May 1988. They were much more genuine, even to the extent that the photographs showed them in a better light, whereas Mrs McPherson is shown with a glare. Why was the report of the Chairman of the Commission, Mrs McPherson, not included in this year's report as it has been included for the past six years? Why in the list of commissioners is the name of Charles Perkins, who was a commissioner to 30 June 1988 along with the other people whose potted biographies and photographs were included, omitted? Obviously, in the eyes of the Government, he is the man who never was. The Government does not want to give him credit for the statutory appointment which he held.

As I said earlier today, it is also important to recognise the other commissioners who were not acknowledged in the report at all for the 10 1/2 months of significant work that they carried out in that year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a shame!
—What a shame, as Senator Stone says.
—Shabby stuff.

—Shabby stuff. As we are well aware, the report was delayed before presentation to the Senate. We had to agree to two extensions of time for it. The omissions from it and the changes in it will probably require further investigation. I am very mindful of moving a motion in due course to have the matter referred to the Public Accounts Committee, which is currently undertaking a major inquiry into the presentation of annual reports to this Parliament. It would be very interesting to see how this report measures up to the guidelines of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with regard to the presentation of annual reports. It would be very interesting to know who deleted and why he deleted the particular reference to commissioners and the traditional introductory remarks of the Chairman.
—How do you know they were ever there?

—If they were not there, why? They should have certainly been part of the normal drafting by any comparison, even with past years. The report that has been handed down today is certainly a shabby document and an insult to this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to refute any comparison between the information which has been made available to me over the past year and which has led to the very significant inquiries, reports and recommendations to this Parliament and the activities of Senator Schacht in this chamber last night, who attempted to present in this place information from a meeting of senators and members of parliament within the precincts of this Parliament. There is a very major and significant difference. Senator Collins always enjoys having two bob each way on issues and I believe that his contribution to this adjournment debate tonight certainly highlighted that fact.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

(6) The effect of CESRF activities in terms of reduced Reserve Force wastage cannot be quantified. CESRF activities represent part of a corporate approach to retention. The National Chairman CESRF has advised that it is estimated that when CESRF first started the Army Reserve alone was losing some 1500 soldiers per year due to employer resistance. Within twelve months the loss rate directly attributable to employer resistance had been significantly reduced, particularly in states with an active CESRF group.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 May 1989 (Hansard p. 1959), Senator Newman asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training advise the Senate when it may expect the Government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children, which was presented to the Senate on 18 May last year? Does the year's delay indicate the Government's commitment to making a major response to this important report, or is it simply an indication that the Government's rhetoric about the need to encourage a skilled work force is simply window-dressing without any concern for the plight of our most able children ploughing through the education system?
The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Government's response to the Report of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children will be tabled in the next sitting period, commencing 23 May 1989.
